column2: In this new collection of essays, Mordecai Richler speaks in passing of the old-time Catskill comedians known .as tummlers, and a note of affectionate admiration can be heard in his voice.
The engagement of Miss Judith Terry Sim to John Manfred Sartorius Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Craig Sim of Garden City, L. I., parents of the future bride.

At a time when a great part of the world seems in a state of frazzle, it's comforting that International House will celebrate its golden jubilee of weaving harmony among more than 50,000 young graduate students from many countries.

Miss Marianne Giniger, an editor and translator for the French Embassy offices here, was married yesterday afternoon to John LaVette Moncrief Jr., a lawyer. State Supreme Court Justice Sidney Ash performed the ceremony at the Gotham.

My recommendations of 1974 fiction worth spending some beach or lakeside time on this summer had best begin with a couple of caveats. Notwithstanding the urgings of billboards and skywriters, I have not read Peter Benchley's "Jaws."

At our house we have been discovering the latest economic miracle. It is called the "pass through." At first it looked like the keenest idea to emerge from the economic science since the Caesars came up with bread and circus.
Miss Suzanne Sommer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan B. Sommer of Saddle River, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to William Ray Brakebill, son of Mr. and Mrs. James William Brakebill of Memphis.

Women have made so many advances in athletics during the last year that just about every men's sport has been invaded at varying degrees of proficiency.
President Nixon is planning to abolish the Attorney General's formal list of subversive organizations, according to Administration officials.
MINEOLA - The Nassau County Police Department has started a special squad to investigate the growing number of bicycle thefts.
Queens may be the only county in the nation where the Democratic county committee has two annual dinners in the same year and this year there may be three.

David Mancuso, the philosophic young music lover whose weekly parties have become a Saturday night sensation for several hundred devoted followers but a persistent headache for his artistic neighbors, has been ordered by the Build.

New York Telephone Company customers will have to pay a dime to call information and directory assistance under a plan adopted on a vote of 3 to 2 by the State Public Service Commission and announced today.

Ron Klotzer of Union set at state record of 196 feet 2 inches in the discus throw today at the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association group track and field championships.

The engagement of Miss Maureen Merhoff to Peter A. Velde has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Merhoff of Fond Du Lac, Wis. Mr. Velde is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Velde

Hymie Zorinsky is a longtime downtown businessman whose property is being taken by the city for "progress." He doesn't like what the city has offered for the property and is of a mind to fight City Hall.
Pope Paul VI today expressed his "growing anxiety" over the situation in Ireland, and appealed for an end to the violence.

Miss Jane Kathryn Gardner, a magna cum laude graduate of Williams College, class of '71, was married in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., yesterday to Wynne Shepard Carvill, who graducated summa cum laude from Williams the same year.

Miss Catherine Marks McCreary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Newberry McCreary of Larchmont, N. Y., was married yesterday at noon to the Rev. Joel Edward Strauch, minister of the Highland Avenue Congregational Church in Orange, N. J.

Day-care centers have become the salvation of scores of unused movie houses, synagogues, factories, garages and stores around the city. The conversions have meant a shot in the arm for the neighborhoods surrounding the old buildings.
A large and powerful Wisconsin crew won the national intercollegiate rowing championship today in impressive style

A son was born May 21 to Mr. and Mrs. John W. Geary 2d of New York and. Southampton, L. I., in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Geary is the former Hilary Somers Roche, daughter of J. Jeffrey Roche of New York and Mrs. Sidney D. Wood. Jr. of New York and Southampton.

Almost by definition, cancer is a one-way process. It starts for reasons that are usually mysterious. Unless something drastic is done to halt it, such as surgery or radiation, a cancer grows, sometimes rapidly, sometimes slowly, until it kills.
The proposed 96th Street luxury apartment building ["96th Street Development Set, "May. 12] represents the beginnings of an assault on the West Side community. This assault will have various effects.

The Protestants of Northern Ireland are now being confronted by both the British Government and their own extremists with the consequences of their abandonment of power-sharing with the Catholic minority. The hard-line Protestant leaders are arguing that an independent, Protestant-dominated northern state is a viable alternative to another Protestant-Catholic coalition government, which London demands and they eschew.

Donald Quarrie, the little Olympian from Jamaica, upset Ivory Crockett, the world record-holder, and Steve Williams in the featured 100-yard dash today before a crowd of about 1,000 in the Kennedy Games.
The huge combines, looking from a distance like famished dinosaurs, were chewing up Oklahoma's winter wheat crop this 'week and spewing it into the trucks that followed them.

With Whistler, Sargent, Cassatt, Eakins, Homer among its painters, Stieglitz and Jacob Riis pioneering in photography, and designers and architects such as Tiffany, Olmsted and Sullivan at work, the period from 1865 to 1900 was indeed a gilded age for art in America.

While the aftermath of today's acquittal was filled with delirious relief for seven harness-racing drivers and their families, their happiness was tinged with bitterness over the nightmarish circumstances that had wreaked havoc with their lives. .
Summer, a time for picnics, camping and easy living, is also, unfortunately, the prime season for foodborne illnesses.

Johns Hopkins, as well-known for its strong lacrosse team as for its world-famous school of medicine, finally established its national supremacy in lacrosse today when it won the national collegiate title by beating Maryland, 17-12, in the final of the fourth annual N.C.A.A. tournament at Rutgers Stadium.
Thirteen Persons were seated in a semicircle in an aged building on the Fort Totten Army base. All were dressed casually; some were wearing guns.
Guy Earl Conrath, who retired as a New York insurance executive in 1971, died Friday at his home, 2 Mansfield Place in Darien, Conn. He was 68 years old.

Gerry Russell of Lafayette swept the sprints and Brooklyn Tech won the team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League city wide track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

With whom would you like to swap lives for a month? I asked the question recently at a dinner party. A Hollywood agent picked Henry Kissinger; a sports-obsessed film producer wanted to be George Plimpton; I was torn between Billie Jean King and Barbra Streisand;

Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. O'Connor of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Carolyn O'Connor, to Steven Mark Gluckstern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gluckstern of Amherst, Mass.

Mrs. Anne Tilney Holmes of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julie Sage, to Jerome Corbin Day of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Day, also of Llewellyn Park.
The state's Democratic voters will choose a candidate for Lieutenant Governor Tuesday in a run-off election in which Gov. George C. Wallace has steadfastly maintained his neutrality.

PARIS. "I don't want my life to obey any other will but my own," Simone de Beauvoir wrote in her diary when she was 19. She has indeed made her own life, and the will of others has played a remarkably small part in it.
Rod Jenkins rode Number One Spy to the open jumper championship tonight to wind up a dazzling exhibition of horsemanship at the concluding session of the Devon Horse Show.

Night watchmen and guard dogs are being replaced at many companies by the use of closed circuit television cameras for security purposes. The companies that make the cameras report a booming business.
MOUNT HOLLY-The Burlington County Office of Consumer Affairs has embarked upon a bold experiment. It is using "Mr. and Mrs. Average Shopper" to uncover false or deceptive advertising.
These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

Miss Patricia Josette Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Wilson 3d of Ridgefield, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt., was married at noon yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield to David Joseph Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Perkins Jr. of Raymond, N. H. The Rev. John Sabia performed the ceremony. eremony.
Dr. George W. Hill, medical director of the Ossining (N.Y.) Correctional Facility and an attending physician at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y., died Friday at the hospital.

The marriage of Miss Susan Ellen Bender to Alvin Keith Klevorick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Klevorick of Rego Park Queens, took place here yesterday evening at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. Rabbi Edward E. Klein performed the ceremony.

" Power!" exclaimed the Rev. John J. McLaughlin, pacing his tiny office. "What do we know about it? We don't know anything about it. We have sex education-why don't we have power education? You can train yourself to handle power."

BANGKOK-Thailand's self-conscious "experiment in democracy," which is going on eight months, has survived its first leadership crisis and is moving toward general elections at the end of the year. The Thais, aware that they are going against a trend to authoritarianism in Asia, are far from cocky about their experiment, which began unexpectedly last October when thousands of students and ordinary citizens took to the Bangkok streets and drove out a detested military regime.

Dr. Anthony Della Rocca, an eye surgeon, died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, while attending an ophthalmology congress in Paris. He was 72 years old and lived at 30 Colonial Road, White Plains.

Joseph F. Madine, president of the National Association of Wholesale and Restaurant Meat Purveyors, died Thursday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the Southampton (L. I.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Southampton.

At least 60 South Vietnamese troops were reported killed, wounded or missing as 1,000 infantrymen battled against heavy artillery tonight to recapture a village on Saigon's northern defense perimeter.

Two arbitrary rules govern this sampling of recent biographies. First, all have been published since the beginning of this year. Second, "summer reading" is not a consideration: "Put 'Hitler' in your beach bag" just isn't a workable approach.
A plastic sealant applied to I schoolchildren's teeth has reduced decay by about two-thirds, according to state officials.

WASHINGTON-The fifth annual Brookings Institution "budget book," published last week, contains a bewildering array of information. Although it is 269 pages long, it is not susceptible to book-review treatment because it covers so much unrelated ground.

PORT WASHINGTON With little fanfare, suburban libraries increasingly have taken on the role of community centers. Diversified, centrally located and attuned to community needs, libraries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are growing yearly in both size and scope, backed by the people they serve.

A four-day auction that ended yesterday at the Louise C. Morgan estate, Salutation, on West Island, near Glen Cove, L. I., brought a total of $1,211,535. This was described as "a record for a house sale" by a spokesman for Sotheby Parke Bernet, which conducted the auction of the estate's rugs, furniture, art objects and personal belongings. .
Have you ever heard of a Tibetan mastiff? A Little Lion dog? Or a Chinese crested? If you haven't, there's no need to be apologetic, Few in the United States have.

So much had hapened since we first learned of Marty and Mark being pro draft choices, and there had been little time to think of all the many changes and adjustments that would affect our lives.
Two points are implicit in the Nixon Administration's special report on the state of the economy: Inflation is both serious had persistent; the methods to combat it will be orthodox and painful.

TRENTON-In response to environmentalist pressures and in fulfillment' of campaign promises by Governor Byrne, the state Democratic administration has drafted a $150-million 'Green Acres bond issue for legislative approval.

Miss Joan Killian Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Gallagher of Armonk, N.Y., was married in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday afternoon to John Sheppard Warden, son of Dr. and Mrs. David E. Warden of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

Miss Priscilla Finley Gray and Richard Goodwin Moon were married yesterday afternoon in Old Wye-Church in Wye Mills, Md., by the Rev. William Hargett, rector, of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Centreville, Md.

In these days of instability in sports, where new leagues and franchises are emerging every month, where in a players' market the allegiance to team, city and fan are at best capricious, the concept of arrogance and insensitivity to one's community and environment has to be altered.

Today -- Drag racing, Madison Township Raceway Park, Englishtown, N.J., 2 P.M.

Stanley Van Ness, who recently added the post of New Jersey public advocate to his portfolio as public defender, thinks the state will be able to save money by relying on in-house instead of outside counsel to represent consumer interests in utility cases. Stanley Van Ness
Brian Redman of England charged past Mario An dretti midway through the race today and won the $58,000 Mid-Ohio Formula 5000 auto road race.
Mrs. Judy Rankin was declared the winner of the $40,000 Baltimore tournament on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today after heavy rain washed out the final round of the 54hole event.
President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after spending a rainy day at Camp David, Md., with his wife and his friend. Charles G. Rebozo.

Negotiations here on reductions of troops in Central Europe are moving ahead slowly, with current emphasis on which of the NATO and Warsaw Pact countries involved will make the initial cutbacks, an American spokesman said this weekend.
An 83-year-old man was found beaten and stabbed to death yesterday in his room at the Martinique Hotel, where he had moved following the collapse last August of the old Broadway Central Hotel.

To the Editor: In a May 23 Op-Ed article I examined the contention of Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski that by recently raising the jurisdictional issue of his standing to sue the President the White House violated the promise of independence that was made to Mr. Jaworski.

Misjudging the finish line only 90 feet from victory, John Vitale watched helplessly as Ronald Wayne suddenly spurted past him to take the Yonkers marathon by six feet today. Ron Wayne, of Brockton, Mass., beating John Vitale by one-fifth of a second after 26 miles 385 yards of running in the Yonkers Marathon yesterday. Time was 2:18:52.8.

The Duke Ellington Society, which has presented a concert of Ellington music once each year since 1961, entered the post-Ellington era yesterday afternoon at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, by turning over its 14th annual concert to Clark Terry's 18-piece band.

The Soviet press, in its first significant comment on President Nixon's visit since the date was announced on Friday, stressed today that the summit meeting beginning June 27 enjoyed the backing of Democrats as well as Republicans in Congress.

Most orchestral players like an occasional solo night out, so why not a choral singer? Lin Garber, who has worked with the Gregg Smith, Camerata and other major vocal ensembles, successfully took the plunge Saturday night with a debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Dr. Edward H. Alhano, the state's Chief Medical Examiner, says that proposed legislation authorizing the practice of acupuncture in New Jersey by "qualified and certified" specialists would prevent exploitation of patients by an unregulated "racket."

About 50,000 pupils, chosen at random in all of the city's 32 community school districts, will be retested for reading ability today and tomorrow because of irregularities found in some schools after the annual reading test in April.

Forty scholars and religious figures will meet at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine today for a four-day international symposium on the "full meaning" of the Nazi slaughter of six. million Jews during World War II.

A Morris County Court jury will resume deliberations today in the trial of the chief of detectives of Paterson and a Passaic County detective who are accused of accepting bribes to protect a gambling operation.

John James of Katonah, N. Y., who ranked as a top junior in Australia before coming to this country, won the Long Island men's tennis championship today by defeating 18-year-old Mike Grant of Roslyn in the final, 6-0, 6-4, at the Tower Tennis Club.

Once there was a little boy named Big Mac who would not eat pizza or peanut butter or Happy Birthday cake. All he would eat were Big Mac hamburgers from McDonald's. Whenever Big Mac felt hungry, he would point to his mouth and say, "Aaah . . ." Then his parents would say, "Oh-oh. Let's get up and get away to McDonald's."

An 18-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged with the murder of her infant son last night after admitting to the police that she had punched the child in the chest earlier in the day as punishment for his slowness in learning to walk.

Rain forced the postponement yesterday of the Mets' game against the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium. Before the Mets suffered their seventh washout of the National League season, the teams had divided the first contests. of a scheduled three-game weekend series. No makeup date was set, but the Astros will return to New York only once more this season, during the final week of August.

Senator William Proxmire Democrat of Wisconsin charged today that the Pentagon was experiencing "outrageous" cost overruns on 55 major weapons systems. He said that the difference between original development estimates and current cost estimates now totaled $26.3-billion.

Borders aren't what they seem in this steamy enclave of Angola, rich with petroleum offshore and timber inland. Cabinda, north of Angola proper and above the estuary of the mighty Congo River, is surrounded by hostile territory--the Congo Republic to the north and Zaire everywhere else.

A lively mixture of creative expression and career concerns marked Black Creative Weekend, an attempt by the Community Action Team of Montclair and North Essex to encourage the aspirations of young people.

The Arab oil producers maintained today their embargo on the Netherlands at the insistence of Saudi Arabia. They set up a special fund for Arab countries without oil to offset deficits resulting from higher oil payments.

A rocket from Communist launchers struck a South Vietnamese prison housing Vietcong and other political prisoners near Bien Hoa air base before dawn today, killing 29 and wounding 63, the police reported.

Seven bills designed to help discharged mental patients make their way back into society and to ease the burden of their return on local comnlunities, have been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office reported yesterday.

About 3,000 persons began moving back to their Lincolnshire villages tonight, hoping that their tomes had escaped damage from the blaze that followed yesterday's explosion of a chemical plant at Flixborough. Firefighting at the Nypro chemical plant in Flixborough, England, continued for more than 24 hours. The blaze destroyed the $50-million factory.

D.I.D. In a series of Monday evening get-togethers, the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is providing an opportunity for you to fraternize with some video luminaries.
The credit-market schedule this week includes $655-million in new corporate offerings; $445-million in new tax-exempt bond offerings; and $500-million of new tax-exempt note offerings,

There are festivals of animated films, of comedy films, of sports films. There are festivals devoted to short subjects, to films on mountain-climbing, to films that celebrate human values.

W. Whittredge Katzenbach, who retired in 1958 as treasurer and vice president of Katzenbach Warren, Inc., wallpapers, died yesterday at his home in Westport, Mass. He was 66 years old and formerly lived in New Canaan, Conn.

One more thing is disappearing, relinquished forever to nostalgia and memory and those few history or sociology books that may characterize it as yet another example of the kind of thing that floundered and finally lost its place in modern times.

FACT, the First American Congress of Theater, began a four-day "summit conference," in Princeton, N. J., yesterday to discuss the common artistic and economic concerns of the commercial and institutional theater.

Mrs. Ruth Aronson Lipsky, a psychologist with the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education for 14 years and the wife of David Lipsky, a theatricall publicity man, died Saturday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital.
A major steamship company, Prudential-Grace lines, will transfer its $15-million-a-year cargo operation from Port NewYark to the new Northeast Marine Terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront.
Thirteen persons were willed and 31 injured when a bus went out of control and olunged into a ravine yesterday, the police reported.
In the finals of the Reisinger knockout team championship, the most prestigious event in the New York bridge calendar, the defending champion, headed

A statistical study of municipal water supplies in 94 American cities has linked a corrosive factor in drinking water to fatal heart attacks. According to the investigators who did the study, the corrosive factor exerts its greatest damage in soft water by attacking pipes.

Despite the sense of triumphant diplomacy that the Israeli-Syrian troop disengagement pact has evoked, both sides at Geneva are keenly. aware that successes so far have been easy, compared with the problems ahead.
Israeli and Syrian military negotiators reported that they had made "considerable progress" today in drafting the technical arrangements for separating their forces on the Golan Heights.
The Gulf Oil Corporation said over the weekend it was reducing its gasoline price to retailers by 1.3 cents per gallon for regular and premium, and 2 cents per gallon for no-lead.

Steady rain dampened banners but not enthusiasm for the annual Puerto Rican Day parade here yesterday. Although the crowd along Fifth Avenue was sparser than usual, spirits were high as ever. For the Puerto Rican Day Parade here yesterday, one m youngster found a see-through umbrella just the thing.
Lilian Arnold, a theater talent representative who had run her own office here since 1957, died yesterday in Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 69 F years old and lived at 134 West 58th Street.

Representative Jerome R. Waldie, Democrat of California, said today that he heard President Nixon make an ethnic slur on a White House tape recording that is in the possession of the House Judiciary Committee.

The New York State Senate Select Committee on Crime chastised the Queens Criminal Court's Bar Association for exonerating Supreme Court Justice Albert H. Bosch in his handling of two cases that the committee is investigating.

The head of the National Urban League chided elements in the Jewish community yesterday who, because of their concern over quotas, "are no longer including themselves in the coalition to build a more equal society."

The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization presented a political platform today that bars participation by a Palestinian delegation in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva unless the terms of reference used
Adnan Barnieh, an officer in the Syrian secret police, was proudly showing his friends an autographed photograph of Henry A. Kissinger, whose life he had guarded during 13 visits here this month.
Colgate piled up 42 points today to win the team title in the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament, its first crown in 52 years of competition. Penn State, with 32 points, finished as runner-up.
A former inmate of Green Haven Prison graduated from Vassar College with general honors today.

Developing countries will face shortages of grain by 1985 that they probably will not to be able to afford to meet through imports if present trends in population growth and demand continue, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported today.

Thirteen became the Princeton University tennis team's lucky number when it beat Harvard to win its first pastern Intercollegiate Tennis Association title in four years. Posting a 13-0 won-lost record, with nine shutouts, the Princeton squad fielded only one upperclass player on its way to ending Columbia's two-year dominance of eastern collegiate tennis.
The King of Bhutan, Jigme Singhi Wangchuk, was crowned today in a ceremony that sought to merge the traditions of Buddhism with the awakening of this remote Himalayan nation.

Terry Bradshaw said today he had spurned a substantial offer from the New York Stars of the World Football League and signed a multiyear contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League.
William, Mager of Norwalk, state commander of the American Legion, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital after having suffered a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

Everything appears to be breaking well for Gaylord Perry. Some day he may even be considered a law-abiding baseball citizen and his greaseball throwing antics will be left for the library shelves where his book, "Me and the Spitball." sits.

Federal mediators kept in touch with both sides by telephone yesterday but failed to halt the strike begun Saturday by 110,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America against 750 manufacturers of men's and boy's clothing across the country.

" I just put the mike in my pocket, went out there and let the fans know exactly what was going on," said Tom LaSorda, third base coach of the Los Angeles Dodgers. LaSorda was hooked in on yesterday's nationally televised game between the Dodgers and Chicago Cubs so the third-base coach could tell the viewers what the strategy was as it developed.

WASHINGTON--Arab oil earnings will rise by $65 billion this year, the amounts will get even bigger in following years, the balance-of-payments positions of the consuming countries will plunge into the abyss, the international monetary system will collapse, the Arabs will buy up all our companies-so goes the refrain heard frequently since the dramatic increase in oil prices in December.

More than 10,000 Boy and Girl Scouts gathered here this weekend to reaffirm their faith in the traditional tenets of Scouting and to demonstrate their growing involvement in community service. Cub Scouts from Pack 176, Babylon, L.I., at an Indian crafts exhibition during the weekend gathering of Boy and Girl Scouts at Stony Brook, L.I.

An Israeli border patrol killed two Palestinian guerrillas infiltrating across the Lebanese frontier late yesterday, the military command said. The incident was said to have occurred in western Galilee about six miles from the Mediterranean Sea.
Mayor Richard J. Daley was reported in good condition today after undergoing surgery for removal of fatty deposits in an artery on the left side of his neck.
How much should be Federal Government contribute toward the training of the nation's highest wage earners, physicians?
To those critics who have suggested that he openly zigss and zags" on such important issues as the release of taped White House conversations, Vice President Ford is fond of saying:

The New York City Police Department has racial problems, but unlike many other similar institutions, it is making a convincing attempt to overcome them in at least two ways. First, Commissioner Michael J. Codd, in a policy statement acknowledging some racial polarization in the department, has directed firmly that internal interracial confrontations be investigated by superior officers "who will be held accountable for their

With muted Republican opposition and little fanfare, John L. Burton, a Democratic State Assemblyman, is preparing to claim the Congressional seat of retiring Representative William S. Maillard, a Republican, in a special election Tuesday. A Burton victory would mark the fifth for a Democrat in six special Congressional elections this year - all in customarily strong Republican districts.
The State Board of Law Examiners today announced the names of 687 applicants who passed the examinations for admission to the bar given last March 11 and 12.

This year's dance concert by the High School of Performing Arts on Saturday night-using the auditorium of another school (the High School of Art and Design, 1075 Second Avenue)-carried the interest of commissioned works created by professional choreographers and dancers.

A Soviet Union junior wrestling team, making an eight-stop tour of the United States, ran its won-lost record to 5-0 last night by winning all 10 matches against a group of Wyoming High School all-stars for a 20-0 triumph.

Brian Redman of England charged past Mario Andretti midway through the race today and won the $58,000 Mid-Ohio Formula 5000 auto road race. It was Redman's fifth straight victory in the series over two seasons.

Members of the international oil cartel-the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries-are concerned about the way world inflation is cutting into the real increase in income they achieved by quadrupling crude oil prices. New York's rock Anglophiles were out in force Sunday night. They didn't quite manage to fill the Academy of Music for Roxy Music-which had a recent No. 1 album in Britainbut they managed to greet Roxy with rapture.

MONTREAL--In a bleak frozen wilderness 600 miles beyond the Arctic Circle, a team of Canadian scientists is measuring ice floes and charting polar bear tracks in what could turn out to be one of the world's most ambitious pipeline projects.

PARTICIPANTS-The Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., representing 750 manufacturers of men's and boys' suits, topcoats and overcoats, and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, representing 110,000 machine operators, cutters, markers, button and pocket makers.
The Government has agreed to accept payment of $1,100 by former Vice President Agnew for nearly $180,000 in improvements made to his Washington home at Government expense.

The Bon Vivant Soup Company has agreed to let the United States Government destroy 1.5 million cans of Bon Vivant soup and other foodstuffs, after fighting for three years against the action. The value of the foodstuffs was estimated at $600,000.
A number of brokerage houses have found themselves tilting at rumor mills in recent days and trying to resolve the delicate question if where flirting ends and courtship begins.
The Brit ish. Government moved ahead today with plans to provide some form of limited selfgovernment for Scotland and Wales to meet rising demands of nationalist groups in both regions.

Gay Brewer, Ben Crenshaw, Miller Barber and George Archer were among the more prominent pro tour golfers who failed to qualify yesterday at the Charlotte (N. C.) Country Club for the United States Open.

A. B. Volvo of Sweden reported yesterday its first quarterly earnings decline in four years despite record sales in the first quarter. Net income for the period came to $46.7million, or $1.77 a share, down from' $60.9-million, or $2.33 a share, a year ago.
The New York Stock Exchange board is considering extending the market close by a half hour to 4 P.M., a spokesman for the exchange reported yesterday.

About 110,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America abandoned their sewing machines and cutting tables yesterday, the first work day since their nationwide walkout began last Saturday. Sewing machines were idled at Rosenmond-Shiers on West 23d Street because of the strike by some 110,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market rose yesterday in stepped-up trading. The Amex market value index closed at 82.04, up 0.53 with advances outnumbering declines by 402 to 259, and 286 issues were unchanged.
The deadline for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Laos passed today with a considerable number of North Vietnamese soldiers reported still in the country.

Every year when the American Advertising Federation has its public affairs conference here the current chairman of the Federal Trade Commission is a luncheon speaker. Usually he doesn't have all that much to say.
The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted unanimously today to authorize the hiring of four lawyers to work full time on eliminating welfare cheats from the county's social services rolls.
ABRAMS--Nalhan, beloved husband of Rulh, devoted father of Heidl Ann, loving brother of Edith Broder and Samuel. Services today, 12:30 P.M., "Garlick's," 1439 Unionport Rd. at Parkchester, Bronx.
The greatest fear of the players on the tournament circuit is that they will run into an opponent's prepared variation that puts them out of business without a chance to make a real fight of it.
The constitutionality of the five-month-old Regional Rail Reorganization Act was challenged today before a threejudge Federal court by some creditors and stockholders of the Penn Central Railroad.

Henry Fonda's widely praised performance in "Clarence Darrow," a one-man stage play by David W. Rintels, will be presented on television this summer as a 90-minute prime time special. NBC-TV has scheduled the show for Sept. 4 with the International Business Machines Corporation as sponsor.

The city paid the highest interest rate in its history for revenue-anticipation and taxanticipation notes yesterday 7.019 per cent on a total borrowing of $431.8-million.

Supertanker Uncontrolled technology is the gravest menace to the future of people and the survival of a habitable planet. The nuclear arms race is the most hideous example of the danger of technology careening out of man's control.
Better weather over large areas of the Middle West caused a decline in the price of futures in corn, soybeans and wheat yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Production of steel in the week ended June 1 totaled 2,901,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 2.1 per cent over the 2,840,000 tons poured during the preceding week, and pushed the index of production to 118,9 from 116.4.

Bjorn Borg, Sweden's 17-year-old star, won the $16,000 top prize in the men's singles at the Italian open today, surprisingly overwhelming topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2. Bjorn Borg holding cups he won at the Italian tennis championships yesterday in Rome

" All theater is in a constant state of crisis," said producer Alexander Cohen today in the opening speech of the first plenary session of FACT, the First American Congress of Theater. "We all work under the sword of Damocles. It's about time we worked under a common shield."

Moody's Investors Service, which rates the creditworthiness of the nation's corporations, yesterday withdrew a key rating from U.S. Industries, Inc., making it more difficult for the giant conglomerate to sell its short-term commercial paper.

Senator Jacob K. Javits announced his candidacy for a fourth term yesterday, emphasizing his independence of President Nixon and castigating the "moral and systemic decadence that has led us to the disgrace and tragedy of Watergate." Senator Jacob K. Javits at news session yesterday.

Thomas J. Murphy, a retired Rochester newsman who had held many posts in the Newspaper Guild, died today at the age of 70. Mr. Murphy was an international vice president of the Guild, 1957-59; president of its Empire State Council and president of the Newspaper Guild of Rochester.
Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of scarlet tanagers have perished in recent days as a cold spell in northern New England blocked their spring migration.

State Controller Arthur Levitt warned yesterday of increasing defaults on stateguaranteed student loans for college and other higher education, estimating a potential loss of $88-million to $129-million, or 12 to 18 per cent, on loans outstanding last year.
The Argentine police arrested 98 Uruguayan political exiles last night while they were meeting to organize a protest demonstation against the militarycontrolled government in Uruguay.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here yesterday refused to stay the eviction of residents in Encounter, Inc., a drug-free program for addicts at 35 East 68th Street, a facility many residents in the area have opposed. The judges gave no

The House Judiciary Committee's decision last week to put off public, televised hearings for the time being was influenced by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, according to committee members and officials.

The House of Representatives voted the other day to repeal the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 and to let the Office of Economic Opportunity die next month. The Senate is likely to follow suit. The Times reported that Chester Higglns/From the book "Drims of Life"

William J. Prater, a former organizer for the United Miner Workers, was sentenced today to three concurrent terms of life imprisonment for the 1969 slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.
- The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court order blocking disposal of the assets of a company controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

The seven harness drivers acquitted last Saturday of fixing races got temporary licenses yesterday from the State Racing and Wagering Board.

Roger Pryor Dodge, dancer and choreographer who translated jazz dances into ballet format, died Sunday in 'the New York Infirmary. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 Fifth Avenue.

Sol Berg missed it. The rotund owner of the New York Sets, who backs them with. cheers and money, passed up a match for the first time this season and missed his team's first home victory in Nassau Coliseum before a crowd of 2,017.
The State Department acknowledged, today that the United States had agreed to support Israel in efforts to prevent guerrilla incursions from Syrian territory.
Israel and Syria said today they would sign a military accord on Wednesday on the practical arrangements for disengaging their forces.

If he had it to do over again, Larry Jones said yesterday he would not have signed his New York Giants pro football contract and taken his bonus money until he had finished his career as an amateur quarter-miler this spring.
IN THE DEEPEST PART OF SLEEP, A PLAT by Charles Fuller, directed by Israel Hicks, performed by the Negro Ensemble Company, at the St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, 7:30.
The people in this little coalmining town nestled in the valley of the Little Coal River in the green hills of West Virginia are not easily frightened by the threat of disaster, natural or otherwise.

An armed man died and a pedestrian was wounded yesterday in a bizarre happening in a sixth-floor apartment at 261 West 21st Street in which a l man and woman had been held hostage before the police arrived. Police officers rushing down West 21st Street to apartment house where gunman identified as John D. Portee was killed by gunfire yesterday afternoon.

Welfare recipients were taken by car to a city 18 miles away today to get food-stamp vouchers because four banks here had refused to handle the stamps or had limited their participation in the program.

A suspended narcotics detective was convicted of selling heroin and cocaine that he helped seize in a West Side police raid four years ago. On its fourth day of deliberations, a Federal jury in Manhattan found the suspended detective, Joseph Novoa, 32 years old, of 1738 33d Street, Brooklyn, guilty on all eight counts. A co-defendant identified only as Demetrios Papadakis, 30, was found guilty of one count of selling narcotics.

The National Kinney Corportion, one of the nation's largest building and real estate maintenance companies, announced yesterday that it had almost completed its acquisition of all outstanding stock and warrants of the Uris Building Corporation and that Uris stockholders would meet June 24 to consider merging Uris into Kinney as er a subsidiary.

A special investigative body representing the nation's 5,000 prosecuting attorneys reported here today that it was satisfied that the major oil companies were pursuing "anti-competitive practices and tactics."

The Governor's Task Force on Energy today recommended a series of measures to reduce and control energy supplies in New Jersey, including a graduated increase in automobileregistration fees from the present maximum of $35 to more than $200, an extra sales tax on electrical appliances and higher expressway tolls for automobiles with only one occupant.

Despite the current improvement in the availability of petroleum, the energy crisis "can be expected to last practically indefinitely," accoding to Thornton F. Bradshaw, president of the Atlantic Richfield Corporation.

Arno Nessen of the Netherlands won the closing day event of the Wieshaden international horse show today in a jumpoff with John Heims, a fellow countryman. Robert Ridland and William Brown, of the United States finished third and fourth respectively.

Five law firms that participated in the settlement of the $85-million estate of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge will share almost half a million dollars in lawyer fees under a ruling issued today by Judge Robert Muir Jr. in Superior Court.

If he had it to do over again, Larry Jones said yesterday he would not have signed his New York Giants pro football contract and taken his bonus money until he had finished his career as an amateur quarter-miler this spring.
Wall Street's recent elusive dream - a reduction in the prime rate by a major bankcame true yesterday and the stock market responded by posting its best advance in almost three months.

The citizens of Sukhumi, a pleasant resort city on the balmy coast of the Black Sea, have found their civic confidence as well as their homes jeopardized by the recent antics of their local fire department.

Mrs. Loel Kaiser Acker, division head of special projects for the Institute of International Education, died yesterday in the New London (Conn.) Convalescent Hospital of pneumonia, following a heart attack four months ago. She was 41

In his first week in office, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has acted to demystify the presidency, set France on a more liberal course and consolidate his power by moving friends into key positions. President Valery Giscard d'Estaing waving as he walked to the Elysee Palace for his inauguration on May 27 in Paris
The northbound entrance ramp of the West Side Highway at 46th Street was closed last evening, shortly after the discovery of a hole in what was described as "badly undermined" pavement.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced a consent order with the Arlen Realty and development Corporation, parent company of the Korvette discount department stoes, preventing Korvette from making any deceptive guarantees of home-improvement products or services.

Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, the ailing senior member of the New York State Congressional delegation, invoked the last hurrah of his 30-year tenure in the House yesterday by disclosing his decision not to seek reelection this year.

Does the Constitution authorize impeachment of a President only for conduct constituting an offense punishable by the criminal law? The press has been full of conflicting answers in briefs and articles by the lawyers for the President, lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee and legal academics.

The Society for the Family of Man Award presented by the Council of Churches of New York City will be awarded Oct. 31 to President William R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia. Katharine Graham and Federal Judge John J. Sirica flanking Dr. Donald F. Hornig, the president of Brown University, at commencement ceremonies in Providence, R.I. Mrs. Graham and Judge Sirica were awarded honorary degrees.

Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., battled through gale-force winds today and moved into the second round of the British Amateur with a 5-and-3 victory over Ireland's Perry Malone. Dick Siderowf in a bunker at Muirfield, Scotland.

Mortgage lending fell nearly 18 percent during April from year-ago levels at New York savings banks, industry figures disclosed yesterday. The Savings Bank Association of New York State reorted that new mortgage loans in April fell to $451-million from $547-million in April of last year. Last month, the association said, savings banks granted $440-million in new mortgages.

The chairman of the American Stock Exchange said today that elimination of uniform commission rates for floor brokerage would leave more than 1,000 maturing public companies without a secondary market for raising and allocating needed capital.

The House approves today, by a vote of 273 to 0 a resolution opposing any consideration. of foreign aid or accommodation with North Vietnam and the Vietcong until they do more to account for Americans missing in action.

" There has to be an end to these intraparty blood-baths," decrees City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Democratic overlord of Queens. To insure strict party regularity free of primary challenges in this year's elections, Mr. Troy has a formula that would seem mild in any Latin-American dictatorship. "We will try to kill anyone who wants to fight the party's designees," he says. "It will be a vendetta to the death ..."

William M. Dougherty, who retired in 1960 as secretary and a director of Uniroyal, Inc., died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 79 years old. Mr. Dougherty was a former director of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries and trustee of the Rubber Manufacturers Association's employes' retirement plan.
Seventy-two Chileans who had spent almost nine months in asylum in the Mexican Embassy in Santiago flew here last night after the Mexican Government had won safeconduct for them.

Amtrak, the nationwide passenger rail system, was given approval by the Department of Transportation yesterday to order more than $110-million worth of new equipment, including six French-built turbotrains.

Two bills one of them requiring that the state's Consumer Protection Board be notified of proposed rate increases and service charges by utilities, and the other permitting the board to intervene in such proceedings before the Public Service Commission, have been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office announced today.

It finally happened over the weekend. The Philadelphia Freedoms lost two in a row after 12 straight W.T.T. victories. Mrs. Billie Jean King, the player-coach lost a set to Francoise Durr of the Denver Racquets.
A Superior Court judge was killed today when a small package delivered to his chambers exploded, two of his colleagues said.

A lawsuit was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday, calling upon the city's Environmental Protection Administration and its administrator, Robert A, Low, to make public an analysis of the effect upon air quality of the proposed West Side convention center.

To the Editor: It is true that nuclear weapons and their proliferation are a threat to mankind, and India's test beneath the Rajasthan desert must be regretted. However, these dangers have existed ever-since their development and use by the United States against Japan.

Only two years a Democrat himself, Representative Ogden R. Reid broke with party leaders yesterday and charged that they were trying to control the Democratic gubernatorial nomination and were more concerned about winning the Democratic primary than the general election.
A Federal judge upheld today President Nixon's claim of executive privilege and quashed a subpoena for documents relating to the conditional clemency granted to James R. Hoffa.

MENLO PARK, Calif.--In January of 1973, the investment advisory firm of Fields, Grant Company here decided to act on its judgment that the stock market was going to fall precipitously in the months ahead. The firm sold all its clients' equity shares and began putting the money into fixed-interest securities, primarily commercial paper.

In the first Nixon Administration, there were several insiders who had ready access to the President and who individually had knowledge of most of his political and legislative tactics. Those insiders included John Mitchell, Attorney General and campaign manager, and H. R. Haldeman, John Ehrlichman and Charles Colson, three senior White House aides. All four are now under criminal indictment.
A new wind of social innovation and aggressive leadership is blowing through the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a union long noted for its harmonious collectivebargaining relationships.

Larry Bowa stole third, then raced home with the lead run on Del Unser's squeeze bunt in an eighthinning surge that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight. Braves' Darrell Evans tagging Phillies' Willie Montanez as Montanez tried for a triple in the fourth inning at Philadelphia. Terry Tata made the call.

The past is casting a long shadow on the contest for the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of New York County. Brooding over the race, which will almost certainly mean election in November for the winner, is the spirit of Frank S. Hogan, who held the post for 32 years until shortly before his death in February. Richard H. Kuh Robert M. Morgenthau
The First National Bank of Chicago announced yesterday that its corporate base rate, which has been at 11.75 per cent, would be lowered to 11.60 per cent, effective today.

The deadline for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Laos passed today with a considerable number of North Vietnamese soldiers reported still in the country. "They have withdrawn into the scenery but not back home," said the Defense Minister, Sisouk na Champassak, yesterday.
Larry Richardson is a likable and often arresting dancer. His company of nine is well-trained and equally agreeable.

For two years now, the city has been eager to unload $840,000 worth of concrete support columns bought when the Board of Higher Education was planning a new 13-acre campus for the Bronx Community College.
Simon Ottinger, who with his late cousin, Lawrence Ottinger, began the United States Plywood Corporation in 1937, died Sunday at his home, 912 Fifth Avenue. He was 89 years old.
Saudi Arabia called today for a limited but high-level meeting of major oil-producing and oilconsuming countries for a 'practical dialogue" on energy, raw materials and technology.

Staffs of Senate-House conferees have drafted what is expected to be the final version of legislation to overhaul drastically the way Congress considers the Federal budget and decides where the money is to be spent.
The seven harness drivers acquitted last Saturday of fixing races got temporary licenses yesterday from the State Racing and Wagering Board.

The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission said today that television advertising of premiums to children violated Federal law and that television advertising aimed at selling dangerous drugs and toys to children was not properly regulated.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the Nixon Administration and the American Medical Association brought their three-way battle over national health insurance before the National Governors' Conference today.

Alvin Ailey has a sense of history and a sense of humor. It makes him an unusual artistic director and his company's dance's both thought-provoking and entertaining. The company closed an exuberant spring season Sunday evening at the City Center 55th Street Theater with three historical revivals and two pieces from repertory.

FILMS Parly because the United States is rich enough and technologically and visually oriented, more and more persons have acquired skills and equipment and gone out to make films-we used to call them documentaries-about life as it is today and, with imagination and creativity, to show life in the past.
A Staten Island police sergeant has been acquitted of a perjury charge brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor.
City and state politicians seem to be competing in irresponsibility in the political manipulation of New York City rent control.

The Rev. John J. McLaughlin, the Jesuit who is a deputy special assistant to President Nixon, said today that the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings "produced little but noise and a few selected leaks."
The state's Power Authority retained independent outside experts yesterday to help determine the value of two Consolidated Edison plants it may buy under a new state law.

Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington attacked today low-interest loans being made by the Government's ExportImport Bank to the Soviet Union and to Iran and said he was drafting legislation that would give Congress a veto over the bank's transactions. Senator Henry M. Jackson

Dr. Daniel C. Baker Jr., a specialist in diseases of the larynx and president-elect of the American Laryngological Association, died Sunday of a heart ailment at his home, 232 County Road, Demarest, N. J. He was 65 years old. Dr. Daniel C. Baker Jr.

This is clearly the year for Hasidic dance in American classic ballet. A couple of weeks ago we had Jerome Robbins's "Dybbuk" for the New York City Ballet, and then, on Sunday night, the Eliot Feld Ballet gave the world premiere of "Tzaddik" at the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare's Public Theater complex on Lafayette Place.

The National Citizens' Committee for Fairness to the Presidency is holding a "citizens' Congress" in support of President Nixon next Sunday, but most of the invited "honored guests," including Vice President Ford, are not coming.
The Democratic executive committee of Queens last night redesignated all Democratic incumbents from the borough except Councilman Arthur J. Katzman.
The Supreme Court upheld today for the first time the 10-yearold Congressional mandate that employers pay women equal wages for equal work.

Charles W. Colson, formerly one of President Nixon's closest aides, pleaded guilty today to a charge that he attempted to obstruct justice and influence the trial of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. Charles W. The Soviet Union and Japan signed a long-term agreement today providing for $450-million of Japanese credits to be sued to finance development of coal in the South Yakutia basin of eastern Siberia.

Archbishop Molloy High School successfully completed defense of its Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball championship yesterday by overpowering Monsignor McClancy, 12-1, in the final game at St. John's University.

The Oakland A's, winners of the World Series the last two years and currently carrying the best record in the American League, are 134,624 behind last year in home attendance. Even San Diego and Texas, baseball's two weakest situations the last two years, are drawing more than the A's with their star-studded roster. Charles O. Finley

A Federal regulation limiting the amount of fat in prodcuts eligible to carry the name "beef sausage" will be put into effect July 29, three and a half years after it was originally announced, the Agriculture Department said today.

The deadline for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Laos passed today with a considerable number of North Vietnamese soldiers reported still in the country. Under the cease-fire agreement signed on Feb. 21 "foreign military personnel" were obliged to leave the country "within a period of no longer than 60 days" after the formation of a coalition government. The coalition has been in office since April 4. [1:1.]
Hampshire College, founded four years ago as a center of educational innovation in Amherst, Mass., has been granted full accreditation by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges.

Mrs. Sarah Lowell Gifford Smith, former owner of. Hunting-Smith, a silver-chest manufacturing concern of Westfield, N. J., founded by her late husband, Edward Hunting Smith, died Friday at the Medicenter in Red Bank, N. J. She was 71 years old and lived at 657 Hillside Avenue, Westfield.

The Japanese Parliament closed its session quietly today and members headed for their home districts for what is expected to be a lively political campaign ending in a critical election July 7.

Capt. Robert A. Winston, a Navy flier in World War II who wrote several books, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 66 years old and lived on Long Ridge Road in Bedford, N. Y.

Three speakers were scheduled for the opening of the general session of the American Advertising Federation meeting here this morning. But there were only two. No. 3, Senator Lowell P. Weicker, showed up, but left.

The Justice Department said today that officials of the Consolidation Coal Company, the nation's second largest coal producer, were under criminal investigation for possible fraud in falsifying coal dust data de signed to protect miners from pneumoconiosis, an occupational disease often called black lung.

Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, testifying yesterday at his trial in the murder of 10year-old Clifford Glover, said that he had fired at the fleeing victim's back as the boy "made a reaching motion" and then raised his hand "and I saw what I believed to be a revolver"

The year's biggest flurry of primary elections involves eight states today with voters choosing nominees to succeed retiring Governors in California and New Mexico and a United States Senator in lowa.

Clifford H. Keep, a lawyer and retired attache of Kings County Court, died Saturday at his home in Jamaica, Queens. His age was 91. Mr. Keep was a graduate of Amherst College and the New York University Law School.
Donald E. Santarelli has submitted his registration as the head of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, Justice Department sources said today.

A 27-year old Woodbridge woman who helped extinguish a fire on a couch in her apartment died in a predawn blaze yesterday that apparently began again later in the couch. The police identified her as Mary Anne Minkewicz, who shared the first-floor apartment at 270 Smith Street with a friend, Susan Conti. Miss Conti had left the apartment after the first fire, which began at about 2 A.M., the police said.
The British Government said today it would not withdraw its army from Northern Ireland, warning retreat would bring "a large-scale bloodbath" between Protestants and Roman Catholics in the province.

The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday, that its international division had agreed to supply tire technology and engineering for a large tire plant in Turkey. Neither the value of the deal nor the site of the project were disclosed. The Air Force has awarded a $13.5-million contract for target drones to the Sperry RandCorporation's Sperry Flight Systems.

The second season of New York Philharmonic Rug Concerts opens next Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, with Pierre Boulez conducing a Brahms-Debussy-Bartok program. As before, seats will be removed from the hall's orchestra level and the floor will be covered with rugs on which part of the audience will sit.

Richard J. Davis has his work cut out for him if he is to live up to the advance billing and pledge of the special I Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski. Last week, Mr. Jaworski named Mr. Davis the a new head of the force investigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporaction case.

Sol Berg missed it. The rotund owner of the New York Sets, who is their most avid fan, passed up a Sets match for the first time this season and missed seeing his sorry group of tennis players blossom into a hard-hitting team. The Sets gave the Detroit Loves and fire Rosemary Casals a run for their money tonight before a crowd of 2,017 persons at Nassau Coliseum.

After more than a year of uncertainty, the Nixon Administration has granted approval for converting the controversial Forest Hills low-income housing' project to a cooperative, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

President Nixon will arrive in Egypt on June 12 and visit Alexandria and Cairo for two days of talks with President Anwar el-Sadat and for some sightseeing, informed sources said here today. An official announcement of the visit is expected to be made public in Washington and Cairo tomorrow.
The Chase Investors Management Corporation disclosed yesterday that in the year and a half since it has been in business, assets under management have declined about $2.7-billion.

The special Federal grand jury that investigated Spiro T. Agnew and his successor as Baltimore County Executive handed up two final indictments and one "criminal information" today, the final day in its 19-month term.

Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, the ailing senior member of the New York State Congressional delegation, invoked the last hurrah of his 30-year tenure in the House yesterday by disclosing his decision not to seek reelection this year.

Cambodia's Education Minister and his top assistant were killed today when Government troops stormed a high school where students were holding them hostage in a protest demanding educational reforms. Cambodian students holding Education Minister Keo Sangkim, rear, hostage at a high school in Phnom Penh. The minister and his chief assistant were killed when Government troops stormed the school.

Prime Minister Wilson ruled out a British troop withdrawal from Northern Ireland today as an emergency debate in the House of Commons ended without evidence of progress toward a resolution of the political crisis there.

In a politely worded but politically pointed letter, Mayor Beame challenged yesterday what he called "errors and deficiencies" in Controller Harrison J. Goldin's criticism of his proposed municipal budget.

" It's been tough," said BarryAshbee, an all-star defenseman for the Philadelphia Flyers in announcing his retirement yesterday following injury to his right eye from a puck shot by the New York Rangers' Dale Rolfe last April 28, in a Stanley Cup semifinal hockey playoff game. Barry Ashbee announcing his retirement. At the left is Ed Snider, the Flyers' owner.

Two leading New York banks have quietly raised their lending rates on personal loans. The move does not apply to automobile loans so far, but will affect a wide variety of other general-purpose borrowings, including loans for medical expenses, vacation trips and the consolidation of debts, as well as for any other worthwhile purpose.

President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Donald E. Santarelli, who said he was quitting as head of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration because of "misleading reports" about his comments on the President.
Miss Aviva Wininger, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Harold Wininger, was married last evening to Jacob Wasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wasser. Both families are of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, the former director of the state Office of Consumer Protection and a former Republican Assemblyman from Somerset County, apparently won an extremely narrow victory yesterday in the Republican Congressional election in New Jersey's Fifth District.

California's experiment in regulation of land use is entering its critical second phase. For more than a year the state's Coastal Zone Conservation Commission has been winnowing proposals for virtually all new development within 1,000 yards of the ocean.

At least 16 members of the House Judiciary Committee accepted political donations ranging from $100 to $11,000 from the same three dairy farmer cooperatives the panel is investigating as part of its impeachment inquiry.

The dollar dropped slightly on larger European money markets today and gold prices also showed small losses. In London, the dollar closed at $2.4009, compared with the opening rate of $2.3995 to the pound. One dealer described the market as being "as steady as a rock" and the lack of business caused an over-all spread of three points on the pound against the dollar.

Voting officials at Hackensack Fire Department headquarters building on State Street waiting for voters. Polling place had only 17 voters from 7 A.M. until noon, and turnout statewide was extremely light.

The nation's railroads were told yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission that they could increase freight rates by as much as 10 per cent in a move that would cost shippers an additional $1.25billion in rail charges over the next 12 months.

A joint American-Soviet program to study the government of large cities this summer was announced yesterday by Columbia University. The effort, said to be the first systematic attempt to exchange data between the two nations on municipal management and urban services, is being supported by Columbia by an initial grant of $128,000 from the National Science Foundation.

Is Christian theology responsible for anti-Semitism, for the Holocaust and its six million Jewish victims? Plainly yes, argued Prof. Rosemary R. Ruether of Howard University. A Jesuit priest from Woodstock College, the Rev. Walter Burghardt disagreed.

Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations today inspected observation posts along the Golan Heights front where United Nations troops will oversee the disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces.
The hopes of investors that interest rates may finally have peaked helped the stock market post its second consecutive broad advance yesterday in the heaviest trading in almost three months.

A 1967 West Point graduate who broke his neck six weeks after receiving his second-lieutenant's commission and a 21-year-old who turned pro just six months ago led the field today as 77 golfers sought the 11 precious United States Open berths available in the final Northeast sectional qualifying round.
Flat, S.p.A., the giant Italian auto maker, announced today an average 13 per cent rise in the price of its models.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. - The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions cherishes many ideals, including one that may be indispensable: Robert M. Hutchins. Fifteen years after he founded the center and became its leader, he ceded his office last Saturday to Malcolm C. Moos, for the last seven years president of the University of Minnesota. Dr. Hutchins, Dr. Malcolm C. Moos, new head of center Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, center's founder

The New York Mets and Cincinnati Reds minded their manners again last night, but the Reds were rude enough to score three runs in the 10th inning for their fifth straight victory of the year over the defending National League champions. Mets Jerry Grote nabbing Reds' Pete Rose at the plate as Rose tried to score from first base on a hit by Joe Morgan to left field in the third inning.

Britain presented in detail today her demands for better membership terms in the European Common Market but did so in tones suggesting that she really wanted to stay in. James Callaghan, left, British Foreign Secretary, and Jean Sauvagnargues, his French counterpart, arriving at Common Market headquarters in Luxembourg.

Richard M. Rosenbaum, the State Republican chairman, said yesterday that his party would endorse Associate Judges Harold A. Stevens and Samuel Rabin for full terms on the Court of Appeals and that if the Democrats did not, it would be a major campaign issue.

The nature of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings is changing this week. During eight days of closed hearings last month on the Watergate burglary and its aftermath, much of the evidence presented to committee members was contradictory.

The Labor Department opened hearings yesterday on how to apply new minimum wage and overtime legislation to policemen and firemen, taking testimony from Gerald M. Feder of the International Association of Fire Fighters.

The way it was, is still much the way it is, but neighbors change and people leave, and only the feeling of the place goes on forever. Bay Ridge in Brooklyn is still the home of the middle class and the people who fight to get into it.

More than 2,500 of the states' judges will be required to make intermittent visits to jails, prisons, drugaddiction centers and training schools as a result of a rule adopted yesterday by the Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference.

Prices rose again in steppedup trading on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market yesterday as more traders became convinced that the round of increases in the prime rate was coming to a halt.

Charles W. Colson today is a surprise witness for the prosecution in the Watergate affair, but his exact value in that role is a matter of dispute. Associates of the tough-talking former special counsel to President Nixon say privately, "The notion that he is going to pull the President down from his perch is not there."

The Navy notified Congress today that it planned to provide the Grumman Aerospace Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., with up to $100-million in advance payments to assure continued production of the F-14 fighter aircraft.

Maria Winley went back to school last fall because it was getting lonely with only eight of her children still around the house. Last night all 16 Winley children were at Hunter College to see their mother receive her elementary school certificate.

Negotiations aimed at settling the nationwide strike in men's and boys' clothing industry are scheduled to resume tomorrow in the offices. of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington.
Gen. Antonio de Spinola, provisional President of the new Portuguese Government, will visit Mozambique and Angola shortly, it was announced here to day.

American officials said today that they did not expect a major new Soviet grain purchase from the United States this summer, despite reports of difficulties with the Soviet crop.

Seeking wider international recognition, the American textile industry yesterday opened the first American Fashion Textiles Exposition, Texpo '74, at the New York Coliseum--amid fiber shortages, rising prices and growing financial pressures. Buyers from Wolf Z. Schnitzler Sons, Ltd., of Israel, examining one of the styles at the Dan River display at Texpo '74 exhibition at the Coliseum.

E. F. Hutton Co., one of the nation's biggest brokers, and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood, Inc., of Minneapolis, a major regional broker, said yesterday they would raise commissions by about 5 per cent on securities transactions of up to $300,000 in value.
Vice President Ford heaped lavish praise on Secretary of State Kissinger in a talk dealing mainly with foreign trade before an apparel-industry group here yesterday.

Worden, the command module pilot for the 1971 Appollo 15 moon, mission, began to read softly from his new book of poems, the publishers in the Shoreham Hotel suite around him kept up their cocktail chatter. The Rev. Patrick G. Miller, a leader in the Presbyterian Church of the U. S., died last night. He was 74 years' old. Mr. Miller was moderator of the 1968 General Assembly of the denomination and was credited with being the principal architect of the church's national mission program during the ninteen-fifties and sixties. Cambodian students holding Education Minister Keo Sangkim, rear, hostage at a high school in Phnom Penh. The minister and his chief assistant were killed when Government troops stormed the school.
The House Judiciary Committee has quietly intensified its inquiry into 17 so-called "national security" wiretaps authorized by President Nixon beginning in 1969, court records showed today.

About 100 visitors sat at little tables on the clubHouse terrace at Belmont Park yesterday, some eating pancakes, some watching the morning works, some just soaking up sunshine. There were pillars of the turf in perambulators and strollers and slightly larger handicapders riding iron horses set on stanchions in a patch of tawn. A three-judge Federal appeals court panel handed down today an opinion that apparently will allow the Reserve Mining Company to continue to pollute Lake Superior from its Silver Bay, Minn., plant for up to five years.

Houston I. Flournoy, a former college professor, was nominated by the Republicans today for Governor of California. Edmund G. Brown Jr., son of the former Governor, was leading on the Democratic slate. Houston I. Flournoy addressing supporters after winning G.O.P. primary.

This tiny South Jersey community was virtually without a local government after the Mayor and four of six Council members resigned yesterday in a demand for more state funds to solve its sewage problems.

The juror responsible for the mistrial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. and two Republican fund raisers will not be prosecuted for alleged deliberate attempts to mislead the court during jury selection, the Attorney General's office said today.

A Federal appeals court enjoined the Prentice-Hall publishing company from selling "Child Psychology," a textbook that is the target of plagiarism charges by the authors of a competing Harper Row book, "Child Development and Personality."

Tonight's new TV material, a scarce commodity at the height of the rerun season, includes a new series called "Bobbie Gentry's Happiness Hour" on CBS-TV at 8 and "Nourish the Beast," a play by Steve Tesich, on public television's Hollywood Television Theater at 8:30. Neither should seriously challenge the supremacy of the repeats.

A total of $300-million in two new corporate offerings were about sold out yesterday as bond market participants threaded their way through another large one-day calendar. The tax-exempt sector was also involved in' the round of new obligations that were marketed via competitive bidding and for the most part specialists felt it, too, gave a good account of itself.

The Food and Drug Administration ordered the $117-million-a-year antacid industry today to stop making exaggerated claims for its products and to limit them to a small set of safe and proven ingredients.
A move was begun in the Senate today to force a debate over whether the United States should develop larger, more accurate intercontinental missiles capable of striking at Soviet missile silos.

President Nixon's mission to Moscow at the end of June has raised two new controversies in Washington: first, whether his new approach to the targeting and control of nuclear weapons is sound; and second, whether he should go to Moscow on such an important mission in his present weakened political position at home.
The National Football League awarded a franchise to Seattle yesterday, bringing the total number of its teams to 28. The new teams in Tampa and Seattle will begin play in the 1976 season.

Henry Fonda's widely praised performance in "Clarence Darrow," a one-man stage play by David W. Rintels, will be presnted on television this summer as a 90-minute prime time special. NBC-TV has scheduled the show for Sept. 4 with the International Business Machines Corporation as sponsor.

The 22d Stratford Festival openedd at the Festival Theater last night and will run for 23 weeks through Oct. 26. This is the sixth and last season that Jean Gascon has been artistic director and. appropriately enough, the season opened with his own staging of Moliere's "The Imaginary Invaild."
A bill requiring the posting of foot-square gasoline price signs with numerals large enough to be read by a passing motorist was adopted yesterday by the City Council by a vote of 39 to 0.

Petroleos Mexicanos, the petroleum and petrochemical agency of the Mexican Government, has awarded contracts valued at "about $90-million" to the M. W. Kellogg Company, a division of Pullman, Inc. The contracts call for design and construction of three large-scale ammonia plants valued at about $125-million. A Mexican contractor was awarded the balance of the contract.

The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, announced today the revocation of the most crucial terms of coal leases granted by his department for strip mining on the Northerp Cheyenne Indian reservation in eastern Montana.
Government troops recaptured An Dien village, 24 miles north of Saigon, early today after a five-day battle. military sources said.

Mayor Beame and David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, pitched in yesterday morning at the city's first underground voter registration. The subterranean voter registry, in the IRT subway station concourse at Grand Central Terminal, was sponsored by New York Votes, a coalition of 56 major organizations formed to encourage registration among the city's two million unregistered voters. The man who gave the world Mars candy bars has given the 195th English Derby its favorite. Forest E. Mars, a Virginian, brought the late sire, Neararctic, to an untried dam named Seximee.

At least 10,000 - perhaps as many as 20,000 people - in the Indian state of Bihar have died this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the disease in recent years. More than 30,000 smallpox cases were reported in the last five weeks from virtually every vil. lage in Bihar, an official of the World Health Organization said in Geneva. [1:6-7.]

A court-appointed panel of technical experts has concluded that "the only completely plausible explanation" for the 18 1/2-minute gap in a crucial White House tape recording is that the gap was caused by "pushing" the keys of a "normally operated" tape recorder at least five times.
Japan and China have signed a contract in Peking for constructing a large steel plant in China. Shipments will begin a year from now and trial runs will begin in January, 1977.
