Two university economists said yesterday that the Government's Wholesale Price Index "grossly overstates" the extent of inflation affecting the United States.
A Manhattan furrier was fined $3,000 yesterday in United States District court on conviction of having made three $150 payments in 1969 to union officials for special treatment.
The White House today announced President Nixon's itinerary for his visit to the Middle East next week, saying that he would seek to "consolidate what has been achieved on the road to peace."

Although Arab oil-producing states have decided to maintain their embargo against the Netherlands and Denmark, officials attending a meeting of the European Common Market here see a good sign in the fact that Algeria sought to end the boycott.

The Federal Trade Commission accused E. J. Korvette yesterday of deceptive claims regarding the price, quality and guarantees of its home-improvement services and prohibited the national chain from engaging in termite control or waterproofing services without its approval.

The Right Rev. J Brooke Mosley, under pressure reflected by the board of directors of Union Theological Seminary, announced yesterday his decision to resign from the presidency of the prestigious 138-year-old Protestant school. Bishop J. Brooke Mosley

Attorney General William F. Hyland today called New Jersey's narcotics laws "unrealistic" because they did not set stiffer penalties for bigtime drug pushers than for street dealers. William F. Hyland

Oscar Alvarado of Houston knocked out Koichi Wajima of Japan in the 15th round tonight to capture the World Boxing Association junior middleweight boxing title. The knockout came at 1 minute 57 seconds of the last round as Alvarado floored Wajima for the third time in the round.

The judgment to be handed down shortly in a Sudanese court extends far beyond the fate of eight confessed murderers brought to trial-the Palestinian fanatics who kidnapped and killed three diplomats, a Belgian and two Americans, in March of last year.

In a politely worded but politically pointed letter, Mayor Beame challenged yesterday what he called "errors and deficiencies" in Controller Harrison J. Goldin's criticism of his proposed municipal budget.

There was a pause in the Rothko estate trial in Surrogate's Court yesterday, but legal fees continued to pile up toward an ultimate total large enough to buy several Rothko paintings-even at their highest prices.

After meeting for more than three hours yesterday with Leonid I. Brezhney, the Soviet Communist party leader, W. Averell Harriman, the retired diplomat, said that he told Mr. Brezhnev he could count on a stable United States Government over the next two years even if President Nixon were impeached. Leonid I. Brezhnev, left, welcoming W. Averell Harriman yesterday at the Kremlin

Because of the Consolidated Edison Company's growing financial difficulties, the Atomic Energy Commission has begun an investigation into whether the utility has enough funds to continue operating its nuclear plants safely.

Secretary of State Kissinger told a Congressional committee today that foreign aid was vital to peace in the Middle East and Indochina and was needed to prevent a split between the developed and developing nations.

The agricultural ministers of the nine members of the Common Market agreed here today on measures to allow Italy to lift recently imposed restrictions on imports of farm products from other countries in the bloc.
IN THE DEEPEST PART OF SLEEP, a play be Charles Fuller. Directed by Israel Hicks; settings and costumes by Mary Mease Warren; lighting by Susan Chapman; production stage manager, Harrison Avery.

Syria expects improved relations with the United States to lead to the resumption of diplomatic relations and to economic aid, sources close to the Government said today. Syrian officials and Western diplomats said relations were improving almost daily and were expected to improve even more in the next few weeks.

The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to ease the way for transfer of assets between United States companies and their overseas affiliates by cutting down on some of the red tape. The, proposal was put in the major tax reform bill the body is now considering.
The United Fund of Greater New York, the fund-raising organization for 425 socialservice agencies, announced the election of a new chairman yesterday.

Francis J. Souhan, a textile manufacturer and former Assemblyman, died last night at his home. He was 66 years old. Mr. Souhan was an Assemblyman from 1959 to 1961. Active in Democratic politics, he had been Mayor of this village. He was president of the Seneca Knitting Mills and the Geb Souhan Yarn Company.

PARIS-It is hard to realize that thirty years have already gone by since history's largest armada landed an Allied army in Normandy, breaching the defenses of Hitler's Fortress Europe and launching what General Eisenhower called "the great crusade toward which we have striven these many months."

The Kennecott Copper Company and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company joined several other producers yesterday in raising their prices for full-plate electronic copper cathodes produced and sold in the United States by 5 cents a pound to 85 cents, effective immediately.

Public records show that since the new Election Reporting Law went into effect in April, 1972, the milk cooperatives have contributed a total of $32,000 in campaign funds to nine Democrats and seven Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee, the same committee that is considering allegations that President Nixon raised Federal milk-price supports in exchange for contributions from these same cooperatives.

The House Judiciary Committee heard today two White House tape recordings that apparently rebutted charges that President Nixon was aware of a plan by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to contribute to his 1972 re-election campaign when he intervened in an antitrust case against the conglomerate in 1971.
Security officials said today that two armed infiltrators from Lebanon had been intercepted and arrested but three others had apparently escaped back across the border.

From the ornate five-story town house at 35 East 68th Street, 19 youths-classified as "potential drug abusers"moved out mattresses yesterday to be trucked to a dingy loft building at 150 Spring Street. Members of Encounter, Inc., moving mattresses from 35 East 68th Street. A truck then carried the bedding to a loft building at 150 Spring Street In the West Village, the site of a planned campout.

Eugene J. Santoli, former Mayor of the Borough of Woodcliff Lake, pleaded guilty to charges of having filed false income-tax returns from 1969 and 1971. Mr. Santoli, 47 years old, and a Democrat, was Mayor of the Bergen County suburb from 1966 to 1977. He admitted he filed income-tax returns for 1969 and 1971 totaling $52,060 when his Income was substantially higher.

Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today that the United States economy would have to be run at less than full capacity for a "considerable period of time" in order to "squeeze inflation out of the system."

Knocked out of action by a seven-day suspension, Angel Cordero Jr. appears ready to seek a court injunction that could enable him to ride Cannonade in Saturday's 106th Belmont Stakes. Angel Cordero Jr.
Eleven men described as members of a large two-state drug ring pleaded guilty to narcotics charges in Federal District Court today. The case had been scheduled to go to trial tomorrow.

American new-car sales were down an estimated 23 per cent last month to 880,147 from 1,142,304 in May, 1973. But auto makers reported today some signs of improvement in the sales picture, including a resurgence in luxury-car sales and increasing demand for trucks.
The last time the Yankees saw Wilbur Wood they beat him in both games of a doubleheader. The last time they saw Dick Allen they limited him to two singles in 10 times at bat.

DeWitt Weaver, a 34-yearold pro whose biggest victory was in 1971 at the United States match-play championship, coasted to a seven - under - par 137 yesterday to lead six golfers qualifying for the United States open at Canongate Golf Course near Atlanta.

A three-judge Federal appeals court panel handed down today an opinion that apparently will allow the Reserve Mining Company to continue to pollute Lake Superior from its Silver Bay, Minn., plant for up to five years.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's bankers are expected to reduce their interest rate temporarily on Lockheed loanfrom the current 12 per cent maximum to 4 per cent as part of a proposed deal with Textron, Inc., for the financial overhaul of the troubled aerospace manufacturer.

Two large utilities in Michigan and Arizona announced retrenchments yesterday because of declining activity and rising costs. One of them included the first layoffs that are known to have occurred during the current squeeze on the utilities industry.

A court-appointed panel of technical experts has concluded that "the only completely plausible explanation" for the 181/2-minute gap in a crucial White House tape recording is that the gap was caused by "pushing" the keys of a "normally operated" tape recorder at least five times.
Three armed men broke into the estate of a prominent English racehorse owner and former member of the British Parliament early today and kidnapped him and his wife.

There will be those who ask what purpose can be served by conjuring up the demons of the Nazi death camps. Why inflict those unspeakable horrors once again on the human mind? Why let these visions of death fall particularly across the consciousness of those too young to recall that these terrible shadows were cast by actual events?
Lieut. Gov. Jere Beasley, fighting an uphill battle for a second term, won renomination today by defeating Charles Woods, a millionaire industrialist, in the Democratic primary.

The longest reign in the history of sports celebrity tennis - Hank Greenberg's three straight championship years-ended today as Rick Barry and Kyle Rote Jr. defeated Greenberg and Bob Klein in doubles in the final match of a two-day frolic at the Riviera Hotel. Walt Frazier of the Knicks returning a serve on the first day of the tournament.

The Borough Presidents and Mayor Beame have acquitted themselves well in the selection of the new Board of Education. The retention of a strong nucleus of members who, while serving on the interim board, have been responsible for the difficult transition to school decentralization will help further to stabilize the system.

Futures prices of three basic metals--silver, platinum and copper--rallied yesterday, recovering virtually all of their losses on Monday. The rise came on a day when the price for gold in London moved downward:

Victor Manuel Bustamante was banned from the President Remon race track today by the National Racing Commission for shooting his horse in the nose during a fit of anger Sunday when it failed to win the 10th race.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., the widely diversified industrial company, announced yesterday it would make tender offers of $12 a share for Brown Company common stock and $6.75 a share for Madison Square Garden common stock.

The Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, said yesterday that he was investigating conflicting stories about the chief Federal prosecutor's mysterious illness during the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D Roncallo.
China has a new air force commander, succeeding Wu Fahsien, who disappeared at the time of the abortive coup apparently planned by Defense Minister Lin Piao in September, 1971.

George Goldberg, a retired wholesale - meat distributor, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Park Way General Hospital, North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.
A second field of 470 contestants from 32 states turned out for the United States Seniors' Golf Association's annual two-day tournament today.

In the coffee-growing highlands northwest of the capital, Luanda, where the concentration of guerrilla fighters is heavier than anywhere else in Angola, uncertainty of purpose and boredom weigh down Portuguese soldiers more than acts of war. Portuguese soldiers on patrol in Angola. The security of the Half-million Portuguese living in the country, whose population is 5.7 million, is the army's responsibility.

Representative Ogden R. Reid yesterday raised the possibility for the first time that he might drop out of the Democratic race for Governor after the Democratic State Committee designates a candidate next week.

At least 10,000-and perhaps as many as 20,000-people in the northeastern Indian state of Bihar have died so far this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the viral disease in recent years.

Frederic A. Davidson, retired president of Refined Syrups and Sugars, Inc., and former president of the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Board of Education, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 9 Keogh Lane in New Rochelle.

For old-timers in the industry, the strike of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America awakes memories of 50 years ago when the infant union was struggling for recognition and strikes were a nearly everyday occurrence.

Harold Miller is no devotee of chicken necks. In fact, he feeds them to the family dog. Which may explain Mr. Miller's chagrin when, home from the supermarket with 10 sale-priced fryers, he found the bags contained 15 necks. Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, accused Nixon Administration officials today of undermining the revenue-sharing program by failing to enforce strongly its regulations.

WASHINGTON-The signing of the Paris peace agreement in January, 1973, marked the official termination of direct American combat involvement in Vietnam. Since then, the United States Government has committed approximately $2.3 billion in economic and military assistance to Vietnam.

Senator Mike Mansfield's renewed effort to force substantial withdrawal of American troops from Europe and other areas overseas is the wrong battle in the wrong place at the wrong time. The Senate floor is the wrong place for this decision to be taken because the issue is now under negotiation in Vienna between the NATO and Warsaw Pact powers in an effort to bring about Soviet as well as American troop cutbacks.

A 1967 West Point graduate who broke his neck six weeks after receiving his second-lieutenant's commission and a 21-year-old who turned pro just six months ago led the field today as 77 golfers sought the 11 precious United States Open berths available in the final Northeast sectional qualifying round.
Basil Woon, whose career as a journalist spanned more than 60 years, died today in a Reno hospital. He was 80 years old.
One of the nation's leading scientific societies has initiated what it believes to be a novel providing key members of Congress with top-quality, nonpartisan scientific advice.

The chairman of the central bank of the world's leading capitalist economy and the Premier of the world's leading Communist economy sat down in the Kremlin last month for three hours of conversation over tea Dr. Arthur F. Burns, head of the Federal Reserve Board, held talks in the Kremlin on recent trip. George Garvy, adviser to the head of New York Reserve Bank and Soviet expert, was with Dr. Burns.

Comdr. Gabriel Scott Findlay, U. S. N. retired, who had been a teacher of engineering and an administrative officer in merchant marine schools, died in the Veterans Administration Hospital here Monday. He was 82 years old and lived at 23 Lexington Avenue.

Following are the results of yesterday's school elections in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties. The tax rates in Nassau and Suffolk are for every $100 of assessed valuation and in Westchester for every $1,000 of assessed valuation.

Lefkowitz, the only Attorney General millions of New Yorkers have ever known, is expected to say today that after 18 years in the job he wants another four-year term as the state's chief law officer. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz greeting residents of a housing project for the aged in Long Island City in April. The occasion was the opening of a consumer information center sponsored by his office.

WARSAW--Somehow, Poland must build more than seven million apartments. Under high-priority planning, if all goes well, the job can be done by 1991. Huge government investments have been poured into the program, and as a stopgap, Swedish contractors have been brought in to help with some hotel construction.
The House Judiciary Committee has quietly intensified its inquiry into 17 so-called "national security" wiretaps authorized by President Nixon beginning in 1969, court records showed today.

The nation's top two auto makers are seeking another delay in making air bags mandatory safety equipment on 1977-model cars. In briefs filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety administration yesterday, General Motors and Ford asked that customers be allowed to choose between air bags and safety belts, G.M. estimated that motorists would have to pay $2.6-billion additional a year if air bags became standard.

Howard H. Fogel, a freelance writer for trade magazines and former editor of the Hearing Aid Journal, died of cancer yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 60 West 13th Street.
The head of the National Science Foundation predicted here yesterday that solar heating and cooling systems would be commercially available in five years.

President Nixon has abolished the list of subversive organizations maintained by the Attorney General that was used to screen applicants for Government jobs, the White House and Justice Departments announced today.
Mrds. Ralph Petrone of Blacksburg, Va., shot a 77, five ovedr par, to take the first-round lead today in the 63d annual women's Eastern Golf Association championship.

One afternoon in January, 1973, a Brooklyn mother and her two shall children were trapped in "an oven-like atmosphere" as fire raged through the apartment below them, their only escape "a leap to almost certain death at the base of an interior courtyard."

The other day there was an ad in the paper for Studs Terkel's new book, "Working." One excerpt from this compilation of people's feelings about their labors was from "The Executive": "My day starts between 4:30 and 5 in the morning.... I will probably have as many as 150 letters dictated by 7:30 in the morning. I have five full-time secretaries...." And more of the same.
Henry Aaron hit his 16th career grand-slam homer last night in Veterans Stadium to add to his record as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-3.

The Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, said yesterday that he was investigating conflicting stories about' the chief Federal prosecutor's mysterious illness during the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo.
Robert D. Root, director of press relations for the American Medical Association, died yesterday after a long illness. He wag 47 years old.

Bill Feldhaus, a former National Football League all-pro lineman, died Sunday in a nursing home here, He was 61 years old. Mr. Feldhaus, who played for the Detroit Lions, was named N.F.L. rookie of the year in 1937.

Mrs. Edith Friedman Barenholtz, a pioneer in educational equipment for preschool children and a founder of Creative Playthings, died on Thursday in Princeton, N. J. She was 60 years old and lived there.

At least 10,000-and perhaps as many as 20,000-people in the northeastern Indian state of Bihar have died so far this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the viral disease in recent years.

The defender, DICK Siderowf of Westport, Conn., was upset in the second round of the British Amateur golf championship today, but James Gabrielson, a Walker Cup player from Atlanta, lifted America's fortunes with a victory.

Hundreds of spectators charged onto the field in the ninth inning of the game between the Texas Rangers and the Cleveland Indians tonight and staged a wild brawl, leading the umpires to order the game forfeited to the Rangers, 9-0.
A record field of 470 contestants from 32 states turned out for the United States Seniors' Golf Association's annual two-day tournament today.
President Anwar el-Sadat crossed the Suez Canal today and visited Egyptian Third Army troops in Sinai for the first time since before the October war.
The jump in world oil prices enabled the Soviet Union last year to reap nearly a billion dollars more in oil revenue than a year-earlier, with only a modest increase in exports.

A measure that would delete statutory requirements calling for about $600-million from the 1967 Transportation Bond Issue to be used for specific subway projects in New York City has been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office reported today.
The United States Embassy today expressed frustration and disappointment at the refusal of the Vietcong and the North Vietnamese to attend discussions on the search for men missing in action.
Baseball will conduct its summer free agent draft beginning today and the San Diego Padres, leading off the lottery, are expected to choose Bill Almon of Brown University, a shortstop.

Even taking into consideration the "independence" of marriage partners, the Acting State Commissioner of Education ruled today that a married woman should not be a member of a local board of education if her husband is a paid employee of the board.

California voters in both parties generally gave the edge to the more progressive contenders in Tuesday's primary election and came down very decidedly in favor of stringent political reform. The companies that own New York magazine and The Village Voice announced their merger yesterday, but each publication will keep its independent identity, staff and facilities. The merger is a corporate one, not an actual merger of the two publications.

Mrs. Sara Ferris Fowler, who had taught at the Rippowan School in Bedford, N.Y., for 43 years, died Monday in Mount Dora, Fla. She was 68 years old, the wife of Walter G. Fowler, retired head of the Fowler Engineering Corporation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and lived in Cross River, N.Y., and Mount Dora.

The Senate voted today, 82 to 0, to force the Navy to abandon its gunnery range on the island of Culebra off Puerto Rico by the end of 1975.

A sharp rise in the price of gold in London and elsewhere attracted buy orders from speculators in silver, platinum and copper futures in New York yesterday.

G. Thomas LoRe, retired supervising referee of the State Unemployment Insurance Board and a former Brooklyn Assemblyman, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten island. He was 66 years old and lived at 1100 Clove Road in the Sunny Side section of Staten Island.
Stanley H. Stroffolino, a former State Senator and State Representative from Norwalk, died this morning at Norwalk Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 272 Flax Hill Road.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.-There was in the land a certain rich man, richer by far than most men of his time. He had several daughters, one of whom was clearly his favorite, though before the age of twenty she moved from his house to live with friends in a neighboring town. But the rich man did not grieve, for he knew his daughter was happy, and she took comfort in his love.

The chairman of Textron, Inc., G. William Miller, said yesterday that he did not "foresee or contemplate" ever merging with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the financially ailing aerospace giant in which Textron has tentatively agreed to invest $85-million.

The North Carolina senior, a runner-up to Dave Wottle last year, had recorded nine consecutive sub-4-minute races before fading to a 4-minute-5-second effort at the Modesto (Calif.) Relays.

Ballantine Sons brewery accidentally ripped into an ammonia line and sent the fumes billowing through the St. Aloysius parochial school less than 200 yards away. Davis S. Racusin, who retired in 1972 as executive vice president of the Barbizon-Plaza ter Hotel, died yesterday in Fort an Lauderdale, Fla. He had been living in Palm Beach. Fla.

Javits has also made it official. He will seek a fourth term in the United States Senate. And Louis J. Lefkowitz has put himself in the running for a fifth term as State Attorney General.

To the Editor: While very comforting, your May 25 editorial "A New Middle East" bears hardly at all upon the reality. Painstaking scrutiny of the region itself scarcely reveals any change in the Jews' and Arabs' attitudes toward each other that is "close to the miraculous." What changes obtain seem tactical rather than substantive.

Secretary of State Kissinger told three Senators today that he had received assurances recently from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko that emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union would be further eased, according to Senate aides.

Frank Della Santi, owner-operator of a Newark trucking company, was indicted on charges of income-tax evasion by a Federal grand jury in Newark. Mr. Della Santi was accused of having attempted to evade $17,316.25 in income taxes for 1968 through 1970 by failing to report income totaling $63,404.18. If convicted he faces a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison and a $30,000 fine.

The Metropolitan Opera's season of eight free concerts in the city's parks will begin June 25 with a performance of Puccini's "Turandot" on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. All together, there will be, four performances of "Turandot" and four of Puccini's "La Boheme."

Joe Price, executive secretary of the Professional Dance Teachers Association, died Wednesday at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 73 years old.

Canada's mining industry is suddenly suffering-as a result of too much prosperity. After a slump of several years, soaring world prices for the metals that this country has in abundance have revitalized the industry, which is a traditional mainstay of the Canadian economy.
A group of New York banks led by the First National City Bank has submitted to Government authorities a plan to aid the troubled Franklin National Bank, according to banking sources here.

For the last two weeks, 10 detectives have been combing the East Side neighborhood where a 23-year-old library researcher was raped and strangled in her apartment, but they say they have not turned up any clues as to the identity of the killer.

Prices continued to rise on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market yesterday as the trend toward lowerprime interest rates was given impetus by the First National City Bank, which cut its rate from 11 1/2 to 11 1/4 per cent. A few smaller banks followed suit.

Israel began today a 19-day phased evacuation of Syrian territory occupied in last October's war, and military sources said United Nations troops had begun demarcation of the new Golan Heights buffer zone they will man.

The head of a Buenos Aires supermarket chain was shot and killed today in the second attempt to kidnap him in less than six months, his family reported. Relatives said that Gregorio Manoukian, 38 years old,
The City Council's Finance Committee yesterday demanded that Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd appear before 'it in person to defend his budget and a proposed 1,440man increase in the police force.

The Actors Equity Association has entered into negotiations with the League of New York Theaters on terms for a new three-year contract covering basic minimum wages for Broadway and touring performer.

At a recent break in the House Judiciary Committee's closed hearings, Representative Wayne Owens, Democrat of Utah, was besieged by clamoring reporters as he emerged from Room 2141 and walked down the hall.
Premier Mariano Rumor and his key ministers met throughout the day today to discuss Italy's deteriorating economic situation amid speculation that the lira would soon be devalued.

Governor Wilson has indicated that Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, will be his choice for running mate as Lieutenant Governor, state Republican leaders said yesterday.
Unemployment rose somewhat ora in May but remained in the C general range that has pre- Jr. vailed since the start of the year, the Labor Department reported today.
Senate and House conferees have agreed on legislation to impose a temporary ban on research involving the living human fetus, a subject of great controversy in recent months.
The United States and Saudi Arabia agreed today to work together on economic, social, security and financial problems, informed sources reported tonight.

A 20-month-old boy survived without serious injury yesterday when he fell from an eighth-floor apartment window on Madison Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets and landed, apparently unharmed, on a street canopy of a travel agency.
SEX, LUV and JOY are banned on New York State license plates. So are WOW, EEK and NUN. They are among 245 three. letter combinations on a list of taboo words adopted in January, 1973,

W. R. Grace Co. announced yesterday that it would build a $70-million ammonia fertilizer production facility on a site three miles west of Woodward, Okla. The 1,200-ton-per-day plant is scheduled to go into operation by the middle of 1977.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd, and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), in which BP has a 25 per cent interest, have agreed to raise their share in the Alaskan pipeline now under construction from 28 to 50 per cent, British Petroleum said today.
Apparatus that "sees" objects passing before it is proving an effective assembly-line aid for a large pharmaceutical company. Patent 3,814,521 was granted this

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a Government motion to reinstate an indictment thrown out by a lower court after the defendant charged he was being prosecuted only because he supported Senator George McGovern against President Nixon in the 1972 campaign.

A young German couple accused of hiding about 6.6 pounds of cocaine in their baby's crib and baby-food boxes as well as in their baggage were arraigned before a Federal magistrate in Brooklyn yesterday.
Dr. Zelda Sobel Klapper, chief psychologist in the children's evaluation and rehabilitation clinic of the Rose F. Kennedy Center of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of cancer Thursday.
A week long hearing on a lawsuit seeking to compel private voluntary hospitals in New Jersey to open their facilities for women electing to have abortions ended in State Supreme Court today.

Young men and young women, pairing off, now with one, now with another. Coupling, uncoupling. Night blending into day and day into night, weeks to months until no one knows what month,
Negotiations aimed at settling a nationwide strike of men's and boys' clothing workers continued yesterday at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington.

Johnny Miller, who will defend his United States Open golf championship next week, came charging to within two strokes of the lead in the IVB-Philadelphia classic today, but it was Hubert Green who charged to the top.

Former Attorney General Rich ard G. Kleindienst, weeping openly, received today a sus ended sentence for misleading a Senate committee that was investigating the Internationa telephone and Telegraph Corp oration case.
The body of a corporation executive, Dan Burney, missing since he drove out of a downtown parking tower May 21 was found today in a grassy area on the southeast side of the city, the police said.
Legislation aimed at curbing and realigning Presidential staffs and abolishing the President's discretionary $1-million emergency fund has cleared a House committee.
Arthur Ashe and Marty Riessen led a five-man American challenge into the third round of the $200,000 French open tennis tournament today in which the top European favorites also advanced with case.

Rockland County fire and emergency officials tonight began flooding a mile-long railroad tunnel, the scene yesterday of a derailment just south of here, in an effort to subdue the acrid inferno inside.
What a Camden County grand jury will find when it investigates the Camden Police Department next month, City Council President John R. Marini said today, is "chaos."
Defying the sales slump that still afflicts the rest of the auto industry, the Cadillac division of General Motors is selling its luxury cars in record numbers once more.

Rear Adm. William A. Jenkins assumed command of the United States Coast Guard Academy today, relieving Rear Adm. Joseph J. McClelland, who, as a Vice Admiral will command the Coast Guard, Pacific Area.

Prices of truck and other heavy tires are moving up again. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would increase prices on most types and sizes of replacement tires for trucks, industrial vehicles, farm equipment and on all automobile tire tubes, beginning July 1.
Manager Preston Gomez of the Astros received added reason to feel more complacent about his pitching staff tonight.
The Justice Department today asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation why an agent had questioned a newsman about what the head of another branch of the department had said in a speech.

Pakistan charged in a! United Nations committee today that India was at work on a delivery system for nuclear weapons. Iqbal Akhund, Pakistan's chief delegate, also challenged India to prove that she had no intentions of producing weapons by putting all her nuclear facilities under international supervision.

PARIS-The disappearance of Portugal's dictatorship in the wake of a military coup has been regarded with fear and fascination by Europe's remaining right-wing regimes, Spain and Greece. The Governments in power tend to emphasize the fear; their opposition, which includes a majority, stress the fascination.
There are nearly a million soccer fans in the ethnic melting pot of New York, but fewer than 3,000 turn out for the "big-league" games of the Cosmos.

A Manhattan psychoanalyist who treated Mrs. Daniel Ellsberg has disclosed that his office was searched by intruders in November, 1971, less than three months after the attempt in Los Angeles by the White House "plumbers" to steal Dr. Ellsberg's medical records from the office of his former psychiatrist.
The new version of the Kennedy Library has been designed to meet all objections to the original, says the architectural firm of I. M. Pei and Partnersand that is just the building's problem.
The leader of the Kurdish minority in Iraq accused tile Baghdad Govermnent today of waging "a war of genocide" against the 2.3 million Kurds.
The court-martial of 57 air force officials and 10 civilians accused of sedition moved into its final phase with the end of public hearings today.
Unemployment rose somewhat in May but remained in the general range that has prefailed since the start of the year, the Labor Department reported today.

Six stolen, oil paintings worth $500,000 were returned to. the multimillion-dollar art collection of Joseph H. Hirshhorn today following a secret rendezvous in a Federal courthouse.

A 20-month-old boy survived without serious injury yesterday when he fell from an eighth-floor apartment window on Madison Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets and landed on a street canopy of a travel agency.

Rockland county tire and emergency officials tonight began flooding a mile-long railroad tunnel, the scene yesterday of a derailment just south of here, in an effort to subdue the acrid inferno inside.
George T. McSpedon, a trade union official, died yesterday morning at Yonkers General Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 187 Morsmer Avenue, Yonkers.

Glenn W. Johnson has been named president and chief operating officer of Sterling Drug, Inc., a major pharmaceutical and consumer-goods company, effective July 1. He will succeed David J. Fitzgibbons, who is retiring. W.

Premier Mariano Rumor of Italy and his key ministers held long meetings to discuss the country's worsening economic crisis. Meanwhile, there were reports in financial circles that the Government would officially devalue the lira by 20 per cent, and newspapers and politicians speculated that Premier Rumor's Cabinet might collapse. [1:1.]
An American helicopter has been shot down over Seoul by nervous South Korean gunners in an action that is taken here as underscoring the jumpy and confused mood of the city.

Despite its seeming complexity, the gold issue is not insoluble. Americans and Europeans should not find it hard to agree that the present official price of gold at $42.22 is meaningless and that it would be desirable for nations to be able to use their gold reserves to cover deficits.

A White House spokesman said today that President Nixon had "expressed a willingness" tp help two close former aides, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, meet their Watergate-related legal expenses but that the President had never provided any such help.

Dover Delicacies, at 144 East 57th Street, is a place where one can find 14-ounce tins of Beluga caviar for $90 and s where celebrities line up for sandwiches when they visit in New York. It is a place that has been asked to send fruit to a Florida, cold cuts to a Democratic national convention in Atlantic City and ice cream to Califrnia.
William D. Eberle, President Nixon's special trade representative, ended two days of intensive talks with officials of the European Economic Community here today.

Governor Byrne proposed today two alternative plans for imposing a graduated state income-tax on New Jersey residents to raise $750-million that is needed to refinance the state's public schools and to aid counties and municipalities.

The head of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries-the cartel of foreign oil producers-today expressed greater willingness for a dialogue with consumer countries on the problems created by higher oil prices.

The Jamaican Senate approved a bill today that will more than quadruple the money Jamaica receives from companies operating there for bauxite, the raw material of aluminum.

J. Paul Getty, one of the world's richest men, is most unhappy about the British Government's plans to tax the worldwide income of foreign residents, and he's threatening to quit Britain. For about 20 years he has operated from Sutton Place, his mansion in Surrey, running an empire so wealthy that he doesn't know its value.

It will not have escaped the student of such matters that the art market has at last caught up with Mark Tobey, and that his name now figures on the list of painters most sought after by unnamed "investors." Doubtless, this would have happened years ago, had it not been for the fact that Mr. Tobey is the most steadfast of absentees from his native country.

Exhibitions designed to evoke the splendors of distant theatrical achievements are, by their very nature, exercises in magical suggestion.

Verrazzano College, the Italian-American-sponsored institution first conceived of more than.10 years ago, will finally open next fall on a ready-built campus in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. With a president, some office workers and the beginning of a faculty, all it needs now are students.

The stock market finally got the good news it has been waiting for-a cut in the prime rate by a major bank-and moved upward yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average gained 8.37 points and closed at 853.72.

In its first major action against extreme left-wing groups here, the Portuguese Government today arrested the editor of a weekly newspaper. The editor, Luis Saldanha Sanches, was picked up by the police early this morning and taken to the town of Elvas,

Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for,,,Governor, charged yesterday in a suit filed in Federal District Court that Governor Wilson, while Lieutenant Governor, violated the law by representing as a lawyer companies subject to state regulation.

The First National City Bank, second largest in the nation, cut its prime lending rate yesterday by one-quarter point to 11 1/4 per cent effective immediately. The move sparked optimistic speculation that soaring interest rates may have finally peaked.
A grand jury today indicted 13 men, involved in three separate cases, on charges of stealing $520,000 in securities and conspiring to counterfeit $4-million in stock certificates,

The United States warned the Comnon Market countries, in a letter sent to each last week, about the political danger of the proposed European dialogue with Arab states, informed sources in Brussels said today.

A very gentle lobby paid a call upon the office of Premier Tanaka in Tokyo the other day. Girls from the United States, Canada and Sweden presented 75,000 letters from children around the world urging Japan to agree to a ten-year moratorium on whaling.

The most menacing attack the New York Yankees could muster in their 3-2 defeat to Minnesota last night at Shea Stadium turned out to be the threatening gestures Lou Piniella made toward Bert Blyleven, the Twins right-hander in the seventh inning.

More than 4,000 nures struck today at 40 major hospitals and clinics caring for thousands of patients. The nurses set up picket lines at dawn, and the hospitals in the San Francisco Bay area quickly began discharging any patients able to leave.

Four more Government .ministers resigned today, informed sources said. Eight ministers in the Government of Premier Long Boret have now. resigned since the death of Education Minister Keo Sangkim during clashes Tuesday between military policemen and students.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that the tenants conducting a rent strike at the Stella Wright Housing Project had rejected efforts to resolve the dispute over living conditions at the high-rise project "because they simply want to live rent-free."

Federal Judge John J. Sirica lifted today the protective order that has kept secret for almost a month the court papers describing President Nixon as an unindicted co-conspirator in the Watergate cover-up.

A 20-year-old factory worker suspected of slaying two high school girls and charged with kidnapping two women at knifepoint was being questioned today in connection with a number of missing-persons cases in South Jersey.

Appearing on demand before the City Council's Finance Committee yesterday, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd defended the program to increase the police force by 1,440 new men and the need for $29-million in the budget for this purpose.

The Lykes-Youngstown Corporation's estimated earnings for the first half of this year should reach $40-million after taxes, J. T. Lykes Jr., chairman, announced yesterday. The rise would come to 86.9 per cent above the $21.4-million net income shown in the corresponding six months of 1973.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that President Nixon was apparently under a "misapprehension" in reportedly suggesting that he had requested the wiretapping of Government officials and journalists beginning in 1969.
Doctors contirmed today that Ohio State's football coach, Woody Hayes, suffered a heart attack early yesterday at his home. His condition was described as "stable."

Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Transportation Subcommittee of the Senate Public Works Committee, introduced mass-transit legislation today that would give New York City $100-million this year - half its operating deficit.

The possibility that Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson exceeded the legal spending limit in last month's mayoral election by funneling money to other candidates is being investigated by the State Election Law Enforcement Commission. David F. Norcross, the commission's executive director, said yesterday that the commission was investigating the possibility that two Paterson Council candidates spent $8,000 to help Mayor Kramer and listed the expenditures in their own names.

With a statement of conscience and some plans for action, religious leaders ended today a four-day seminar on a crisis that they agreed was awesome and corn plex: hunger, poverty and injustice in the world.

Weariness with the Watergate story and with the snowballing problems of the Nixon Administration are thought by some 'network officials to be the reason for a decline of more than 2 per cent in the audiences for television network news over the first five months of this year.

Following is a weekly listing of the Un-audited net asset value applicable in the capital shares of dual-purpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market price of best over-ten-counter dollar-to-dollar asked price for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference(discount on Premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.
The police said today they know who kidnapped the Earl. and Countess of Donoughmore and expressed fears that the elderly Protestant couple may have been murdered.

Jimmy Gabrielson, a United States Walker Cup player from Atlanta, charged into the final of the British Amateur golf championship with two victories today. Gabrielsen outclassed two English rivals over Muirfield's windy, 6,862-yard,
The Soviet authorities have decided to let the ballet dancers Valery Panov and Galina Ragozina, his wife, emigrate to Israel, unofficial Soviet sources reported today.

A 20-year-old factory worker suspected of slaying two high school girls and charged with kidnapping two women at knifepoint was being questioned today in connection with a numher of missing-persons cases in South Jersey.
Weather: Chance of rain today and tonight. Mostly cloudy tomorrow. Temp. range: today 56-65; Friday 56-64. Temp.-Hum. Index yesterday 63. Additional details on Page 62.

Miss Robin Tieken, daughter of Mrs. Robert Tieken of Chicago and the late Mr. Tieken, was married yesterday to John W. B. Hadley of Chicago, an independent investor. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hadley of New York. The Rev. Martin E. Marty, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom.

Two young Palestinians who hijacked a British Airways jet to Amsterdam in March were sentenced yesterday to five-year prison terms. Adnan Nuri, 23 years old, was convicted of air piracy, illegal possession of arms and arson. Sami Tamimah, 22, was convicted on piracy and arms charges.
The pain at Great Neck, L. I., is mainly on the train these mornings-specifically the new 8:15 for Manhattan, which is already packed when it rolls into the station, bound for the city.

Robert L. Banchard, whose tents and survival gear were used in Adm. Richard E. Byrd's early polar exploration work and in the 1963 American Mount Everest expedition, died here Monday, apparently of a heart attack while driving his car. He was 79 years old and lived at 180 Central Park South.

One of the key issues that will be confronting representatives of the major financial powers at the final session of their monetary conference in Washington next week will be how to resolve the conflict between the United States and several European countries on the future role of gold.

There is a fine and wild variety to the New York City Ballet repertory. Weather dominated trading in grain futures once again yesterday. Traders talked of a forecast of rain over Oklahoma this weekend and the Mississippi River being about five feet above flood stage at Alton, Ill.
Former Treasury Secretary P. Shultz tacitly approved a secret plan to distribute $1.4billion in Government funds to create the most favorable impact on President Nixon's reelection campaign,

Northrop Worldwide Aircraft Services, Inc., received a $23.2-million Army contract for maintenance of fixed-wing aircraft and helicopters for fiscal 1975 at Fort Rucker, Ala., it was announced yesterday.
Six months of turmoil in the office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York began last Dec. 4 with the suicide of the man who had held the job for two and a half years.
Governor Wilson has indicated that Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, will be his choice for running mate as Lieutenant Governor, state Republican leaders said yesterday.
Scaled-down plans for the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library were unveiled here today amid continuing controversy over the project in the city that contributed so much to his mystique.

When Princeton University's women's sailing team returns from a trip to California later this month, it hopes to bring back what most of its male athlete friends at the college have failed to achieve - a national championship.

The fuel economy of 1975 cars will be much higher than had been expected with the new catalytic converters to control pollution, Russell E. Train, administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, said yesterday.

Vicente Duarte Gomes came to Angola 23 years ago because Portugal did not provide enough work for him as a bricklayer in and around Lisbon. He was a construction worker for three years, making a living. Then he came to this region more than 100 miles southeast of the capital, Luanda, to help in the restoration of the ruins of a 300-year-old foundry.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art's recent venture into purchasing quilts has produced a collection that, although modest in size, is exceptional in quality.

Lynda Gudde, very much an original choreographer, continues to work tenaciously and fruitfully outside the mainstream of current modern-dance modes. Her company, the Gudde Dancers, presented four works, including two premieres, Thursday night at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street.

An endearingly simple, honest and moving film like "Where the Lilies Bloom" would be welcome any time. Arriving now on a screen splattered with violence and sex, this beautiful little movie is like a cool, clear dip of mountain spring water.

Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, weeping openly, received today a suspended sentence for misleading a Senate committee that was investigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation case.
Jim Northrup, who has won his share of games with his bat during 11 seasons in a Detroit uniform, provided the hit for another victory last night in Tiger Stadium.
Senate and House conferees have agreed on legislation to impose a temporary ban on research involving the living human fetus, a subject of great controversy in recent months.

The New York Philharmonic's final Promenade program of the season, which will be given its last performance tonight, is devoted to French music and has Mignon Dunn, mezzo-soprano as soloist in two groups of songs and arias.
At one point during the 24th annual convention of the United Automobile Workers, Douglas Eraser, . a vice president, Warned the delegates: "You can push too far. You know this is a delicate balance."
Attorney General William B. Saxbe warned the nation's businessmen today that free enterprise maybe wrecked if: they do not face up to "personal Watergates" and stop cutting corners with the law.

A former Queens prosecutor yesterday denied at the murder trial of Police Officer Thomas J. Shea that any threats had been made against Officer Walter Scott, who was the patrol partner of the defendant. Omcer Shea is charged with the slaying of 10-year-old Clifford Glover.
The Rev. William E. Gardner, pastor of the First Baptist Church of East Elmhurst, Queens, died Tuesday at Hampton, Va., where he was attending a ministers' conference.
Premier Mariano Rumor and his key ministers met throughout the day today to discuss Italy's deteriorating economic situation amid speculation that the lira would soon be devalued.

Tornadoes were reported yesterday in Arkansas and Texas and thunderstorms and hail pounded the nation's midsection, United Press International reported. A tornado was sighted in England. Ark., 17 miles southeast of Little Rock,
Israeli prisoners of war who returned from captivity in Damascus said in interviews today that they had been brutally treated by their Syrian jailers.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had agreed to negotiate future American military assistance to Israel on a long -term rather than yearly basis.

Blessed though compassion may be, it can hardly be said that confidence in equality of justice has been fortified by the gentle sentence administered to former Attorney General Kleindienst. He admitted that he lied under oath to the Senate Judiciary Committee while testifying on his qualifications to be the nation's chief law-enforcer.
The Nixon Administration used the Federal bureaucracy for political profit and apparently violated several criminal statutes in the process, according to a Senate Watergate committee staff report.

Top-seeded Patti Hogan lost to a fellow Californian, Kate Latham, in a controversial third-round match in the Northern tennis tournament today. The scores were 4-6, 6-2, 6-3. Miss Hogan protested bitterly when the match, the first set of which was played on grass, was switched indoors. After losing, she left the court in tears.

"Oh, no, no, no, no, no!" Nelson A. Rockefeller let a wisp of frown mix with his crinkled grin as he rejected the suggestion that he might suffer pangs of regret at not having the dominant role to play at the Republican state nominating convention next week.

The Belmont Stakes will have its 106th running today, at Belmont Park, and the line-up for the 1 1/2-mile contest: embraces 11 thoroughbreds. There is a strong chance, though, that there may be further withdrawals before post time at 5:40P.M.,

Federal Judge John J. Sirica lifted today the protective order that has kept secret for almost a month the court papers describing President Nixon as an unindicted co-conspirator in the Watergate cover-up.

A voice said by her family to be that of Patricia Hearst stated in a tape-recording broadcast here today her commitment to the so-called Symbionese Liberation Army and her determination to continue the terrorist fight.

The teen-aged son of a police lieutenant and two other youths were charged today with the kidnapping of a woman from the garden of her five-acre estate. "This caps our investigation, and no further arrests are expected," said Richard J. Baker,
Grant Gilbert Simmons, retired head of the Simmons Company, manufacturers of mattresses and home furnishings, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 80 years old.

Seventy-four years after his death in a Los Angeles home for soldiers, John (Liver Eating) Johnston is returning to Cody, Wyo.-within sight of the Absaroka Mountains he once roamed. Mr. Johnston, recently portrayed by Robert Redford in the movie "Jeremiah Johnson," died in Santa Monica on Jan. 22, 1900, at the age of 78,

The New York Philharmonic's final Promenade program of the season, which will be given its last performance tonight, is devoted to French music and has Mignon Dunn, mezzo-soprano as soloist in two groups of songs and arias.

Ritha Devi provided an invaluable compendium of classical Indian dance styles Thursday at Carnegie Recital Hall, both in her wise and funny commentary and in her demanding 2 1/2-hour solo recital. She is an artist who must be seen.

Shortly after the Senate session began this morning, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, whispered to Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, that he had "a little amendment that would just take a few minutes."

A tender offer was made yesterday by the Signal Companics, Inc., to purchase at least I million shares of its common stock for $24 a share If the offer is oversubscribed, the company at its option will buy up to 1.6 million shares, and if all tendered shares are not purchased, shares will be bought on a pro-rata basis.
The National Football League Players Association disputed yesterday claims by the club owners that the teams in 1973 averaged profits of $472,500, or 7.6 per cent, after taxes.
The African nationalist movement in Portuguese Guinea said today that a force of African mercenaries in the pay of foreign powers was heading toward the territory's capital of Bissau in two ships.

The Kremlin has dispatched a negotiating team to Vienna for economic talks following Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's failure last week to win Soviet agreement to step up oil supplies to his country.

Negotiations are being conducted by the International Paper Company for a possible merger of the General Crude Oil Company, a Houston-based independent producer of oil and gas, as a whollyowned subsidiary
Alan J. Zuch, proprietor of the Williamsville Inn near Stockbridge, Mass., died here Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Stockbridge.

State Supreme Court Justice Franklin W. Morton Jr. said yesterday in an address to graduates of the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University that adult, not juvenile, education was needed to combat the revival of street gangs in Brooklyn.

The problem of the municipal laundry on Roosevelt Island is like a lot of the pesty problems that come up in city government. It sounds simple but ends up being complex. It is too important to be ignored by City Hall, but not quite important enough to occupy the highest officials.

Senator Charles H. Percy called today for a Government crackdown on the hearing aid industry that would limit sales to prescriptions only and bring an end to what he described as "immoral" prices and profits.

Mrs. Joanne Carner rallied from three strokes behind today to overtake Sandra Palmer and win her third tournament in four weeks by capturing the $100,000 Desert Golf Classic. A final three-under-par 70 for 284 earned her a one-stroke victory over Carole Jo Skala.
State Senator John J. Marchi said today that he would introduce a bill at next year's session of the Legislature to prohibit corporal punishmen in all public schools throughout the state.

The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday attributed the upset victory he and his entire insurgent slate scored late Saturday to the "erosion" of the professional and economic status of New York's police officers.

The Earl and Countess of Donoughmore, who were freed early this morning after being held four days by kidnappers, said here today that they thought the masked gunmen who guarded them around the clock in a hide-out were members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

Jody Scheckter, who frightened rival drivers with madcap tactics as much as thrilled spectators last season while capturing the Formula 5000 series title in the United States, drove one of the most disciplined races of his young life today and won his first grand prix.

Charles Evers, the civil rights leader, says Gov. George C. Wallace has changed over the years to the degree that he would support the Alabama politician as a Vice-Presidential candidate on the national Democratic ticket in 1976.

The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America yesterday unanimously endorsed the proposed three-year contract that would end the nationwide strike against 750 manufacturers.

The Union Oil Company of California has developed a new process for oil and gas recovery from shale that is expected to increase the company's reserves by 15 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday.

Italy's Roman Catholic bishops today warned those priests and monks who dissented from the hierarchy's stand on the referendum on divorce last month that "there will not be space in our churches for arid and corrosive protest."

Steel production in the week ended June 8 slipped to 2,862,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was down 1.3 per cent and left the production index at 117.3. A week earlier the industry poured 2,901,000 tons for, an index of 118.9.

Awilda Grayson's debut recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night suggested that with the right program she could be a modestly successful soprano. Miss Grayson, who was born in Puerto Rico but has studied and performed in this country for some years, proved to be an ample-voiced singer with a bright-eyed charm that seemed to endear her to the large audience.

The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a nontenured teacher could no longer be discharged summarily without being given a reason for the dismissal. In a 5-to-2 opinion that overturned a series of lower court and state administrative rulings, New Jersey's highest court declared that if a teacher was not rehired after a threeyear probationary period, "and tenure is thus precluded, he is surely interested in knowing why."

Rear Adm. Raymond J. Mansfield, U.S. Medical Corps, retired, died yesterday at Stamford, Conn. He was 80 years old and had lived in nearby Darien.

The Metropolitan Opera discovered a workable combination last night in its new production of two oneacters, "Bluebeard's Castle" and "Gianni Schicchi." The former and more profound work proved disappointing visually, but more of that later.
Contending that "cocaine is simply not a narcotic drug," Roger A. Lowenstein, the Federal public defender for New Jersey, today asked a Federal district court to declare the substance a nonnarcotic.
The Wounded Knee trials were temporarily postponed today after a Public Health Service physician reported that Russell C. Means, one of the defendants, was suffering from bleeding ulcers.

EDINBURGH, Scotland-The American Revolution was the first blow struck against the British Empire. The 200th anniversary of this great event might easily see the coup de grace dealt by England's oldest Colony.

White spectators attacked anti-apartheid demonstrators who delayed a British Lions Rugby Union game today. The 10 protesters walked onto the playing area where the Lions were competing against the Southern Universities, carrying a banner reading: "We are playing with apartheid."
President Nixon has signed legislation providing an additional $306-million in Federal funds to create jobs for young people this summer, according to the White House.

President Nixon's White House economic adviser said tonight that, in contrast to the last 106 years, the Government planned now to stick with fiscal and monetary restraint for as long as needed to bring down the rate of inflation.

Circuit Court Judge John V. Cassidento, who had been a lawyer for Alfred Baldwin 3d, a Watergate figure, before his elevation to the Connecticut bench last year, died while undergoing heart surgery in Yale- D New Haven Hospital on Monday evening.

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has announced a $1-million grant in Federal funds to rehabilitate public housing units in Newark and possibly $1-million for Jersey City and Camden. H. R. Crawford, the assistant secretary, said he hoped the new funds could help stop the rent strike that has paralyzed the Newark Housing Authority.

At 27 years old, has seen his dream of a major league 'pitching career pass him by. The former Minnesota Twins' bonus baby has settled for being the team's batting practice pitcher, His pay is $15 for throwing batting practice for approximately 15 minutes.

In a small farming community north of here, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau looked down from the stage of a high school auditorium at a crowd that included at least a sprinkling of political opponents.

President Anwar el-Sadat has promised Palestinian leaders that he will seek concessions from King Hussein of Jordan to make it possible for the Palestinians to take part in the Middle East peace talks in Geneva.

The Pittsburgh Triangles filed an official protest today with the World Team Tennis commissioner, George MacCall, over a disputed call in last night's 22-19 loss to the Detroit Loves at Detroit. The call involved an out-of-bounds shot by Detroit's Allen Stone in the deciding mixed-doubles event. The umpire ruled the point and game to Pittsburgh, but changed his ruling when the net cord judge declared the ball hit the racquet of Pittsburgh's Peggy Michel.

Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, citing President Nixon's refusal to provide White House documents, ordered today that a separate, delayed trial be held for John D. Ehrlichman in the "plumbers" case.

A strike by 4,000 nurses in northern California went into its fifth day today with no end in sight. Forty-three hospitals in the Bay area alone were reportedly closed yesterday for all but emergency cases.
Edward J. Pierce, retired board chairman of the Harlem Savings Bank, died Monday in his home at 22 Bacon Road, Old Westbury, L.I. He was 68 years old.
President Nixon met with Austria's Chancellor, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, today as part of his preparations for the beginning of his Middle East tour tomorrow.
In a stormy court hearing, a Harlem pastor was directed yesterday to keep his hands off $50,000 he had tried to post as bail in a murder case.

Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday to pay their outgoing president, Robert M. McKiernan,,and the other 12 outgoing board members a year's expenses, as the P.B.A. describes the payment made above regular police salaries.
declared today that despite the resignation of six Cabinet ministers, he had been asked by President Lon Nol and the governing Social Republican party to remain in office.

President Nixon departed for his travels in the Middle East confident that his legal position on impeachment and public feeling about the Watergate scandal had stabilized, according to White House aides close to the President.

Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and now a partner in Brown Brothers Harriman Co., predicted here yesterday that borrowings in this country by foreign governments and foreign government entities in 1974 would total $10-billion.

George Mitchell, a former political lieutenant of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in the state's primary election tonight. On the Republican side, former state Attorney General James S. Erwin of Pittston held a slim lead over Harrison Richardson.

Commercial banks, in a continuing effort to quash the introduction of savings bank "payment order" accounts here, urged the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday to equalize the interest rites they can pay on savings accounts with the rates now paid by New York State savings banks.

An estimated 17,000 foreign students out of the 150,000 who are enrolled in American colleges face financial difficulties this summer if the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service enforces its recent order prohibiting these students from accepting temporary employment.

The House Banking Committee approved a bill today extending the Export Control Act for an additional two years, giving the Secretary of Commerce continued authority to impose export controls under certain conditions. Present authority of the act expires June 30.
A member of the Soviet leadership asserted today that President Nixon's forthcoming visit to the Soviet Union emphasized that Moscow and Washington had put summit meetings on a regular basis.

Francisco Springer, who is better known as the Mighty Sparrow, calls himself "the calypso king of the world." The city's West Indian community agrees, by and large, and when he performs here, as he did on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, the hard grind for the Yankee dollar is forgotten for a while.

Re-election efforts on behalf of President Nixon included a plan for using Federal funds to induce black leaders such as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and James Farmer to remain neutral or support the President in 1972, according to a draft report by the staff of the Senate Watergate committee.
Secretary of the Treasury told Congress today that he hoped to recommend to President Nixon "before the end of this year" that Americans be allowed to buy, sell and own gold.

A House Banking subcommittee approved a bill today authorizing a $1.5-billion contribution for low - interest loans to developing countries and sent it to the full Banking Committee.

The platform adopted today by the Republican State Committee without a murmur of dissent appeared designed to offer something for virtually everyone in the state much as its "balanced" statewide ticket did.

A long-term analysis by Government experts shows that the economy will not be able to grow as rapidly in the next decade as it has in the past, according to Roy L. Ash, Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

Secretary of State Kissinger, in an extraordinary news conference at which he appeared choked with hurt and angers said today he would resign unless he was cleared of allegations that he participated in "illegal or shady activity" in Government wiretapping of individuals.

The House voted today to extend for a year suspension of duty on certain forms of copper. Without Congressional action, the duty, suspended since 1966 except for a brief period, would be reimposed July 1. The measure was sent to the Senate by a voice vote.

Two youg men, arrested following a high-speed chase through Newark city streets today, were held in connection with the stabbing murder of a Seton Hall University law professor in his home early Sunday morning.
James J. Del Mauro, the formed chief magistrate of Newark who was mentioned in the telephone conversations of the mobster Angelo DeCarld pleaded guilty today to incometax fraud.

The Right Rev. John, Maury Allin was formally installed today as the 23d presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church during ceremonies at the Washington: Cathedral.

The House Judiciary Committee reportedly heard evidence today suggesting that concern about the possible disclosure of a burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist was a principal reason behind the alleged Watergate cover-up.

President Giovanni Leone tonight started the traditional round of consultations preliminary to designating a new Premier to succeed Mariano Rumor, who resigned with his coalition last night after it failed to agree on how to deal with Italy's financial emergency.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City extended his political control over Hudson County tonight with the election of Bernard Hartnett Jr., a close friend and political ally, as chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization.

School Chancellor Irving An ker said yesterday that he would ask district school authorities to respond to charges that they had appointed some acting principals who were "illiterate in English" and thus unfit for their Dosts.
Eleven major New York banks, with the apparent backing of the Federal Reserve Board, have agreed to lend $250-million--on a secured basis--to the financially pressed Franklin National Bank.
Mrs. Corinne L. Duffy, the mother of James E. Duffy, president of ABC-TV, died Saturday at her home in Princeton, Ill. She was 75 years old. Her husband, Harold, died last year.

Mrs. Luisa Graa de Alvarez del Vayo died May 28 in Geneva at the age of 76, it was learned here yesterday. She was the wife of Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of the Spanish Republic until its overthrow in 1939.

After a show of dissatisfaction from Republicans loyal to Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Governor Wilson today filled out his state ticket with an upstater, former Mayor Stephen May of Rochester, as candidate for Controller.

Local elections rarely have international as well as national importance; but the narrow victory of West Germany's new Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, in the state of Lower Saxony is an exception to the usual rule.

WASHINGTON-This is going to be a hard year for Republicans on the campaign trail. But observers are saying that it may also prove to be a tough year for incumbent Democrats. Some of the voter sentiment is indiscriminately anti-incumbent.

Henderson Smith, 82 years old, injured by a tornado that wrecked a nursing home on Saturday, died today, increasing to 16 the number of persons killed during weekend storms, the Red Cross said.

A Manhattan grand jury harshly criticized the Department of Social Services yesterday about its management of a welfare photo-identification system, charging that the system was promoting fraud rather than preventing it.
The head of the Internal Revenue Service denied today charges that the agency works under a quota system that rewards tax agents for their harshness.

Edgar Ellinger Jr., who had been a securities analyst and financial executive with Lionel D. Edie Co., Lazard Freres and other Wall Street houses, died on Monday at his home in Mountain Ranch, Calif. He was 68 years old.

Billy Feliciano of South Shore won the Public Schools Athletic League tennis singles championship yesterday with a 6-1, 6-1 rout of Dave Cooper of Newtown in the final at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

The triangle is named in honor of Father Francis P. Duffy of the Fighting 69th in World War I, but to a younger generation it is known as Needle Park, where junkies nod in the sun.

William R. Sands, a campaign manager for the Advertising Council, died Friday of a heart attack while on the way to his office in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Elizabeth, N.J.

About 10,000 Americans complain to the telephone company each year that their telephones are tapped, and subsequent investigation has found their suspicions valid in about 2 per cent of the cases, a telephone company official said today.

The jury deliberating the murder case of Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, the first New York City policeman ever charged with committing murder while on duty, failed to reach a verdict last night and will resume its efforts this morning.

Silver futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday dropped the 20-cent-an-ounce limit. The July delivery for silver futures closed at $5.061/2 an ounce down from $5.261/2 Monday. With contracts down the limit, trading dried up during the session and volume amounted to only 2,536 contracts.

Charles J. Spies Sr., who retired as assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1958 after 40 years with the institution, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital, Denville, N.J. He was 80. years old and lived in Boonton Township.
The House Interior Committee approved today a $3.1-million energy research and development bill. The bill has strong emphasis on renewable resources, solar energy research, and energy conservation.

The National Hockey League filled the rosters of its two new teams today, the New York Rangers officially acquired Derek Sanderson from the Boston Bruins and Denver and Seattle were named as the expansion clubs for 1976.

Nathaniel S. Rothenberg, a lawyer and a Zionist leader, died at Mount Sinai Hospital on Tuesday evening. He was 61 years old and lived at 225 West 86th Street.
