A key prosecution witness in the conspiracy trial of Currier J. Holman and his company, Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., testified yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that Mr. Holman had known that "payoffs" were necessary to do business in New York City.

Governor Wilson accepted the nomination of state Republicans for a full term tonight with "a message for those crepe-hangers, those hopeful pallbearers and those wishful thinkers outside our party who would like to believe our party is dead."
Saudi Arabia's acquisition of 60 per cent ownership of the ArabianAmerican Oil Company forms part of a plan to bring crude oil prices lower, according to Saudi Arabian Government sources.

Italy's second political crisis in three months has the same origin as the first: the impact of a fourfold increase in oil prices on an economy already suffering from strains difficult for a weak coalition government to resolve. The international cause of the trouble suggests that it requires an international solution.

Norman Cousins announced yesterday that Saturday Review/World had begun operating in the black in recent weeks-a year after the publishers of the old Saturday Review magazines had filed bankruptcy proceedings with more than $4-million in debts.

The United States contributed $400,-000 today to the United Nations program for assisting the repatriation of Bengalis and Pakistanis trapped by the 1971 war between India and Pakistan and by Bangladesh's gaining of independence.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Conference on the International Sale of Goods--10 A.M. Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee I-10:30 A.M., subcommittee 11-3 P.M.

Th Asamera Oil Corporation Ltd., reported yesterday net income of $6.5-million, or 89 cents a share, for the fiscal year ended March 31. This represents an increase of 132.1 per cent from the $2.8-million, or 38 cents a share, earned in the preceding fiscal year, which included an extraordinary gain of $59,743.

Henry Kissinger's unique place in world politics was indicated plainly enough by the British treatment of his resignation threat. It made banner headlines even in the tabloids. The Guardian doubtless reflected informed opinion when it said his departure would be "a sad day."
A county guard whose father was jailed on gambling charges and ended up being guarded occasionally by his son, has been ordered transferred from the Morris Counto Jail.

Fresh doubts over the prospects of lower interest rates sent the stock market down yesterday in sluggish trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened sharply lower and by 10:30 A.M. the Dow-Jones industrial average was down 9.15 points, its low for the day.

Lee MacPhail, American League president, upheld yesterday the forfeit of the Cleveland Indians' June 4 game to the Texas Rangers after he met with Indians' officials. MacPhail met with Ted Bonda, vice president of the Indians. and Phil Seghi, the club's general manager.
Given the rate at which talented cellists have been emerging within the past few years, the nineteen-seventies may someday be identified in cello history as the decade of the talent explosion.

Savers last month withdrew $190-million more from their savings bank accounts than they deposited. This outflowthe first for the month of May since World War II-worsened The shortage of funds available for home mortgages.
Maurice Bower Saul, who had been a lawyer in Philadelphia from 1905 until his retirement in 1970, died Monday evening at his home in Rose Valley, Pa. He was 90 years old.

Backed by the state's top Democratic leaders, Howard J. Samuels today appeared assured of at least 70 per cent of the Democratic State Committee vote while his only challenger, Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn, fought to capture at least the 25 per cent of the vote needed to force a primary fight over the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

The nation's druggists have proposed that certain nonprescription drugs be sold only by registered pharmacists so that consumers can be warned about adverse reactions to the potentially harmful chemicals that many of the drugs contain.

The following are the results of local school board elections in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. The tax rates, where available, are for each $100 of assessed valuation in Nassau and Suffolk and for each $1,000 in Westchester and Rockland.

The announcement from Washington yesterday that the National Ballet was to suspend its activities indefinitely and was immediately releasing its dancers and staff caused no surprise in American dance circles.

A detailed plan for the amalgamation of the American and National Basketball Associations in time for next season has been drawn in informal meetings the last few days, It will come up before each league in formal meetings next week.

Greetings! Those cards that people send to each other on Father 's Day, Mother's Day, graduation day, birthdays and all of those other Big Days are not just sentimental. They're also sexist.
A 13-year-old boy drowned yesterday while swimming with three playmates in the Bronx River near a waterfall in the Bronx Zoo, the police reported.

Prince Charles, saying that he stood with "some degree of fear and trembling," made his maiden speech from the floor of the House of Lords today, the first such speech by a member of the royal family in 90 years.

A biomedical research institute meant to be comparable to New York's Rockefeller University will be established at Duke University through a gift of a New York industrialist, it ' was announced here today.

Don Cherry, who led the Rochester Americans to the best over-all record in the American Hockey League last season was signed yesterday as the new coach of the Boston Bruins, Stanley Cup runner-up, in the National Hockey League.

An international banking group has arranged a $100-million eurodollar loan to Argentina. The money is to be used in the country's development program. The loan will be for eight years at a floating rate. Members in the group include Bankers Trust Company. Euro
The "bugs" invaded Music City this week-more than 12,000 of them, armed with cameras, pens and tape recorders.
Jim Barr scattered six Chicago hits and Gary Thomasson singled home the only run of the game in the seventh inning today to give the San Francisco Giants a 1-0 victory over the Cubs.

A Federal appeals court today ordered an end to former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s freedom on bail while his conviction for the My Lai slayings is argued in civilian courts.

The art of resigning from political office-whether to slip or sneak away or go out with a bang-has declined rather seriously in this country in recent years. The people who should resign won't, and the people who shouldn't, threaten to do so.
United States Air Force planes will start a 90-day relief operation to Mali in West Africa on June 15, the Pentagon said today.
Howard J. Samuels easily won the Democratic State Committee designation for Governor tonight, but Representative Hugh L. Carey won enough support to force a fight in the September 10 primary.

William F. Knowland, the former Senate majority leader and publisher of The Oakland Tribune, was financially insolvent at the time of his death and owed more than $900,000 in personal bank loans, court documents showed today. Mr. Knowland died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound last Feb. 23.

Tempers and radiators were boiling yesterday over the West Side Highway-or the lack of it. Angry drivers, residents and some politicians are charging that the city is dawdling on repairing the tumble-down elevatedd route and its extension north of 72d Street, the Henry Hudson Parkway.
An armed robber shot and wounded a police officer and disarmed another officer by using a 3-year-old girl as a shield during a holdup yesterday in a discount store in Glen Oaks, Queens.

Business loans at New York and Chicago banks increased sharply during the week ended Wednesday, and some key short-term interest rates rose. The developments at least partly deflated the hope that the worst was already over for the credit markets.

In an effort to erase the disparities in the quality of education in' New Jersey's school districts, the Joint Education Committee of the Legislature proposed today to limit the expenditures for each pupil in affluent districts while encouraging poor districts to increase their spending.

The 254 public broadcasting stations in the country have a chance to make a great leap forward if the Federal Government finally recognizes that they are not a threatening force but a national resource. This is the moment when the independent Corporation for Public Broadcasting, a major source of funding and also of immunization from local political pressure, can be assured of the longterm financial stability essential to intelligent programing.

The army in the Republic of Yemen has seized power in an apparently bloodless coup. The state-controlled Yemeni radio, quoted by Egypt's official Middle East News Agency, announced tonight that the armed forces had set up a seven-man council to run the country.

The performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" offered Wednesday evening by the Metropolitan Opera had its intermittent charms, no doubt. But it was presented as part of the Met's June Festival, and it hardly measured up to the festive standards suggested by the word "festival."

Not many horses achieve instant stardom in the showjumping world. For the most part, they are bought young, usually right off the race track and their progress is slow. They are sent to small shows when they are ready, then return to the farm and work some more.
Landlords were ordered by Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz yesterday to pay tenants accrued interest on security deposits held before Sept. 1, 1970.

The austerity program that the French Government proposed yesterday brought expressions of anxiety today from both unions and business circles but for different reasons.

Senator John G. Tower almost succeeded today in getting the Senate to consider legislation that would have permitted Gen. William G. Westmoreland to retain his military retirement pay if elected Governor of South Carolina.
Pepsico, Inc., has signed an agreement to be the sole United States importer of a Russian champagne called Nazdorovya, the company announced yesterday.

Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell delayed today for 24 hours the issuance of a formal order reinstating John D. Ehr lichman as one of four defendants in the "plumbers" case, pending a challenge by Mr. Ehrlichman to-a crucial White House affidavit filed yesterday.
Kaneb Services, Inc., executed yesterday a letter of intent proposing to acquire the Transcontinental Oil Corporation for stock valued at $20.7-million. Terms call for 1.15
The World Bank and its affiliate, the International Development Association, approved today $81.1-million for development loans to Chad, the Philippines and Tunisia.
The National Hockey League completed its business for the season today, but, for all intents and purposes, the real business went on under the table, behind the back and out of earshot.
The first regional, nonprofit kidney center in the country was dedicated yesterday in a two-story building at 184 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, a few yards from the Grand Army Plaza.
Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the favorite, was harried and harassed for 3 hours 10 minutes on center court and incredibly beaten by Harold Solomon in the French open tennis tournament today.

In pledging to introduce legislation to prohibit corporal punishment in the state's public schools, Senator John J. Marchi is courageously facing an issue that has persistently defied all efforts at reform. Legislators, and many conservative professional educators and parents, have perpetuated the myth that rod, paddle or strap are fundamental to maintenance of school discipline.

The birth of two Siberian tigers was reported here today at Warner Bros. Jungle Habitat, where one was born May 28. The two cubs weighing about two pounds at birth were placed in an incubator, as was the previous one, to enhance their chances of survival, according to Charles C. Clift, zoological director.

A persistent, smoky threealarm fire flared yesterday in the 25-story commercial building on East 46th Street that was ripped by a gas explosion on April 22.
Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but rose slightly in the over-thecounter market. The Amex market value index closed off 0.35 at 84.63 after being up 0.33 at 1 P.M.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn. - In this age of the pill, Planned Parenthood clinics, liberated women and legalized abortion-all of which exist even in Calvinist and Catholic Connecticut-teen-age schoolgirls continue to have babies.

Pamela Galiber, the older daughter of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber of the Bronx, died suddenly yesterday apparently of a ruptured blood vessel. She was 24 years old. Because television in the Arab countries is in the early stages of its development, the American networks have run up some unusual costs in covering President Nixon's visit to the Middle East, most of them related to relaying the television picture.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 218.9 from 219.8 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 171.3 on June 12, 1973.
At least two patients have died from faulty heart pacemakers, and the manufacturer, General Electric Company is recalling the particular model.

President Nixon announced today that President Anwar elSadat had agreed to visit the United States later this year. The announcement was the latest of several signs that the two leaders had developed a close relationship during less than two days of meetings and public ceremony.

The Government held a news conference today to charge that Israel, in the treatment of Syrian prisoners, had committed "war crimes that do not differ in their brutality from the Nazi crimes during World War II."

There are blue jeans and there are blue jeans. There's the Everybody jeans, which have a budget-conscious, global following (from Idaho potato farmers to students at the Sorbonne), a made-in-America label (usually it's Levi Strauss Co.) and a modest price tag ($10 to $15 a pair).

Four Arab guerrillas attacked a kibbutz in northern Israel today and murdered three women before being killed themselves in a gun fight with the men of the kibbutz.

Southern textile mills are involved in a mad scramble for synthetic fibers, which have been in increasingly short suply since last fall's shortage of petrochemicals, the basic building blocks for synthetics.

A boy and a girl squared off for the national marbles championship here today, and, as had been expected, the boy won-but just barely.

The Babcock Wilcox Company was awarded a letter of intent to supply a 1.2-million-kilowatt nuclear steam system and associated nuclear fuel to the Power Authority of the State of New York. The contract, valued at about $100-million, is for a nuclear power plant to be built at one of two siteseither Athens or Cementon-in Greene County, south of Albany. The plant is scheduled for completion in 1982.

State Republicans 'gathered' more than 5,000-strong and $800,000-generous last night to hear exhortations from GovernorWilson and other state candidates that they abandon any election-year pessimism.

Sholom Secunda, who achieved fame as an 8-year-old cantor and -went on to write some 60 operettas and more than 1,000 songs, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 590 Fort Washington Avenue.
Presently, there seems to be better than average angling for this time of year for medium-to-large-sized striped bass from northern New Jersey to Cape Cod and the offshore islands.

Japan's balance-of-payments deficit rose to preliminary $990-million in May from $760-million in April, the Finance Ministry announced today. Trade balance deficit also increased to $580-million in May from $379-million in April, the Ministry said.

After five years of study, the Temporary State Commission to Revise the Social Services Law came up last February with an admirable plan for basic reform of the chaotic structure that now mixes income maintenance, Medicaid and social services in wasteful confusion.
The recently elected board of Community School District 1 voted last night to remove a member of the board's minority faction on the grounds that she was not eligible for the position.

A top Soviet atomic energy official reported today that development of atomic energy was proceeding more slowly in the So vict Union than in the United States because the Russians enjoyed an abundance of other organic fuels.
A United States District Court judge ruled yesterday that the voluntary Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings of Interstate Stores, Inc., be dismissed and replaced by an involuntary Chapter X proceeding.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was elected president yesterday of United Neighborhood Houses of New York, a federation of 35 settlement houses here. He will serve a one year term.
The developer of the Suffolk Meadows quarter-horse racing complex disclosed today, that he was on the verge of abandoning the $22-million project.

The lure of World Cup soccer drew a high-spirited and diverse crowd of 9,541 to Madison Square Garden yesterday to watch a scoreless tie between Brazil and Yugoslavia on closed-circuit television from Frankfurt, West Germany.

Israel's former premier, Golda Meir, 76 years old, has been hospitalized here for a series of tests, a hospital spokesman said today. The spokesman said Mrs. Meir entered the haematology department of Hadassah Hospital and would be discharged tomorrow.

Troy, Jr. was not necessarily telling the truth, but then it hardly mattered. Everyone was satisfied, anyway.

On the green of the 446yard first hole at the West Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today, Jack Nicklaus was confronted with a 25-foot birdie putt, but his ball slid past the cup and down a slope. He was now 28 feet away on his par putt. And he missed it.

Greg Zorila of Briar Hall was a tired but happy young man today after winning the Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship for the third time. The 25-year-old Pace University graduate, who sells golf equipment throughout the metropolitan area when he's not demonstrating its proper use, defeated Peter Nisselson of Hampshire, 1 up in the 36-hole final.

A young man threatening to jump from the roof of a 15-story building at 55 West 42d Street at the height of the evening rush hour was pulled to safety by the police as thousands of spectators watched from the street.

Dr. Arnold Galambos, a specialist in internal medicine who had held staff appointments at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Mount Sinai Hospital and Postgraduate Medical School and Hospital, died yesterday in New York Hospital.

Spurred by the bombing of the Chilean consulate in West Berlin and by the, arrest of five Palestinian extremists, police in West Germany drastically tightened security today for the World Cup soccer tournament.

Mrs. Julia Woodruff, a tiny, 74-year-old woman who lives alone in a rural West Virginia hill town, turned over $5 to state officials today and was given a book of stamps worth $8 to buy tickets for buses, taxis, trains or planes.

E. B. Stahlman Jr., former executive vice president and copublisher of The Nashville Banner, died last night at his home. He was 76 years old.

The like-father-like-son adage is quite evident in New Jersey thoroughbred racing, courtesy of the Boulmetis family of Cherry Hill. A suspended United States law ficer was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of extortion and other illegal acts performed in his dities as a special agent of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

About three-quarters of the 94 patients affected by the General Electric Company's recall of a defective heart pacemaker have been notified about the possible need to change the unit, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

When The Senator returned from the Man and His World horse show in Montreal just a year ago, he was limping badly. Frank Andrea, his owner, wasn't sure that The Senator ever would enter the show ring again. But he did after a long rest,. and today he captured the open jumper, take your own line, class at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

Governor Wilson signed into law today a bill that provides tuition assistance of up to $1,500 for most students, whether they attend public or private colleges in the state. Students whose net taxable family income is less than $2,000 a year would be eligible, for the maximum award. Scaled-down awards would be given to students whose net family income was more than $2,000, with the minimum payment,for students whose family income was $20,000 a year.

A powerful phenomenon has begun to shape the cultural and political events of our time. Let us, for want of a better term, call it "news theater." By news theater, I don't mean documentary plays or theater of fact or living newspapers, but rather any histrionic proceeding that results from a collaboration between newsworthy personalities, a vast public, and the visual or print media (television, films, book publishing, magazines and newspapers).

They were larger during the Indian wars in the valley below. And by the time the highway was built, many were mature pines, their fibers tough and strong-and unused.

For the first time in the 96-year history of the high school Regents examinations, New York's State Department of Education has canceled four statewide tests and postponed two others: It found that the answer sheets had been stolen and thousands of copies were being sold in the metropolitan area for $20 to $40 a test.

To the Financial Editor: In a recent article Edwin L. Dale Jr. argues against proposed changes in the tax law to neutralize the impact of inflation on the individual's tax bracket and the tax bill he pays ("Inflation's Tax Trap," May 15).

The body of a 44-year-old police officer assigned to the harbor unit was taken from the water near Battery Park yesterday after he apparently drowned. The police identified the officer as Thomas Eide, a 19-year veteran of the force who had been assigned to the harbor unit since 1962.

JERSEY CITY--With the Election of Bernard Hartnett Jr. as the new chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization, a campaign begun by his father 25 years ago has finally been completed. The objective was to topple the boss-ridden machine created by the late Mayor Frank Hague.

ON THE surface, it would appear that there were some solid reasons for optimism in the business world these days. The American economy has definitely been improving since its rather disastrous first quarter. Food prices have declined in recent weeks.

A House bill on Federal regulation of strip mining moved toward a vote this week with a leading advocate acknowledging the bill was in trouble and a leading opponent offering his office as lobbying headquarters against the measure.
When Arnold Palmer went for the 18th green today in the United States Open, he used a No. 3-iron following a fine tee shot.

Dissident employes of Harper' Row, where. a strike is planned for Monday, have begun efforts to get buyers to boycott the company's books, an official of the Association of Harper Row Employes said yesterday.

This year's college graduate seeking a teaching job will find the opportunities scarce. "At this point I have absolutely no prospects for a job, said Cheryl Walker, a graduating senior at Rhode Island College majoring in teaching high school English.
TRENTON-The season for agricultural fairs in New Jersey got under way this weekend with the Union County 4-H event in Union. That fair opened on Friday and will conclude today.

June 15-Bobby Jones sank a 12-foot putt at the 72d hole of the 1929 United States Open to tie Al Espinosa and force a title playoff that Jones won at Winged Foot Golf Club, where the 74th Open is being held this week.

THE 20 NATIONS negotiating monetary reform reached an eight-point agreement. It sets up a facility for lending to nations affected by rising energy costs and establishes rules for managing floating currencies . . . The Group of 10 agreed on the use of gold as collateral for government borrowing.

The last 12 months have been a chastening experience for the golden boys of American business, particularly those who tied their fortunes to the comet of growth. Inflation, recession, Watergate, uneven economic controls and a bearish stock market have becalmed them in unfamiliar waters.

Half the judgments won in Small Claims Courts here go unpaid because businesses refuse to pay or because some consumers cannot afford the fees to employ city marshals to act in their behalf, according to testimony at a hearing last week.

Miss Magalen Ohrstrom Crane, daughter of William Carey Crane Jr. of Barataria, Riverside, Conn., and Mrs. John Carlyle Herbert Bryant of Locust Hill, Middleburg, Va., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to James Frederick Webert, son of Mrs. James Frederick Webert of Lincoln, Neb., and the late Mr. Webert.
Miss Ava Marie Ottman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Ottman, was married yesterday afternoon to Luther Earle Birdzell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdzell Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgement of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

The late Pierre Teilhard de Chardin and the two Berrigan brothers, Daniel and Philip, have much in common. All three, Roman Catholic priests and, more specifically, members of .religious orders, took their religion seriously in a traditional sense but-saw consequences of their faith that brought them into conflict with their religious superiors

Participants in the annual summer sport of "pick-yourown" have begun to dot Long Island's strawberry patches. Backaches and stained fingers notwithstanding, there is considerable satisfaction in plucking the ripe berries right from the plants.
As the 60-day extension for President Nixon to file his 1973 Federal income tax return expired today, his accountant said the return had been filed within the last several weeks.

Ten men, including a middle-aged businessman and a veteran, and three women, all licensed practical nurses in their 60's, received their associate degrees in nursing last week, along with 180 other graduates, at Queensborough Community College in Bayside.

Thirty years of editing a little mag, almost as surreptitiously for its public reach as samizdat, may not entitle one to special privileges of generalization; but it should provide some vantage point of view. At the age of 67, Norton Simon is a brooding figure on the American business scene, a would-be messiah of industry and the arts, who moves circuitously and always draws controversy with one grandiose gesture or another.
TRENTON--State prison officials are reportedly considering the adoption of a program under which inmates would be allowed to "contract" for their release-at a promised and preset date.

National Hot Rod Association match races for fuel dragsters, funny cars and pro stocks at Madison Township Raceway Park Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J. Class runoffs at 6 P.M., racing at 8. Information: phone (201)--446-6331.

The statewide Regents examination in geometry scheduled for today was canceled last night by the State Education Department, the fifth test canceled because the answers had been obtained by students and were being widely sold throughout the state.

Sweeping change in the international economic system to attain maximum trade freedom and cooperation by all countries on monetary, oil, resources and development. issues has been urged in a joint statement by American and Japanese business, leaders.

White House efforts on behalf of President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign included an extensive plan to politicize programs to aid the elderly, according to a Senate Watergate committee staff report.

If Arnold Schoenberg were alive in this 100th anniversary year of his birth, he might have been depressed by the size of the turnout for the New York Philharmonic's chamber concert of his music Saturday night in its "Rug" series at Avery Fisher Hall.

Scientists have discovered a way of taking living cells apart and putting them back together again in ways that may reveal some of the secrets of aging, of cancer and of some of the most fundamental processes of life.

King Hussein of Jordan is apprehensive that his claim to the West Bank.of the Jordan River and East Jerusalem will be set aside in a Middle Eastern peace settlement, and that is the major issue that Jordanian officials are expected to raise with President Nixon when he visits Amman Monday.
The wife of a pilot who suffered a fatal heart seizure at the controls of his single-engine plane safely crash-landed the craft here yesterday.

Dr. Lynne Gradinger and Dr. Andrew Besen were married yesterday evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Edward T. Sandrow, rabbi emeritus of the temple, performed the ceremony. Rabbi Kalman Max and Cantor Samuel Dubrow assisted.

Senator John Sparkman, who is scheduled to be the next chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says his jbb will be to support Presidential policy and follow the majority will of committee members.

The Rev. Dr. Howard A. Johnson, who served as the canon theologian of the Cathedral Church of St. John. the Divine from 1954 to 1966, was found dead Wednesday in his Long Beach, Calif., apartment, where he lived alone. He was 58 years old.
Sardinians, who feel apart from other Italians in more ways than just geographically, went to the polls today in the knowledge that the entire nation is tensely watching.

Like rubies on a jeweler's tray, the strawberries, thousands of them in open boxes, sparkled in the sunshine. And in less than three hours at the Mattituck Strawberry Festival here yesterday afternoon, the entire stock of 3,000 quarts was sold out.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, head of the Soviet t Communist party, predicted today that "good new agreements" that would please both the Soviet and the American public would be reached during President Nixon's visit here late this month.
Candidates backed by the United Federation of Teachers have won five of nine seats in a court-ordered election held last Tuesday for the District 5 Community School Board in Harlem.
The Cleveland Nets, paced by Mrs. Nancy Gunter and her brother, Cliff Richey, swept all five sets for a 31-17 World Team Tennis victory over the New York Sets tonight.

State and Federal agencies are investigating the possibility that three lawyers representing defendants in criminal cases linked to organized crime may have been the victims of illegal bugging by Federal agents.

The city's 14 housing projects, plagued by rising crime and lacking a housing-police force, are now being patrolled by an unarmed federally financed unit aimed at deterring muggings, break-ins and vandalism.

Watergate is two years old tomorrow. It was on June 17, 1972, that the Washington police, guns drawn confronted five burglars inside the sixth-floor offices of the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate office building.
A Soviet diplomat is sched-uled to make an unusual court appearance here as a prosecution witness against two New York City youths accused of assaulting him last year.
The second tangle between Reggie Jackson and Bill North in less than two weeks, this one on the field, led to the Yankees' 5-3 victory over the Oakland A's today.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Ellen Roth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis B. Roth of New York, to Thomas Frederick Remington 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Remington Jr of Pittsburgh, took place yesterday in New Haven. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University.

The domestic aluminum industry shipped a record high $14.56-billion pounds in 1973, the Aluminum Association reported over the weekend. This was 20.8 per cent ahead of the previous high of 12.05-billion pounds shipped in 1972.

Five years ago Ryoko Ozawa was, outwardly at least, a typical Japanese housewife. Then she suddenly divorced her husband, left her two children, and ran for a seat on the City Council of the Tokyo suburb where she lives.

The Uruguayan Government was accused today of torturing political prisoners to extfact confessions. The charge was made by Amnesty International and the International Commission of Jurists after representatives of the two private organizations made a joint visit to Uruguay last month.
The Presbyterian Church in the United States elected today the first black moderator in the 113-year history of the largely Soutnern denomination

Five Southern California players were named to the 1974 college world series alltournament team last night. With the exception of Bert Newman of Southern Illinois, a designated hitter, and Tom Ball of Texas, an outfielder, the 11-man team was composed of players from the two teams that battled for the championship-Southern California and Miami.

When Representative John F. Seiberling emerged the other afternoon from a long, closed hearing. of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry, the inevitable horde of reporters surrounded him, pressing to find out what had happened.

Dr. George Sheehan, a 55-year-old cardiologist, runs the roads of this town one hour a day, six days a week and has been doing it for almost 12 years now. He does some of his best thinking when he's running. On Tuesday, for instance, he writes his weekly newspaper column for the Red Bank Register while he's running. On other days, he does medical research.

The United States Open golf championship produced the highest scoring in more than a decade. Hale Irwin's winning score of 287 was seven strokes over par, and marked the first time since 1972 that any tournament on the American tour had been won with a score over par.

More than a year after the United States Supreme Court declared that abortion should be considered a private matter between a woman and her physician, a strong campaign is on to make it a public matter between a woman and the Federal Government.

President Nixon and President Hafez al-Assad announced today the resumption of diploinatic relations between the United States and Syria. The announcement was made as the two leaders stood outside the presidential palace near the end of Mr. Nixon's visit to this ancient capital.

The State Education Department said last night that answers for today's geometry and tomorrow's comprehensive history Regents examinations were being circulated and that some of the answers were genuine. But it said both tests would be given as scheduled.

Minority construction companies, traditionally restricted to small jobs valued at $100,000 or less, began to realize an upward trend in their business during 1972 and 1973. The strong minority opportunity programs adopted by several public agencies here and community group pressure on established builders were beginning to have an impact.

Howard J. Samuels, Democratic State Committee designee for Governor, said yesterday that he would meet a variety of leaders in the next few days to explore a course on the party's statewide primary contests.

A bitter squabble involving leading figures in the Government and private industry has interrupted Britain's leisurely journey into summer, just as the country was growing accustomed to a surprisingly peaceful hiatus between national elections.
Richard Petty defeated David Pearson in the Motor State 400 today, as stock car racing's biggest money winners staged a head-to-head duel before 51,500spectators.

Youth will be served. Chris Evert, 19 years old, won the French open today, and Bjorn Borg, 18, in one of the great tennis turnarounds, came from two sets down to defeat Manuel Orantes of Spain, 2-6, 6-7, 6-0, 6-1, 6-1, and capture the men's title.
Matra-Simca won the 24 Hours of Le Mans for the third year in a row todayand not simply because it had the fastest cars in the race.

Mrs. Barry Lee Cohen and her daughter Leslie, who is 5 years old, were on a Madison Avenue bus the other day when a nicely dressed, middle-aged woman got on, sat down, and said that Leslie was a beautiful child indeed.

The American Shakespeare Theater is celebrating its 20th anniversary season, which makes it one of the oldest theatrical institutions in the country. The theater building, which is also 20 years old and an ugly place, was the very first of the new American theater buildings of the last two decades.

The Union Jack flew high over foggy Newport today as Britain's three-boat team of Noryema, Oyster and Marionette won the first race, the Astor Trophy, in the Onion Patch team series.

There were 18,700 more jobs in New York City in March than in February, but the total still was 37,000 lower than in March, 1973, indicating a continuing decline in employment here that is puzzling economists and city officials.

Miss Carol Ann Schapiro, a a child-development specialist at New York Medical College, was married yesterday in Pikesville, Md., to Sidney A. Bludman, professor of physics at the University of Pennsylvania.

The major petroleum exporting countries rejected an appeal today by the European Economic Community against new taxes on oil exports and adjourned their session until tomorrow without announcing a final decision on oil prices and taxes.

Frederic E. Lake, a conservationist and former art dealer, died Friday of a heart attack at a meeting of the Springs Improvement Society in East Hampton, L. I., where he had been a speaker. He was 70 years old and lived in East Hampton.

The only remarkable attribute of the singing telegram Is that it lasted for forty years before joining the nation's cluttered attic of obsolete gimmicks. This small stilled voice will leave no void in the lives of most Americans. The most relevant melody to associate with Western Union today would be a funeral dirge in memory of its once basic service- the telegram itself.

Savings and loan associations may issue negotiable certificates of deposit of $100,000 or more,, Thomas R. Bomar, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced over the weekend.

A member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist party has been attacked by name for the first time in the wall poster campaign here. Hua Kuo-feng of Hunan province in central China, who became a member of the politburo last August, was attacked in a poster that a young woman from Hunan pasted up on a wall opposite the headquarters of the Peking city authorities.

A Greek Cypriote was killed and two were critically wounded by gunmen early today in a resurgence of guerrilla violence in Cyprus. The police attributed the shootings to the EOKA-B guerrilla movement formed by the late Gen. George Grivas to campaign for enosis, or union with Greece.

Stonewalk finished second in the Jersey Derby and won the Gotham.

Four separate fires killed a Harlem and a Connecticut resident and heavily damaged a Queens church and a Brooklyn warehouse yesterday morning, fire authorities reported. The Harlem man, tentatively identified as James Hall, died when he jumped from the fireengulfed top floor of a six-story apartment building at 52 East 132d Street, between Madison and Park Avenues.

The search for the 63foot yacht Shooting Star with 10 passengers aboard achieved its first results today when a sailboat and a dinghy, two small craft known to be carried by the missing vessel, were found in waters off the Mexican coast.

At Central Synagogue yesterday afternoon, Miss Lois Marcus, a 1974 graduate of Vassar College, was married to Andrew David Traub, who graduated cum laude this year from Harvard College. Rabbi David S. Seligson performed the ceremony.
Israel showered President Nixon with praise and cheers this afternoon when he arrived fresh from conferences with Arab leaders in three countries.

Rain was slowing to a stop while Buddy Allin, smallest of the survivors in the last round of the United States Open, waited to tee off at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. Scores of 76, 71 and 74 had left him comparatively little chance to overtake the leaders, but,with his 221 for 54 holes he coulld look forward to a respectable slice of 'the $225,000 purse.

Parades and other traffic obstacles also contribute to another urban indignity--the excessive use of the automobile horn. Noise pollution is a serious affront to city dwellers. While there is no practical way of making New York's streets idylls of serenity, neither is there any excuse for allowing a flagrant and unnecessary assault on the population's ears and nerves.

After deliberating for more than a year, a group of employes from the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation who serve as the conscience for their company's $10-million pension and retirement fund, have sold 2,350 shares of stock in the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.
No pitcher has won the Cy Young Award two years in a row since Dennis McLain turned the trick in 1968 and 1969, and last year's winners--Tom Seaver and Jim Palmer-aren't likely to repeat.
Paul Parker stepped from beneath the Cromartie Funeral Home canopy and walked across the flatbed truck that served as the stage for the sixth annual National Hollerin' Contest.
Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said that France apparently exploded a nuclear device in the atmosphere southwest of Tahiti early today. He termed it "regrettable."

Governor Byrne, in a green blazer, checkered pants, white bucks and a club tie, met complaining letterwriters at an informal session on the lawn of Morven today to explain his proposal for a state income tax.

To the Editor: I write to call your attention to the massive damage which is being inflicted on the U.S. economy by the injudicious action of the Nixon Administration in ending controls on dollar outflows, including the interest-equalization tax and a banking industry credit-restraint program in late January.

True to tradition and Republican predictions, New York Democrats staged a tempestuous convention at Niagara Falls last week, leaving a litter of broken hopes, bruised egos and bitter memories. The convention also left unresolved the party's final choice for most state offices, virtually guaranteeing the long hot summer of Democratic in-fighting that the Republican-controlled legislature gleefully anticipated when it switched the primary date from June to September.

Connecticut lawmakers return to Hartford today for a one-day legislative session to vote on whether to override Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's vetoes of bills passed in the regular session. Majority Republican leaders predict that as many as half of the vetoes might be overridden at the so-called "trailer" session required by state law.

Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, sees no danger that curtailed operations by a troubled cattle industry will cause any shortage of beef for consumers. Commenting on a new report showing that cattle feeders were fattening fewer steers for market. the Secretary said:

Miss Elizabeth Fain was married in Providence, R. I., yesterday to Samuel Gerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Gerson of Natanya, Israel, and New York. Rabbis William Braude and Hershel Schacter performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Irvine J. Fain.

A bill reportedly signed by Governor Wilson has persuaded Harry B. Helmsley, one of the largest real estate operators in the country to "defer" plans for converting part of Tudor City into condominiums, a spokesman. for Helmsley-Spear, Inc., confirmed last night.
Hale Irwin's victory in the United States Open golf championship today could mean the start of a college education for the boy who carried his bags, 16-year-old Peter McGarey of Scottsdale, Ariz.

A reputed organized-crime figure who has been in jail since refusing to testify before the State Commission of Investigation has filed suit against the bottler of a soft drink that his wife drank before dying of arsenic poisoning.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

African delegates said that actions taken by the Organization of African Unity conference, which ended here today, were intended to give Portugal "the widest possible latitude in sorting out her colonial problems."
According to the police, a 62-year-old Bronx man shot and killed his 31-year-old son during an argument over a money debt. The slaying occurred on a street corner in the Tremont section.
At 11:20 Tuesday morning, Adelphia T. was one of a dozen or so men chatting, laughing and cavorting around two benches in Roosevelt Park at 81st Street and CoOlumbus Avenue.

President Nixon and President Hafez alAssad of Syria announced in Damascus the restoration of diplomatic relations between their countries, which were broken off during the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. They said that this was a first step toward establishing lasting peace in the Middle East. [1:8.]

Action by Trenton State Prison authorities to recall a highly motivated inmate from a rehabilitative college program just short of his graduation has strained relations between the prison and Trenton State College. It may have jeopardized the program throughout the state.

Morgan Wing Jr., a past president of the National Beagle Club, died Saturday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and a lifelong resident of Millbrook, N.Y., where he was Master of the Hunt of the Sandanona Beagles.
Martha Waite's husband used to explain the controls on the family's single-engine plane when they were aloft. He even let her fly the plane occasionally. But she had never landed the craft.
A study of 125 of the nation's largest urban areas shows a wide disparity in their Federal tax burdens, the Tax Foundation said yesterday.

In the crisis world of heavyweight boxing, where every big fight is supposed to signal the start or end of someone's career but seldom does, Joe Frazier and Jerry Quarry will put their show on the crossroad tonight.

Starting on Monday, July 1, the International Monetary Fund will begin making a daily set of calculations that will officially tell all of the leading trading countries in the world exactly how much their currency is worth in a world of floating exchange rates. The United Farm Workers of America dedicated the nation's first retirement village for farm workers yesterday in this arid town, which has been the focal point of the union's struggle to organize the nation's farm workers.

Dave Winfield, who had homered in the sixth inning, drove in the winning run with a single in the 13th today to give the San Diego Padres a 7-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The Padres had trailed atone point, 5 0.

This city's two Presbyterian churches are for sale-$700,000 each, including parish houses, frees, roiling lawns, the works. A brochure calls it "an opportunity for building developer or industry."
All roads lead this week to Wimbledon, the world's most celebrated tournament staged at the All-England Club in the suburbs of London.
An arbitrator's decision has averted a mass exodus of Public Schools Athletic League coaches.

In its pending bid for electric rate increases, the Consolidated Edison Company submitted calculations yesterday indicating that small-home and office-building customers had been paying less than their share of service costs while businesses and apartment buildings had paid more.
The Mobil Oil Corporation, the nation's third largest oil company, is discussing with the Marcor Corporation a tender offer under which it would seek 51 per cent of Marcor's stock.
Monetary policy must be the primary strategic weapon to control inflation, James J. O'Leary, vice chairman of the United States Trust Company of New York. said yesterday.
In spite of all their natural color, rhythm and soccer experience, the South American teams have found themselves in a collective gloom in this year's World Cup extravaganza.
Japan's shipbuilding industry, the largest in the world, is losing its competitive power because of the inflation that has hit the country.
The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that states can deny disability benefits to women incapacitated by normal pregnancy without committing unconstitutional discrimination.

A 17-year-old member of the Jewish Defense League was convicted in Federal District Court yesterday of assaulting a Soviet diplomat on the testimony of the official who testified as a United States Government witness.

In a report submitted today to the Senate Judiciary Committee, the American Civil Liberties Union sought to show that the Nixon Administration had subverted the Federal justice system to its own purposes as part of the Watergate coverup.
While her husband held political talks with Israeli leaders in Jerusalem this morning, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon visited a kibbutz here and the repository of the Dead Sea Scrolls.

A 27-year-old man with a long police record held his common-law wife hostage at gunpoint in their' Queens garden-apartment for more than five hours yesterday, but surrendered peacefully last night to members of the Police Department's hostage-negotiation unit.

Exxon U.S.A. filed suit today in United States district court here requesting relief from a Federal Energy Office regulation requiring the company to sell 130,000 barrels of crude oil a day to other refiners. Exxon said certain aspects of the F.E.O.'s mandatory crude allocation program were discriminatory and forced it to sell "an unfair share of crude oil to other refiners."
Trading in commodity futures contracts continued at a record pace for the period for January through May, according to a report issued by the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms.
The French Government maintained official secrecy today on its current series of nuclear tests in the atmosphere in the South Pacific amid protests from Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Japan.

Births among groups that traditionally have had the nation's highest fertility rates--the poor, blacks, American Indians and Mexican-Americans-have declined more rapidly since the nineteen-sixties than births among whites and more affluent Americans, two new studies have shown.

Joe Frazier came out smoking last night and Jerry Quarry had nothing to put out the fire. With a savage burst of fury fueled by pride and the desire to prove his championship fiber, Frazier pummeled the Californian into submission at 1 minute 37 seconds of the fifth round.
Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's former personal lawyer, was sentenced today to six to 18 months in prison and fined $10,000 for illegal fundraising activities on behalf of the White House.
The effort of liberal Democrats to attach a $6-billion tax reduction and a package of tax reforms to the pending debt-ceiling bill appeared likely today to be blocked by a filibuster.

Dr. Clyde O. Fisher, who retired in 1959 as professor of economics at Wesleyan University Middletown, Conn., died Saturday in Middletown. He was 82 years old.

Four members of a family were found slain today in the basement of their suburban home after a fire broke out, the authorities said.

Operators of the American tuna fleet have reacted angrily to reports that Washington, after years of defending their freedom of the seas, was preparing to recognize the right of any coastal nation to turn back foreign fishing boats 200 miles from its shores.

Henry Aaron led the Atlanta Braves into town last night for the first time since he became the ranking homerun hitter in baseball, drew a standing ovation from a crowd of 35,994 persons in Shea Stadium and reflected on the clamor of it all.
A Brooklyn Congressional district that had been reapportioned under a Justice Department order so that a black could be elected will instead very likely have a white representative.
The Rev. Dr. Mills J. Taylor, associate secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Presbyterian Church from 1918 to 1948, died Saturday in Drexel Hill, Pa.

Stock prices continued to decline along a broad front for the second consecutive session yesterday. Trading was light as the absence of favorable economic news kept many investors on the sidelines.

A Jersey City couple were shot to death in their apartment early yesterday. The woman's former husband, a Bronx man, was taken into custody at the scene with a loaded revolver in his hand, the police reported.

Frank DeMarco Jr., the tax lawyer who was accused of backdating documents that gave President Nixon a big tax deduction for his donation of pre-Presidential papers, has resigned his state notary commission.
Four women climbers, two New Zealanders and two Indoians, who were lost in an avalanche in the Himalayas more than two weeks ago, are believed dead, a leader of the expedition said today.

The defense in the trial of four Sunni Muslims charged with murder, kidnapping and robbery at a Brooklyn sporting goods store in January, 1973, portrayed its clients yesterday as formerly peaceful men who had tried to steal guns because they feared for their lives.

The chief United States negotiator on the law of the seas said today that nations seeking to work out a treaty governing the oceans faced tough political choices, but he expressed the belief that they would make those choices to "avoid escalating conflict."

A fire in downtown Lahore, the capital of Punjab Province, killed at least 40 people today, according to reports reaching here. The blaze gutted an entire building and six families were killed, the report said.

President Nixon today concluded a 26-hour visit here in which ?? assured Israel of long-term military and economic assistance and urged the new Government to demonstrate its statesmanship by taking risks for peace.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it had received a "commitment" valued at about $500-million to supply two 626,000-kilowatt nuclear electric generating plants to the Government of the Philippines. The plants would be operated by the National Power Corporation. Westinghouse would provide over-all management for the project through its power systems projects division.

A Public Service Commission examiner has recommended that the charge for intrastate telegrams from citizens to public officials be raised from $1 to $2, and not to $3, as the commission announced last week.

A majority of the world's large oil-exporting countries announced today an increase of 2 per cent in royalties levied on Western oil companies after Saudi Arabia, the biggest exporter, had blocked an attempt to raise oil prices several dollars a barrel.

New York cultural institutions, ranging from the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Magnolia Tree Earth Center of Bedford-Stuyvesant, held a white-elephant party yesterday that turned their attic junk into treasure.

Mayor Beame yesterday dedicated the Richmond water supply project and the restoration of Silver Lake Park on Staten Island, calling the projects "two important improvements that offer something for everyone to celebrate."

Henry Aaron of the Atlanta Braves, baseball's alltime home-run king, continued to lead the voting yesterday for the National League All-Star team, the Associated Press reported. He prevented a sweep by Cincinnati and Los Angeles players who led the other seven positions open to balloting.

An effort to reduce meat prices and promote sales was promised today by supermarket spokesmen during a White House meeting of Government and food-industry officials on the plight of the nation's troubled cattle producers.
The impact of high interest rates on the financial status of real estate investment trusts that specialize in mortgage lending is reflected in statements released by the trusts in recent days.

A bomb exploded today in the most historic part of the Houses of Parliament, damaging Westminster Hall, the 900-year-old chamber that has seen. much of British history. Eleven people were injured, none seriously.

The General Assembly today overrode Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's veto of a bill providing for the erasure of all police and court records of arrests in Connecticut that resulted in acquittals, pardons, dismissals or decisions not to prosecute.

The United States team overtook England to share the lead in its preliminary section of the International Team Tournament here in the Palais des Expositions by taking a 3 1/2 1/2 victory over Ecuador.
Cambodian Government troops killed more than 100 insurgents today in fighting 11 miles north of Phnom Penh, according to reports from the field.
A trial date of Aug. 15 was set today in the perjury case of John D. Ehrlichman, the former Presidential aide. The date was set by Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Gordon Ringer.

The Ford Motor Company has agreed to stop running commericals contending that its Galaxie and LTD cars have steel reinforcements as strong as highway guard rails, or that the LTD runs quieter than a glider in flight, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
senator Gaylord Nelson, asked Congress today to appropriate $600-million for the Federal share of local sewage treatment plant construction projects started between 1966 and 1972.

Dr. Georgiana P. McEntee, professor emeritus of history at Hunter College, died Friday in River Edge, N.J., at the home of her sister, Mrs. Melita Pfiefer. She was 78 years old and lived in the Berkshire Hotel.
Puerto Rico is creating a government-owned merchant fleet, in a move that Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon hopes will hold down ocean freight rates and make the island more tempting to investors.
Aleksandr A. Galich, the Soviet song writer and poet, reported today that he had been given permission to emigrate to Israel.
The House,Judiciary Committe staff interviewed former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst today to determine whether he should be called as a witness by the panel,
When the trial of two Indian leads of the uprising at Wounded Knee opened last January, the Mississippi River was frozen from bank to bank alongside the Federal Courthouse in downtown St. Paul.

After half a century of fruitless' stalking, the National Rifle Association and other "sports" who get their kicks out of killing small animals have finally drawn a bead on Congress in what could be a disastrous game hunt. The House has quietly passed an innocuous-appearing bill that purports "to extend and expand the authority for carrying out conservation and rehabilitation programs" on military reservations and other public lands.
Some 25,000 postal workers began a nationwide strike today in defiance of Government efforts to end the social agitation that has become almost chronic here since the military coup April 25.

A United Nations commission investigating reports of atrocities by Portuguese troops in Mozambique has concluded provisionally that a massacre took place at Wiryamu in 1971, reliable sources said today.
Roger Hane, 36-year-old magazine illustrator, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital of injuries suffered Friday evening when he was beaten and robbed of his new bicycle in Central Park.

Less than half the city's registered voters are expected to turn out tomorrow for a runoff election in which 10 candidates are seeking three at-large and two ward Council seats on the ninemember.City Council.

Tiffany Co. announced yesterday a drop in earnings in the first quarter to $221,236 from $230,117 in the period a year earlier. Pershare earnings remained at 10 cents. Walter Hoving, Tiffany's chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting held in the St. Regis Hotel

" My granddaughter calls me 'Mr. Chairman' now," Peter W. Rodino Jr. said with a raspy laugh and a quick grimace. But he seems to prize "granddaddy" more than "Mr. Chairman" when it comes from Carla, his brown-eyed, 7-year-old granddaughter.

The United States flag was raised at the American Interests Section of the Italian Embassy here today and by the time it reached the top of the staff the building had become, once again, the Embassy of the United States of America.
The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that states can deny disability benefits to women incapacitated by normal pregnancy without committing unconstitutional discrimination.

A new Luxembourg coalition has been formed, with Gaston Thorn, the Foreign Minister in the outgoing Cabinet, as both Premier and Foreign Minister. Mr. Thorn's centrist Democratic party and the Socialists agreed over the weekend to join in forming the cabinet.
To the Editor: In a June 5 editorial, The Times describes the Mansfield amendment to. withdraw troops from Europe as "the wrong battle in the wrong place at the wrong time."

Eighteen Senators introduced amendments today that would require a Congressional review of all Export-Import Bank transactions of more than $50million and limit the Administration's ability to extend Government-backed credits to the Soviet Union.

Only gradually is the reality sinking in that burdensharing between rich and poor nations is not merely a moral imperative or humanitarian preoccupation of idle dreamers; it is the only means of insuring survival of the world economic order.
Edith O'Keefe Susong, publisher of The Greeneville, Daily Sun for more than 50 years, died today. She was 84 years old and was the widow of David Susong.
More than 1,000 union delegates met with hospital and nursing home administrators around the city yesterday as both sides awaited the naming of a panel to break a deadlock in contract negotiations.

A former police lieutenant accused of seizing money from drug suspects testified yesterday in Federal court that he had kept his cash in a little wooden box.

After several hours of paradoxical testimony from landlord and tenant representatives, the City Council's General Welfare Committee voted unanimously yesterday to make the state's new apartment-rent-stabilization law effective in New York City.

With the World Cup soccer matches under way in stadiums across the country, the West Germans, favored to win the championship, are in a fervor that pushes their bitter political squabbles to the sidelines.
The largest of 15 unions facing contract negotiations this year with the nation's railroads said today that it would demand a 35 per cent wage increase.

Seenator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, issued a terse statement yesterday in response to widespread published reports that Senate investigators were looking into the financially troubled Franklin National Bank.
Harvard University has been awarded a grant of almost $200,000 to continue a study for the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services.

KYRENIA, Cyprus--About 2,200 years ago a merchant ship set off on a journey through the eastern Mediterranean, stopping at such islands as Samos, Kos and Rhodes, trading in oil and wine, millstones and almonds.
Gaylord Perry of the Cleveland Indians won his 12th straight game, beating the Chicago White Sox, 4-3, tonight. Jack Brohamer's runscoring single in the ninth inning provided the victory margin.
Mrs. Lucy M. Vaden, a member of the second Watergate grand jury, has been suspended and is under grand jury investigation regarding allegations of fraud, according. to sources.

Cutlass of the Powhatan Stable won the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday, to the mild surprise of the crowd of 18,562. The surprise rested on the fact that the Cragwood At the Stable's Halo, the odds-on favorite, not only finished Tracks third in the field of seven, but was the subject of a stewards' inquiry which ultimately caused him to be placed last.
If a shop owner had been murdered during a robbery in New York City, the incident would probably have resulted in fear and concern among other shopkeepers and residents in the area.
Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the immediate dismissal of James D. Norton, acting director of the city's Bureau of Labor Services, who had been under investigation for misuse of official funds.
A series of free concerts will be presented on five Wednesday in the Lincoln Center Midday Miniconcerts beginning at 12:30 on June 26.

A crowd of 2,800 persons paying from $3 to $50 a ticket, filled Carnegie Hall to capacity last night to help start a nationwide campaign to clear the names of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg ,the couple executed in 1953 for conspiring to pass atomic secrets to the Soviet Union.
A member of the Paterson board that controls liquor licenses was charged today by the Passaic County grand jury with attempted extortion and misconduct in office.
A Brooklyn congressional district that had been reapportioned under a Justice Department order so that a black could be elected will instead very likely have a white Representative.

Organized labor, and New Jersey's public school teachers in particular, won a major victory in the Legislature today when the Senate gave initial approval to a series of amendments that would commit the labor disputes of all public employes to collective bargaining.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld today its order revoking the $1,000 bail of former Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.,

The make-up of the New Jersey State Fish and Game Council as it is currently constituted is unconstitutional, a Passaic Superior Court judge ruled yesterday. In the case of the Humane Society v. the New Jersey State Fish and Game Council, Judge Peter Ciolino handed down a 10-page decision stating that the council could no longer limit the selection of its members to sportsmen, farmers and commercial fishermen as it had in the past.

The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its March meeting both to allow short-term interest rates to rise and to permit the nation's money supply to expand somewhat faster than its long-term target called for, it was disclosed today.
A State Supreme Court justice found yesterday that the conversion of an East Side apartment building into a cooperative had involved "fraudulent practices," but he declined to annul the co-op plan.

Mrs. Marilyn Aschner Rachleff, the East's No. 1 player from Kings Point, L.I., advanced to the fourth round of the Eastern women's claycourt tennis championship today with a 6-1, 6-0 rout of Louise Stolitsky of Great Neck, L.1.
At least 200 of the 600 New York-based employes of Harper Row went on strike yesterday in the first major labor dispute in recent book publishing history.

Driven out by racism and lack of economic opportunity, Southern blacks have been migrating North in huge numbers for more than a century, riding the Illinois Central, the Greyhound and the old family Ford toward the promise of Chicago's South Side and New York's Harlem.
Warren H. Weisz, president of the Clinton Mills Sales Corporation, died Monday in Doctors Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 2727 Palisade Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx.
Yields on three-month and six-month United States Treasury bills were lower today in the Government's weekly competitive sale of these short-term securities.

A surprise party was held here a few nights ago for Dr. Richard A. Patt, with 130 friends present to say good-by to the man who has spent the last two years as a family physician in this rural community while a member of the National Health Service Corns.
President Nixon received another warm ovation today when he arrived here from Israel on the last leg of his Middle Eastern trip.
The strains of John Philip Sousa's "Washington Post March" welcomed President Nixon to Jordan today.

Selma Gubin, an artist, whose work included portraits, landscapes and still lifes, died yesterday at her home here. She was 71 years old.

Evening dresses are somehow beyond the day-to-day fashion scramble. There's a laissez-faire attitude toward lengths. As for shapes, the more they reveal about the wearer's own shape, the more successful they are.
Irving J. Kurz, a retired trial lawyer, died yesterday in the Florence Nightingale Home. He was 82 years old and lived at 68-36 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

Since there is no stopping a golfer, even a slightly disappointed one, Forrest Fezler was on the links for another round today. The 24-year-old runner-up in the United States Open said. "I was thinking of yesterday on every shot today."

The chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee on Acupuncture of the National Institutes of Health says that the widespread clinical use of acupuncture in the United States is unwarranted pending further study.

The California Angels found out tonight it's not easy to hold down the rampaging Yankees for long. Shut out on four singles by Frank Tanana through the first six innings, the Yankees exploded for a 5-1 decision and their seventh victory in the last nine games.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that there was a possibility that an agreement in principle to limit the deployment of new Soviet missiles 'with multiple warheads might be reached during President Nixon's visit to Moscow next week.

The State Senate passed today a controversial bill that would prohibit the use of Medicaid funds for elective abortions. The vote, 23 to 13, came after 20 minutes of debate during which opponents of the measure contended that it would discriminate against the poor and was unconstitutional.

China conducted a relatively large nuclear test early today, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced. The commission said the explosion took place in the atmosphere at about 2 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time, at the test range in northwestern China.

The hottest socio-economic story of the moment is the coming crash and the end of civilization as we have known it. The magazines are filling up with pieces on the coming depression. The gold bugs are warning of a great crash that will wipe out all paper money and stock values.
William H. Ogden, a former president of the New York Water Service Corporation, died yesterday in Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L. I. He was 68 years old and lived at 38 Thompson Park, Glen Cove.

Sunny skies are forecast for the Metropolitan area today and for the Northeast, although a few showers are expected in northern New England. Thundershowers will be scattered throughout the northwest Plains States and the lower Mississippi Valley.

PHILADELPHIA - Few Americans know that there is a precedent in recent history for our energy crisis. Furthermore, the reactions then were remarkably similar to proposals that have been made in response to ours. The ultimate outcome of the earlier crisis and the response to it were unfortunate; it is hoped that a similar situation can be avoided now.

Kenneth Rush, President Nixon's counselor for economic policy, declined an invitation last week to go up to Capitol Hill to testify before the Joint Economic Committee on the President's mid-year economic report. The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline for the second month in a row, according to figures released yesterday by the exchange.

Representatives of almost all the world's countries convened the largest international conference in history here today, a summer-long meeting to draft a treaty that would govern man's use of the oceans.

A former student at Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22 in the Bronx charged yesterday that she had been hit once with a wooden paddle by the school's principal and that later she had been made to sign a statement that this had never happened.

A wave of relief swept through the harried magazine industry with the news that the Senate bill to delay scheduled postal increases had passed in the House and has been sent to the President. A Reuters dispatch noted yesterday that by extending the current increases from five to eight years, the bill if signed, will save the publishing industry $764-million.

A puppet named Funston Frog playfully nipped Mayor Beame yesterday and marked the official commencement of a 1,233-event summer entertainment program for the city.
The Public, Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company an interim electric-rate increase of $28.7-million a year, effective July 1.

The Franklin National Bank disclosed yesterday that it lost $63.6-million in the first five months of the year-some $25million more than the bank indicated when its troubles first became public six weeks ago.

Six weeks away from Watergate seem to have made no difference at all. Like Old Man River, it just keeps rolling along. Like a river, too, it keeps eating away at its own banks until it appears as if everyone and everything in the vicinity may ultimately be engulfed.

PHILADELPHIA-With a great deal of sorrow, I must criticize my fellow prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, for the manner in which he is conducting the investigations and prosecutions arising out of the Watergate and other sordid affairs.
A legislative revenue plan relying heavily on a statewide property tax on corporate and commercial ratables was proposed here today as the second alternative to Governor Byrne's proposed income tax.

The New York Mets began the long road back tonight. Pressure pitching by Jerry Roosman, plus a reliable outfield, gave the last-place New Yorkers a 2-1 victory over the Eastern Division-leading Philadelphia Phillies,

The intensive Israeli air strikes into Lebanon today were carried out in accordance with a new policy of vigorous pre-emptive attacks against the Palestinian guerrilla organizations, Government sources said.

The Soviet Union today signed a $200-million contract with the Chemical Construction Corporation, an American company, to construct four large ammonia plants on the Volga River. The order was decribed as the largest single Soviet contract awarded thus far for American industrial technology.

Six day of "old-fashioned detective work" culminated yes terday in the arrest of six youths in the murder of Roger Hane, the magazine illustrator who was fatally beaten by bicycle thieves last week as he rode in Central Park. Detective Joseph O'Donnell telling how he and others traced suspects in slaying of Roger Hane.

Demand for credit by corporations at major New York City banks soared and key short-term interest rates rose sharply in the week ended Wednesday, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

GREENWICH, Conn.-Somewhere in this well-to-do Fairfield County town, a middle-aged man picked up a telephone the other night, dialed 661-HELP and sought advice about venereal disease from a volunteer young enough to be his son.
Alvah K. Parent, a lawyer here for 50 years, died Wednesday at his home here, 7 Peter Cooper Road. He was 76 years old.
President Nixon briefed Congressional leaders today on his Middle Eastern trip and assured them that he had reached no secret agreements or understandings with Arab or Israeli leaders.

Premier Mariano Rumor and his ministers started tackling Italy's pressing financial problems today after a 10-day Government crisis that many critics termed a waste of time and energies.

At dawn New York's Greenwich Village is reminiscent of Paris in spring, and each morning I used to stroll leisurely through its picturesque streets. Few people were about and the air--without the exhaust fumes--was exhilarating to inhale.

Home runs by Jose Cardenal and Billy Williams led the Chicago Cubs to a 3-0 triumph over Pittsburgh today, ending the Pirates' victory string at six games.

Reorganization of the Federal structure to place all programs dealing with food policy in one agency was proposed today in a report by a panel of specialists to the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs.

A paraplegic motorist was beaten, robbed of his car, money and a watch yesterday by a hitchhiker he had picked up in Babylon, L.I. A suspect was arrested after the police spotted him near the car, a few blocks from the scene of the robbery.

The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has proposed to the nine members of the trade bloc that they substantially increase the generalized trade preferences on industrial goods imported from developing countries.
A Federal judge today ?? in half the one-year prison sentence imposed on Larry. Williams, former fund-raiser for Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida.

The Association'of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18 billion ton-miles, 4.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

A projected "new order" for professional basketball crumbled on all fronts yesterday when National Basketball Association club owners rejected a proposed modification of the players contract which would have cracked the reserve-option system. Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic State Committee's designee for Governor announced additional support yesterday in his bid for the party nomination in the Sept. 10 primary.

WASHINGTON -- With increasing frequency and severity, the symptoms of our nation's ailing economy have revealed themselves. Inflation for the first quarter of 1974 is at a staggering annual rate of 11.5 per cent.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz warned both exporting and importing countries today against trade practices that he said were deepening the distress of the United States cattle industry. The House of Representatives approved tonight a three-year community development and housing bill that would lump a variety of Federal housing programs under bloc grants that localities could use largely as they see fit.

Arthur Levitt, the State Controller, agreed yesterday to make a special audit of the American Ballet Theater and its parent unit, the Ballet Theater Foundation, in response to a request by the New York State Council on the Arts.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States accepted today for at least a year's study a controversial new declaration of faith that attempts to set forth doctrine in a contemporary perspective.
Continued withholding of newly harvested wheat from markets by farmers was said to be the main reason wheat futures prices gained 17 cents and more a bushel yesterday for nearby delivery.
Paul C. Matthews Sr., who retired five years ago as an Admiralty lawyer here, died Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 78 years old and formerly lived in Greenwich, Conn.
