The GL Corporation of Chicago announced yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer to buy 1.5 million shares of the common stock of the Cerro Corporation at $19 a share.

Ron Delsener came up with a pretty good set of substitutes for John Sebastian on Wednesday evening at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. Mr. Sebastian, ill in California with strep throat, will now appear in a special, added Schaefer Festival show Sept. 3.

In a move reflecting the growing size and importance of consumer protection agencies throughout the country, a national organization of state, county and city consumer officials was formed here today.

An increase in the prime interest rate by a Miami bank yesterday sent the stock market into its fifth consecutive decline in continued lethargic trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange had been mostly mixed until shortly before 2:30 P.M., when the First National Bank of Miami increased the interest rate it charges its most creditworthy corporate customers to 11 1/2 per cent from 11 1/4 per cent.

The Israel Philhramonic Orchestra decided yesterday to end its ban on the music of Richard Wagner. The German composer's works had been ruled out by the orchestra on the ground that he was an anti-Semite idolized by Hitler.

In his campaign against Senate restrictions on Soviet American trade, Secretary of State Kissinger is said to have told Senators that Moscow is prepared to issue a written guarantee to allow 45,000 Jews to emigrate each year and a statement on harassment of would-be emigrants. The Senators have reportedly called the pledge on harassment unacceptably vague.

A former supervisor of the financially troubled Franklin National Bank and an independent securities trader have pleaded guilty in Manhattan Supreme Court,to participating in a stock swindle, in which, at one point, they used $2.1million of the bank's funds to buy so-called "flashy" securities on the stock market.

The Screen Actors Guild is asking its 29,000 members for strike authorization. Ballots were sent out this week to learn whether guild members were willing to set a July 1 deadline for reaching a contract settlement without a strike.

New Jersey filed suit in Federal Court here today seeking to force the United States Environmental Protection Agency to release $752-million in water-pollution-control funds that were impounded on President Nixon's order.

The British Treasury announced today that the tax burden on foreigners residing in Britain would not be as great as originally proposed. Foreigners who have resided in Britain for nine out of 10 years will be taxed on only 75 per cent of their earnings from British employment instead of 100 per cent as originally proposed.

The Byrne administration announced today that it was setting up six regional offices to handle inquiries about the Governor's income-tax program. The first office in Trenton that was established this week handled more than 2,000 calls.

Scholars here and in Japan are raising questions about the dating and origin of many Japanese porcelains, the brilliantly decorated ceramic wares treasured for the inventiveness of their designs by museums and private collectors for decades and now being sold for tens of thousands of dollars.

The 42-nation African Lawn Tennis Confederation issued an official protest today against what it termed the imminent admission of South Africa to Davis Cuo competition. South Africa's application for Davis Cup membership is reportedly under consideration by the International Lawn Tennis Association.

The murder of a 36-year-old magazine illustrator last week while testing his new bicycle in Central Park is the most shocking of a mounting wave this year of bicycle robberies in the city's parks and streets.

Wilton Manhoff, a stage and television writer perhaps best known for his Broadway play, "The Owl and the Pussycat, died Tuesday at the age of 56. He leaves his mother and a sister.

The Police Department decided last night not to press "at this time" for the removal of a bullet lodged in the chest of a suspect in the murder of an off-duty lieutenant in Queens on Thursday.

Senator Goldwater wants The Washington Post prosecuted for printing Government information the Governmen doesn't want published. At first glance this seems like a good idea if you are one of those people who would just as soon not know what the Government is up to--and considering what it has been up to lately, only a masochist would want to be even slightly informed.

The beginning of what may be the end of a 300-year-old form of local freeholder's government in New Jersey was heatedly debated today by officials attending the annual conference of the state's Association of Chosen Freeholders.

Jim Mason (22), Yankees' shortstop, and Lou Piniella colliding in the second inning on a fly by Tigers' Ben Oglivie. Oglivie went to second base on Mason's error.

Four young Muslims were found guilty last night of murder, kidnapping, robbery and other charges growing out of the January, 1973, holdup of a Brooklyn sporting-goods store in which a policeman was killed and a dozen persons were held hostage over a three-day ordeal.

Sandra Palmer went on a birdie spree today and set a women's course record of 66, seven under par, in charging into the halfway lead in the rain-splashed $50,000 Ladies Professional Golfers' Association championship.

The race to Bermuda began today in fog as 166 yachts groped for the starting line off the Brenton Reef light tower. The breeze was a moderate 12 knots from south-southwest, and once under way the fleet, on starboard tack, was almost but not quite pointed for the little island in the Atlantic Ocean 635 miles away.

The scientific knowledge of American elementary and secondary school students declined over a recent three-year period, according to a report released today by the Federal Government's National Assessment of Educational Progress.

" The Mets are streaking, baby!" So sounded the joy in the Mets locker room tonight after they had beaten the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1, on three home runs, two by John Milner and one by Rusty Staub. The victory, the second in a row, helped New York jab its needle a little farther into the first-place Phils' bubble. Three games are left in the series.

Gene Francis, the defending Long Island amateur champion, hit a fine No. 7 iron tee shot within 30 feet of the pin at the par-3 17th hole at Plandome Country Club today. Announcement yesterday that the cost of living took another sharp jump in May punctured the fatuous hope of the Administration that the ending of Federal wageprice controls would not lead to a new burst of price increases. Federal Judge Fred Nichol turned down yesterday a request by Russell Means and Dennis Banks, leaders of the American Indian Movement, to order a subpoena of White House tapes.

City School Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday asked the superintendent of Community School District 9 in the Bronx to investigate charges of corporal punishment at a second school in the district, Public School 53.
The dollar showed strength today and the price of gold climbed back from a fourmonth low. The dollar faltered at the opening of most money markets but went into an upward trend at weekend closings.

With the romance found in lawbooks and ledgers, Alan N. Cohen has defined his role as the new president of Madison Square Garden. "If you ask me," he said, "whether I'd rather have a Stanley Cup and a basketball championship at the expense of a profit, I'd say no."

Canada's reported refusal to compromise Wednesday on terms for lifting a ban on American beef imports is "very disappointing" and could escalate into a United StatesCanadian trade war, a top Agriculture Department official indicated today.

New orders for durable goods surged in May, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase of $2.61-billion, or 5.9 per cent, was another indication that demand in the economy at large continued to be strong, though higher prices to some extent distorted the figures.
Lawrence G. Seible, who had been a management executive with the Hilton Hotels Corporation for many years, died Tuesday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 55 years old and formerly lived here.
Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (Television-Channel 11, 2 P.M.) (Radio-WMCA, 2 P.M.)

Rising interest rates again depressed the stock market yesterday in slower trading. The market opened on a weak note in anticipation on a rise in the prime rate, the interest banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.
After offering New Jersey 72 modern mobile homes for migrant farm workers two weeks ago, the Federal Government has suddenly rescinded the offer, citing legal complications.

An astute blend of collective bargaining and plea bargaining, supervised by State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts, has given New Yorkers increased protection against strikes in vital public services.
The First National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday increased their minimum lending rates to large corporate borrowers to 1 1/2 per cent from 11% per cent.

Miss Joan Hull, a merchandising manager for fiber products at the Celanese Corporation, was married here last evening to W. Dale Kelly, Eastern zone manager for the consumer products division of Magnavox in Teterboro, N. J. The Rev.

At the time he had in mind, a vast protective insensibility filled the universe, so that nobody felt anything at all and pain and remorse were unknown. Samuel King's portrait of Ezra.Stiles, painted in 1771, is on view at National Portrait Gallery in Washington.

Cab drivers returned to work here today after a 16-day driver walkout. Their return followed a six-hour meeting last night with a group representing owners of seven taxi companies. Cabs and drivers on line at Terminal B, Newark International Airport, yesterday. The city may take legal action to enable Newark cabs to pick up fares at Terminal A, now limited to cabs from Elizabeth.

Robert Wilson continues to amaze. His "A Letter for Queen Victoria," which has just had its world premiere at the Spoleto Festival, is a further example of his ability to enchant, intrigue, stimulate, puzzle and disorient his public.

The House of Representatives passed tonight a $13.4-billion appropriations bill for agriculture environmental and consumer protection programs, but cut back on food funds for Southeast Asia and dropped college students from the food stamp program.

Harry M. Hynes, a former lawyer and leader in the Irish community here, died Thursday at his home in Lauderdale-bythe-Sea, Fla. He was 89 years old.

A clash between Arab countries and Israel today threatened to disrupt the United Nations conference here that is seeking to draft a treaty governing use of the oceans.

Rutherford J. Gettens, an art expert who over the last several decades had played a major role in determining the authenticity of works of art, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Mooers, N. Y., on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived in Washington.

Stepped-up Palestinian terrorist attacks against Israel and Israeli counterattacks against Palestinian settlements in southern Lebanon pose a threat to the promising progress toward peace in the Middle East that was dramatized by President Nixon's recent tour of the region.

Relative calm settled over the Franklin National Bank yesterday after days of feverish activity spent in the preparation of restated earnings and in securing a replacement for Hahold V. Gleason, the Franklin's former chief executive officer.

The United States, Israel and the Arab nations have agreed to put off until the late fall any further Arab-Israeli negotiations for a Middle East peace settlement, American officials said today.

Two prominent Jewish organizations, commenting on reports that the Soviet Union was prepared to set a quota of 45,000 Soviet Jews to be allowed to emigrate a year, denounced Moscow for "playing a cynical numbers game with human lives."

Judge Gerhard A. Gesell called today for a hearing Monday on another request by attorneys for John D. Ehrlichman seeking access to personal White House notes of Presidential conversations.

Miss Ellen M. Friedman and James S. Marcus, both of New York, were married here yesterday morning at the House of Living Judaism by Rabbi Balfour Brickner.
Robert Hayes, a 23-year-old reputed member of the .Black Liberation Army, was sentenced yesterday to 35 years to life in prison for murdering a Transit Authority policeman and stealing his gun.

Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair, urging his aging legs through a rain-spattered final two rounds, captured his fourth New Jersey amateur championship today with rounds of 73 and 75 for a total of 296 at the Navesink Country Club.

I., was married to Peter Elliot Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lyon Marshall Jr. of Mill Neck, L. I., The Rev. John Hascup performed the ceremony.

The Air Force yesterday awarded a $42.8-million contract to the Rockwell International Corporation to develop, build and launch three prototype satellites in the Navstar Global Positioning System. When the program is completed, 24 satellites will provide everything from supersonic aircraft to ships and infantry and submerged submarines with their locations within 30 feet day or night in any kind of weather. A disagreement has developed between the Soviet authorities and the White House advance team over whether President Nixon should go to Yalta during his forthcoming visit, reliable sources reported tonight.

In this period of shaken public confidence in government, the overwhelming approval given by Senate and House to far-reaching reforms in the way Congress handies Federal spending and taxes represents an impressive triumph for the legislative process.

Ambassador and Mrs. Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Wednesday opened their official residence here, Spaso House, to an exhibition of American paintings from classical studies of American Indians to bright, coloristic modern abstractions.

The Senate approved a landmark bill today giving Congress new machinery for dealing with the Federal budget and deciding how to spend the money The bill, which passed, 75 to 0, now-goes to President Nixon, who is expected to sign it even though it would limit his power to impound, or refuse to spend, money appro. priated by Congress.

Paire Webber Jackson Curtis, Inc., sold a 45,700-share block of Struthers Wells common stock yesterday on the American Stock Exchange evidently because a customer failed to meet a margin call.

An 8.2 per cent rise in the cost of produce and substantial increases in other categories of goods and services more than offset a 3.5 per cent decline in the retail prices of meats; poultry and fish in New York area last month, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Nixon Administration officials disclosed that Secretary of State Kissinger, without informing Congress, made at least two secret arrangements with Soviet leaders in 1972 on the number of strategic missiles on each side. The failure to notify Congress may be a violation of the Arms Control and Disarmament Act of 1961. [1:1.]

Reykjavik, Iceland, has become the first city in the would to be heated almost entirely by geothermal energy and, in view of soaring fuel costs, other Icelandic communities are rapidly following suit.

John J. Egan, the former commanding officer of a special investigations unit of the Police Department's narcotics bureau, who had been accused of accepting money from drug peddlers, was convicted yesterday by a Federal District Court jury of falsifying his incometax return for 1970.

Most corn and soybean contracts closed up the daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid a rush of buying orders. The buying of contracts was attributed to the heavy rains over Illinois and a forecast of more rain over the weekend.

George Carr Leib, who retired as board chairman of Blyth Co., Inc., a major investment banking house, in 1966, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 71 East 71st Street. George Carr Leib
A three-team zonal playoff will begin today in Boston, with the winners scheduled to compete here next month in the auarter-final stage of the Grand National Team Championship.

Lloyd Jacobs, a vice president of the Loews Corporation for construction operations, died Thursday in the Deepdale Hospital, Little Neck, Queens. He was 57 years old and lived in the Hotel Ten Park Avenue, at 34th Street.
Earlier this week the Republicans lost control of the! White Plains Common Council in a special election called to end a state of legislative confusion and paralysis.

Robert C. Sellerole, a former Commissioner of the Bergen County Sewer Authority, was sentenced in New York City to two years in prison for his part in a kickback scheme involving the deposit bf authority funds in a Manhattan bank. Judge Edward Weinfeld, noting that "bribery by a public official is a violation of the public trust," imposed the sentence on the charges of bribery and perjury in the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

A resolution passed by the Board of Estimate late Wednesday evening has cleared the way for one of Manhattan's two cable systems to experiment with pay-television for a two-year period, during which it would pay the city 10 per cent of its receipts.

The first day of Mayor Beame's new plan for speeding West Side Highway repairs and improving traffic flow was characterized yesterday by snarled traffic and community complaints that the emergency repair program was still too slow.

Ford workers at 11 assembly plants will return to their jobs next week following a 10-day strike at the auto maker's Chicago Heights Stamping Plant. Some 33,000 assembly workers were laid off this week after the strike by 3,800 United Auto Workers on June 11 cut off the flow of parts.

A 20-year-old convicted rapist who posed as a deliveryman to gain entry into his victims' apartments was sentenced to 75 years in prison. In State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Justice Alfred M. Ascione imposed consecutive 25-year sentences on two rape counts and a 25-year term for first-degree robbery on Marvin Edwards, a wiry, medium-sized man.

Boosters called the. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway "the world's greatest highway." Critics called it "Dewey's Upstate Boulevard" and a "billion-dollar pot of political patronage." The Thruway service area at Ardsley, in Westchester County, is closed. The 20-year-old road is experiencing a financial slump because of the effects of the gasoline shortage.

The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday its London subsidiary had arranged an $50-million nine-year-loan for the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation. Chase said the money would go toward financing the Suez-Mediterranean pipeline.

Consumer prices resumed their rapid rise in May after some moderation in April, the Labor Department reported today. With food prices, except for meat, on the upswing again, the Consumer Price Index rose by 1.1 per cent both before and after adjustment for normal seasonal changes in some prices.

Pressure by foreign conservation groups to stop Japan from whaling has provoked an angry nationalistic backlash among Japanese and raised charges that Japan is being made the victim of "emotional" attacks.

The City of Rome stopped paying interest today for its mountainous debts in a decision highlighting the disarray of public finances in Italy. "We are on the verge of bankruptcy," said Budget Commissioner Carlo Merolli.

Anna Sokolow's "Rooms" has a hot, lonely intensity all its own that was needlessly intensified in the hot airless atmosphere of New York University's temporarily un-air-conditioned School of "Education auditorium. Mrs. Francine Feldman said yesterday that her 14-year-old daughter, Alyssa, did not attend her eighth-grade graduation ceremony Tuesday and was enrolling in a private school next year because she believes she has been the victim of anti-Semitic attacks in the public school in the northern New Jersey town of Little Falls.

Next month The New York Times will begin to increase advertising rates in most classifications, Warren Wolfe, advertising director, announced yesterday. Averaging about 4 per cent, the rate increases are being forced by higher operating expenses, including newsprint costs.

Charles W. Colson was sentenced today to one to three years in prison and fined $5,000 after telling a Federal judge that President Nixon had urged him "on numerous occasions" to commit the acts for which he was being jailed. Charles W. Colson, right, leaves court after sentencing with Senator Harold E. Hughes of his prayer group.

An upstate Disrict Atorney said yesterday that one of the lawyers for a man on rial for murder in Lake Pleasant, N.Y., told him last Sept. 7 that "he had located tow bodies and that he would give us the locations of the bodies in return for our acceptiong a plea of manslaughter second-degree."
Manny Sanguillen of the Pirates diving for first base as Andre Thornton of the Cubs awaited throw in a pickoff attempt in second inning yesterday at Chicago. Throw was late, Sanguillen was safe.
Jean Wahl, existentialist philosopher and poet, died here Wednesday. He was 88 years old and was on the faculty of the Sorbonne. A bachelor, Professor Wahl left no immediate family.
President Anwar el-Sadat called on President Nixon today to take a "firm stand against Israel's repeated aggressions on Lebanon," the newspaper Al Akhbar reported today.

Three former narcotics-squad detectives were convicted by a State Supreme Court jury in the Bronx late Thursday night of stealing $4,500 from the wife of a man they had arrested. They face up to seven years' imprisonment.
A brief, two-out, ninth-inning uprising topped by a Yankee throwing error turned what seemed certain victory into defeat for New York at damp Shea Stadium last night.
Edward L. Yordan, a former New York Times reporter who turned to teaching traffic safety and later became an English professor, died Thursday in Titusville, Fla., where he lived. His age was 71.

Mayor Beame will interrupt a California trip to return to the city next Thursday to sign new tax laws that will go into effect July 1, his office said yesterday. He will then fly back to California.

A panel of specialists who conducted a four-month study told a Senate committee today that they had found government agencies poorly organized to pursue a national food and nutrition policy and said that even a national goal was lacking.

Once a sleepy little city in the heart of Connecticut's affluent Gold Coast, Stamford is now hard at work recreating the urban dream. The 21-story Landmark Towers looms over a revitalized downtown in Stamford, Conn. Movie theaters, a major hotel, parking garages and a shopping center will rise in area.

Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis won today an easy victory for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate. Delegates to the state Republican convention picked the 42-year-old former Rhodes Scholar, now in his second term as Mayor, over Representative Earl F. Landgrebe, 58, a conservative who asserted that Mr. Lugar was "cutting up my President."

To the Editor: I believe that, if voted, an impeachment should contain a single charge; namely, that the President did "fail to take care that the laws be faithfully executed." There it is: explicit in the Constitution, and about the only item in Sections 2 and 3 which lays a compliance responsibility on the President (almost all the other items -except for procedural matters-run to his powers, rather than his responsibilities).

WASHINGTON--The Watergate prosecution is disposing of the political crimes of the century by plea bargaining. Dealing, to be blunt. Trading. Reducing the charges in exchange for a promise to plead guilty, to testify against the other guy and to saye the prosecution the trouble of trial. It sounds bad and, sometimes, it looks bad, especially when a Watergate defendant walks off with a light sentence. But is it bad?

MADISON - The New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, which is said to be the state's only professional (Actors' Equity) repertory company, will launch its 10th summer season on Tuesday. The festival is being presented again at Drew University, where it has appeared for the last three summers.

RICHMOND, Va.--Henry Kissinger is an authority on Metternich, the Austrian diplomatic genius whom many consider a prototype of the brilliant Secretary of State. Asked once why he had failed to achieve his ultimate policy ambitions, Metternich replied: "Because I sometimes governed Europe, never Austria."
France has been opening to general scrutiny some of the cobwebbed financial corners of her public administration in order to improve services and get them operating with less waste and graft.

Japanese tea gardens are seldom large, but many elements in them conspire to give you a sense of spaciousness and to keep you from racing through them. The stepping stones, for instance, are often of irregular sizes and shapes, and they are placed so as to impede your progress.

I want to single out this movie as one of the very few totally successful radical political films.

It cannot promise the kind of dramatic turn in SovietAmerican relations produced by Richard Nixon's journey to Moscow via Peking of two years ago. Nor the curiosity of Mr. Brezhnev getting acquainted with a bit of America last year while the public took his measure on TV.

The revenue-sharing program enacted in 1972 at the urging of the Nixon Administration was meant to help return government to the people by giving Federal funds directly to lower levels of government with no or few strings attached. WASHINGTON--The White House has said that President Nixon is personally directing economic policy, but that assertion is not taken at face value by people knowledgeable on the subject. Mr. Nixon, insiders report, is preoccupied with Watergate, his impeachment defense and foreign policy. George P. Shultz has left the Treasury after five years in the Nixon Cabinet.

THE files in the State Attorney General's Office on travelers who have been gypped, frustrated or inconvenienced by promoters of charter flights have been getting bulkier and bulkier these last few summers. They are stuffed with complaints about flights that were supposed to go to, say, Madrid, and landed instead in London.

In olden times when everybody in the middle class had an attic, some of the liveliest reading material in the house was stashed away up under the eaves. There, behind mounds of broken furniture and decaying lampshades, buried under a faltering pyramid of aged textbooks and inspirational religious works lay the long-forgotten family "doctor" book, property of an earlier generation and mother lode to prurient adolescents.

Economists for the United Nations say that because of last year's quadrupling of oil prices, earnings of organized oil-exporting countries may well reach $85billion in 1974, over five times the 1972 level.

Officials said today that the Federal Government would disburse $530-million additional in pay over the next few months because of court rulings that President Nixon illegally delayed pay rises in 1972.

When the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Abdul Razak, opened the fifth Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers here Friday, he urged the delegates "to come out with News concrete proposals Analysis that can be implemented" rather than "merely propounding grandiose plans that look impressive on paper but that will not get off the ground," as previous Islamic gatherings have done.

When it originally announced its first-quarter earnings figures two months ago, the Franklin National Bank made a "mistake." It said its profits for that period were $582,000, but it now says it lost over $40 million in the first quarter, and $63 million in the first five months. As one bank stock analyst put it, the bank is now "really trying to go naked."

Stage and film stars mingled with shellfishermen at the Town Hall here today to pay tribute to Katharine Cornell during a two-hour memorial gathering. There were no religious services.
An Indian news agency reported today that the Indian Atomic Energy Commission planned to detonate a hydrogen explosive device following up its underground atomic test last month.

Mull at home in Freehold. Mrs. Mull holds a photo of their daughter, Deborah.

The surge of American investment in Asia has provoked remarkably little controversy in the region, mainly because it has coincided with an even more rapid and conspicuous expansion of Japanese economic interests. Asian demonstrators who protest against foreign businessmen usually have the Jananese in mind.

The unbroken record of victories by Socialist candidates in Austrian presidential elections since World War II was maintained with the election of Rudolf Kirchschlger, a lawyer and diplomat. Mr. Kirchschlager, who has been his country's Foreign Minister since 1970, succeeds Franz Jonas, who died April 24. He is not a member of a political party but was the personal choice of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky as the nominee of the Socialist party. [1:7.]

Forty persons were reported dead and 50,000 homeless as heavy rains engulfed the hilly Chittagong district in southeastern Bangladesh, officials said today.

A continent-width removed from its origins, which go back 85 years, the richest rivalry in American sportsbetween the baseball Dodgers and Giants-was celebrated again today in an old-timers' day ceremony here.

Mayor Beame being welcomed to San Diego by Mayor Roy B. Martin Jr. of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Martin heads the U.S. Conference of Mayors, which is holding its annual meeting.

Consumers lose about $500million a year because bankruptcy laws and procedures are confusing and give large creditors such as banks and investors priority in recouping funds from insolvent businesses, according to legal specialists in the field.

Colson left the Federal Courthouse here Friday after being sentenced tc prison for his part in the Watergate scandals, he looked with his furrowed brow and slightly News disheveled hair Analysis like a little boy about to cry. He also looked, with his horn-rimmed glasses and sober expression, a little like an owl.

Striking clerical workers of the Maplewood Equipment Company agreed to return to work after accepting a management wage and benefit offer. A company spokesman said clerical workers received an increase in wages, improved health insurance and pension benefits, and increased vacation time.

William H. Red) Friesell Jr., a veteran football referee who made a famous officiating error in the 1940 Cornell-Dartmouth game, died today in Shadyside Hospital. He was 80 years old William H. Friesell announcing his refereeing error on Nov. 18, 1940.

The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, said landlords of buildings with six or more units were required to put all tenant-security deposits in separate bank accounts, with the interest payable to the tenants.

The state has threatened to reduce its welfare aid to the city by $500,000 a month unless the Human Resources Administration broadens efforts to halt relief overpayments to welfare clients employed by municipal agencies.

A 34-year-old Brooklyn womman was found stabbed and raped yesterday morning near the boathouse in Prospect Park, the police said. Her condition was listed as critical at Maimonides Hospital.

To the Editor: The United States has offered to provide both Israel and Egypt with nuclear power sources. Fear of the misuse of the atomic material has been expressed by both countries as well as in this country.
Four rapid-fire bursts of radiation, detected a mile underground in South Dakota, have tentatively been interpreted as deluges of antimatter thrown off by a star collapsing to a superdense state.

Smith College will begin its second century next year with its first woman president. Trustees of the women's college at Northampton, Mass., yesterday named Mrs. Jill K. Conway, a 39-year-old historian and educator, to succeed Thomas C. Mendenhall when he retires on July 1, 1975.

It was not a very felicitous first anniversary of the return of Gen. Juan Peron from eighteen years of exile that Argentina celebrated last week. President Peron himself was forced by an influenza attack to cancel a trip to Rosario to observe the anniversary. It was one of several illnesses that have incapacitated the 78-year. old general since he reassumed the Presidency last October.

A Federal grant of $301,480 to help train 100 commercial-shop printers in photo composition and computerized typesetting was announced jointly yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine and Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6.
Vice President Ford, bringing back memories of his predecessor, struck a spectator in the head as Mr. Ford teed off this morning at a celebrity golf tournament.
An expression of fear on the face of a 17-year-old Brooklyn girl tipped off a patrolman yesterday morning that her male companion was less than a friend and led to the man's arrest.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced today the approval of three loans totaling $92-million for development projects in Morocco, Nigeria and Turkey.

The Federal Trade Commission was formally asked today to block the proposed acquisition by Mobil Oil Corporation of the Marcor Corporation in a petition filed by Representative LesAspin, Democrat of Wisconsin. Mr. Aspin asked the F.T.C. to bring restraint of trade proceedings against the proposed merger. He specifically asked the agency
NEWARK-Four years ago a civil engineer working in the Health Department here won election as this city's first black Mayor.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were hoping to announce during President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow that they had reached agreement in principle to limit underground nuclear tests.
Working anonymously, for the glory of their God, some men build cathedrals. Others, equally anonymous, serve their fellow and illustrate postcards.

The condition of the nation's banks is in general "very strong" and the Government can prevent "any real harm" to the economy that might result from the troubles of the Franklin National Bank, President Nixon's economic counselor said today.

Poor weather has dimmed hopes for super-large grain crops this year to help cool consumer food prices, but 1974 harvests of corn and wheat still are expected to be at record levels, the Agriculture Department said today.

Patricia Fogarty McQuillan, last year's New York Feminist of the Year, died of cancer yesterday in a clinic in Bonn, where she had gone recently for treatment. She was 50 years old and lived at 240 East 76th Street.

Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Aziz Ahmed, today denied saying at the Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers here that Israel had collaborated in India's recent nuclear explosion, although official records showed that he had.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 18.

State Treasurer Richard C. Leone charged today that a statewide tax increase on business and industrial property as an alternative to Governor Byrne's pro- t posed state income tax would undermine New Jersey's economy and increase unemployment.

Three Arab guerrillas broke into a small apartment house in the northern resort town of Nahariya last night and killed three Israeli civilians before being slain themselves in a gunfight with Israeli soldiers.
Some of President Nixon's closest and most loyal Senate friends are showing concern over his rejection of demands for more tapes in the impeachment inquiry.
The troubled Citroen automobile works announced tonight a move toward merger with the rival company of Peugeot. Citron is France's third biggest auto maker after Renault and Peugeot.
A Superior Court judge here is handling a custoday suit over two waifs with tawny fur and white spots.

ROXBURY, Conn.--Springtime at Auschwitz. The phrase itself has the echo of the bad and tasteless joke, but spring still arrives in the depths of southern Poland, even at Auschwitz. Just beyond the once-electrified fences, still standing, the forsythia puts forth its yellow buds in gently rolling pastures where sheep now graze.

The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra today surrendered to threats by World War II partisans and concentration-camp survivors and canceled Wednesday night's concert, which was to have included works by Richard Wagner.

Julia Meade, who has sold cold-water detergent, among other products, to millions of American women, yesterday asked them to band together with "heart and soul" to raise money for the United States Olympic team.

Agreed to hear an appeal from a decision enjoining a court-martial for passing classified information to a foreign power on the grounds that a civilian defense counsel could not get full access to classified material (No. 731346, McLucas v. DeChamplain).

There was good news and bad news today at the opening of the America's Cup trials. Of the four United States yachts competing for the right to defend the, trophy next September, the recipients of good news were Courageous and Intrepid, the receivers of bad tidings, Mariner and Valiant.

President Nixon, turning his attention to the nation;s economy on the eve of his departure for the Soviet Union, said today that the Federal Government would try to limit spending to $300-billion in the fiscal year beginning next Monday.

The Supreme Court postponed for two weeks today a ruling on whether the Justices should inspect the Watergate grand jury's records to help them decide if the jurors could name President Nixon as an unindicted co-conspirator.

Engineers have completed the first phase of inspecting the deteriorated West Side HighwayHenry Hudson Parkway elevated structure six weeks ahead of schedule, the city announced yesterday.
Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that it was unfair for Watergate convicts to receive short prison sentences while thieves serve years behind bars.

Clark, the black psychologist whose studies of the harmful effects of segregation were noted in the 1954 Supreme Court decision ordering desegregation of public schools, and Dr. Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish author of "An American Dilemma," the 1944 classic, are teaming up for a new study of racial problems in the United States.
The Byrne administration has established six regional "hot line" telephone numbers to answer public inquiries about the Governor's proposed income-tax program.

The nine members of the European Common Market are seeking to reinforce their joint voice atf the United Nations on economic matters because of the increased activity of the United Nations is international economic affairs.
Mrs. Sue Mead Kaiser, wife of the industrialist Edgar F. Kaiser, died in the Intourist Hotel today, apparently of a heart attack, United States diplomats said. She was 65 years old.

Traders rushed to sell silver futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, and the selling was so heavy that prices dropped the 20-cent-an-ounce limit not long after the opening.
Senate approval of the promotion of a former Watergate prosecutor could aid the President's defense against impeachment, Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen acknowledged today.

Gold and diamonds worth about $450,000 were stolen from a West New York jewelry store last weekend by burglars described by the police as a "team of four or five experts." The burglary was discovered yesterday.
It took Tom Gorman five sets and 3 match points to defeat Anand Amritraj today in the only match remotely close to an upset before the largest opening-day crowd in Wimbledon tennis history.

The Broadway season has ended, but there is no surcease for producers from the economic facts of Broadway. Costs keep rising. More and more, profits are pipe dreams. And it is increasingly difficult to raise money for new shows.

Declaring inflation the "No. 1 problem" in this country and the world, Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said today that it might be advisable to have a summit meeting of world leaders "to get at the handle of inflation."
Prime Minister Wilson announced today that Britain's first nuclear bomb test in nine years was carried out "a few weeks ago" in Nevada.
The Supreme Court reversed today a decision that the Government said would have cost the Treasury about $400-million a year in taxes paid by electric utilities.

The F.B.I. asked a Federal judge today to dismiss a suit filed by a high school student charging that a Federal Bureau of Investigation check on a letter that the student had written to the Socialist Workers party was illegal and the "hallmark of a police state."
The annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors is getting marked attention from officials of the Nixon Administration.

The Watergate prosecutor's office told a Federal judge today that it was changing its tactics in the upcoming "plumbers" trial and would no longer try to prove that John D. Ehrlichman attempted to conceal his alleged involvement in an unlawful burglary in 1971.

The cease-fire talks between the Portuguese Government and the liberation movement have been broken off, but an informal cease-fire has been in effect for about a month. The soldiers of both armies fraternize widely and a feeling of headlong decolonization is in the air.

A group of health care experts urged Congress today to enact Federal legislation that Would force doctors to demonstrate their medical proficiency throughout their professional lives.
Lebanon has asked the Arab nations for assistance in strengthening her air defenses against Israel, Premier Takieddin Solh announced today.

The Supreme Court ruled today that the motion picture "Carnal Knowledge" was not obscene but that an advertisement for an illustrated version of the report of the Presidential commission on obscenity was.
In his first extended interview since his expulsion from the Soviet Union in February, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn said he would return to live in Russia if his work could be freely published there.
Shows listed in capital letters are still running. Figures indicate the number of performances through Sunday, June 30, when the season officially closes.
A Mount Vernon police detective with a hero's record was slain by a close-range shotgun blast early yesterday when he drew his service revolver and exchanged fire with a robber in a bar there.

The House Judiciary Committee, trying to accelerate the impeachment inquiry, issued what were described as its final four subpoenas today for White House tape recordings and authorized President Nixon's defense counsel to begin presenting rebuttal evidence on Thursday.

In the largest sale of taxanticipation notes in the city's history, $800-million worth were sold yesterday at an average interest rate of 7.188 per cent.

The Roman Catholic hierarchy of France has reacted irately to press reports of the circumstances of the death of Jean Cardinal Danielou, one of the country's most prominent church leaders and intellectuals.

The Iranian Government denied today that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi had said that his nation intended to have nuclear weapons soon. A Government minister quoted the Shah as saying that Iran had no such intentions.

Governor Byrne of New Jersey said that, pending a complete re-evaluation by the Federal Government, he was opposed to construction of the Tocks Island Dam project. Mr. Byrne made the statement In a letter to Senators John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi and Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, both chairmen of subcommittees of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

Nearly 100,000 works of art have been catalogued in a computerized system that promises to ease the work of museums organizing loan exhibitions and of scholars and policemen seeking specific information.
Governor Wilson, reacting to pressure from T. David Bullard, his Conservative party challenger, conferred with political aides yesterday in an effort to avoid a Conservative party primary contest.

The "bottom line" management philosophy of Madison Square Garden's new president, Alan N. Cohen, which has brought howls of protest from the sporting world, may nevertheless prove an unexpected boon for our town. Mr. Cohen wants the Garden to be a profitable enterprise.
Senator Barry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, spent about 20 minutes here today to accept a check from a local Rotary district for an American Indian relief program.

Negotiators for 80 craft employes of El Diario-La Prensa agreed yesterday under a $1million settlement to let the Spanish-language daily newspaper move its printing operations to a subcontractor's plant in Stratford, Conn.

Oceanographic Institution scientist who was a pioneer in population, growth and migration research on the Atlantic bluefin tuna, and who in recent years has been warning that the stocks of this magnificent game and food fish have been dangerously depleted, is now experiencing belated recognition of his efforts.

PARIS-When we first explored the great restaurants of Paris and France we willingly played Pantagruel morning, noon and night, sampling any dish that issued forth from oven or saucepan. We seldom passed a pastry shop between meals without spending a few centimes for a barquette here, a sorbet there.

Rates on Treasury bills declined today as the Government borrowed $4.5-billion by selling short-term securities at its regular weekly auction. The average rate on three-month bills was the lowest since early March.

Miss Debora Read Graves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Graves of Rye, N. Y., was married in Mamaroneck, ,N. Y., yesterday afternoon to John Wesley Westcott 3d, son of Mr. Westcott Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mrs. Mary Ingraham Westcott of Rye.

To the Editor: Elliot H. Sharp's tirade (letter June 19) against the class action lawyer combines curious logic with twisted arithmetic. He complains that it is "not uncommon for the lawyers to gain $100,000 or more by settling [class action] cases out of court, with stockholders benefiting by as little as a cent a share."

A volley of rockets that was to have been fired from Wallops Island, off the Virginia coast, beginning yesterday after noon, was postponed because cloud cover threatened to obcure the chemical trails to be written in the sky for upper atmosphere studies.

The widow of Lieut. Henry O. Schmiemann and their five children sat side by side at a Mass of the Resurrection for the slain police officer yesterday, their faces and their bearing as much a triumph of disciplined composure as the formation of 1,500 policemen and policewomen who stood at attention later in a final salute.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Booming, burgeoning Brazil casts a heavy shadow all across South America. Brazil insists the shadow is a benevolent one, the symbol of good-neighborliness, an expression of the desire to help others share in meaningful economic development. Some South American governments remain skeptical.

NEWBURGH, N.Y.-Somebody, no one is sure quite who, planted a tree where some ancient Iroquois and Algonquin Indian trails crossed in 1699. It was only 41 years after the death of Oliver Cromwell and 76 years before the Battle of Bunker Hill.

Thirty-six years ago this month, Cincinnati's Johnny Vander Meer accomplished a pitching feat that made history. Vander Meer pitched two consecutive no-hit games, beating the Boston Braves on June 11 and duplicating the feat against the Brooklyn Dodgers on June 15.

Global Marine, Inc., and Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, Ltd., announced yesterday that they had signed a letter of intent to enter into a joint venture with the first project to be a $40-million, 450-foot drilling ship using a Global Marine design.

President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan today decided to hand over to the Palestine Liberation Organization the guerrillas who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian in a siege of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum 15 months ago, the Middle East News Agency reported.

The golden rule worked for the Mets today. The Chicago Cubs, doing unto the Mets what the Mets have been doing unto others, committed two errors in the ninth inning to let New York win, 4-2, on three unearned runs at Wrigley Field.
Three American aluminum manufacturers have requested arbitration in their dispute with the Jamaican Government over its bauxite revenue increase, the World Bank Settlement Center reported today.
Dr. Samuel Barlow Moore, a psychiatrist in Glen Cove, L. I., died Sunday at his home in Locust Valley, L. I. He was 60 years old.

A state appeals court judge cleared the way today for recruiting of Dallas Cowboy football players by the World Football League. Judge Harold Bateman reversed a lower court injunction that had halted W.F.L. recruiting of players from the National Football League team.

A police officer suffered a fractured skull, two broken legs and serious internal injuries yesterday when he was hit and dragged by a cab he was about to inspect at the 114th precinct station house in Long Island City, Queens.

One reward of writing a regular newspaper column is the discovery of the rich variety of dissent that still 'thrives in the United States. Every week the mail brings refreshing evidence' that Americans remain a wonderfully disputatious race 'eager to catch the arrogant columnist in his foolishness and torment him with demands for public confession of his poor judgment, muddled thought, careless cruelties, subversive opinion, bad grammar, weak history and general ignorance.
The Senate overwhelmingly defeated today a tax package that would have cut income taxes and ended several business tax breaks, including the oil depletion allowance.

The Federal Reserve Board adopted today an amendment reducing the standards that an over-the-counter stock must meet in order for brokers to be allowed to lend money on it, subject to the Reserve's margin requirements.
The attorney for Robert A. Maheu assailed Howard R. Hughes today as "a disembodied voice who did not see fit to show his face to the world as he destroyed another human being."

Secretary of State Kissinger and Senator Henry M. Jackson today continued their dispute over whether the Secretary had made secret arrangements with Moscow regarding the agreement of 1972 limiting some offensive nuclear missiles for five years.

It took repeated assurances that her fans and show-business friends really loved her and only wanted a chance to prove it to persuade Betty Hutton, the former Hollywood star who had fallen on hard times, to agree to last night's benefit in her honor at the Riverboat nightclub-restaurant here.

Overpowering high school baseball pitchers aren't unusual, so not many people got excited at St. Anthony's in the spring when 18-year-old Al Paglione went undefeated in 11 games, pitched five shutouts, struck out an average of nine a game, allowed one earned run in his first 47 innings and finished the season with an earned-run average of 0.24.

The Board of Standards and Appeals ideally represents a judicious balance in the city's building process. When a developer is faced with a genuine economic hardship on a particular construction site, such as an odd-shaped lot or unusual foundation conditions, he can ask-and often gets-an exception to the zoning requirements to make up his additional costs. Usually this means a larger structure or permission for nonconforming features.
Prime Minister Wilson announced today that Britain's first nuclear bomb test in nine years was carried out "a few weeks ago" in Nevada.

American press comments on the financial and political crisis through which Italy is going have caused irritation here, and one columnist charged that the United States must share the responsibility for this nation's plight.
The state's stringent new antidrug laws-have not measurably slowed the over-all Flow of drugs or driven major narcotics dealers out of business, according to many lawenforcement authorities.
Vice President Ford, bringing back memories of his predecessor, struck a spectator in the head as Mr. Ford teed off this morning at a celebrity golf tournament.
Despite the absence of the Soviet Union and Hungary from the World Cup tournament, several Eastern countries have emerged as strong contenders for that area's first world soccer title.

Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist, today urged President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev to take up issues of free emigration and free exchange of information in their forthcoming talks.
The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and President Nixon appealed today for expanding trade links to help consolidate East-West political accommodation and communication.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market dropped again yesterday after announcements of a flurry of increases in banks' prime interest rates.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were hoping to announce during President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow that they had reached agreement in principle to limit underground nuclear tests.

Julia Meade, who has sold cold-water detergent, among other products, to millions of American women, yesterday asked them to band together with "heart and soul" to raise money for the United States Olympic team.

Communist units blew up fuel tanks and an ammunition dump outside Hue overnight, the Saigon command said. It said 24,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel oil were destroyed at the Hoa My depot 12 miles southwest of Hue, and 4,600 tons of mortar and artillery shells, mines and grenades were lost at a munitions dump seven miles southeast of Hue.

" Meat Prices Reduced; See How Much You Save," the nation's largest supermarket chain proclaimed in bold type over a newspaper advertisement published here today.
The United States, against strong Japanese and Soviet opposition, today demanded a 10-year moratorium on commercial killing of whales to save them from extinction.

Charles Colson, who entered a guilty plea under terms of an arrangement with Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, appears to have received a slightly stiffer sentence than Dwight Chapin, who spurned' a guilty plea and insisted on trial.

A former sporting-goods store overlooking an embankment of the winding Moscow River is undergoing a crash renovation here as the future Soviet headquarters of a trade coalition involving American business and the Soviet Government.

According to today's London Evening Standard, the Kuwaiti-based Gulf International group, has been buying heavily into Lonrho, the British-owned conglomerate with commercial and mining interests in Africa.
The White House disclosed tonight that President Nixon recently suffered from phlebitis, an inflammation n a leg vein, but said that the condition had presumably abated.
NEWARK-Four years ago a civil engineer working in the Health Department here won election as this city's first black Mayor.

John B. Connally telephoned President Nixon in 1972 to express concern about a Justice Department investigation of Jake Jacobsen's role in a Texas savings-and-loan scandal, according to a well-placed source.
The White House disclosed tonight that President Nixon recently suffered from phlebitis, an inflammation in a leg vein, but said that the condition had presumably abated.
Attorneys for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., seeking reversal of his Army murder conviction, argued today that he was the victim of "damaging and inflammatory" pre-trial publicity.

-The Rev. Dr. John McLaughlin, a Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, called on a House Judiciary Committee member today to deny under oath that he is leaking secret information on the impeachment inquiry to the news media.

The House Judiciary Committee, trying to accelerate the impeachment inquiry, issued what were described as its final foursubpoenas today for White House tape recordings and authorized President Nixon's defense counsel to begin presenting rebuttal evidence on Thursday.
A MeiPing jar from the collection of Frederick M. Mayer of New York was sold today for $554,000 at Christie's.
Antonio Morelli, former conductor and musical director at the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., died June 17 in Las Vegas at the age of 69.

Mrs. Gloria Goldsmith Raiffa, former assistant director of counseling and testing at the Pratt Institute and the wife of Elliot Raiffa, an executive of the IBM Corporation, died Sunday in Maimonides Hospital. She was 39 years old and lived at 469 Rugby Road in Brooklyn.
The Assembly today gave final legislative approval to a bill that would set up a Division on Women within the Department of Community Affairs.

The Certain-teed Products Corporation announced yesterday that it would assist the Valley Forge Corporation, a 71 per cent-owned subsidiary, by guaranteeing up to $6.2-million in funds for the troubled company.
Two gunmen robbed the pastor of a Washington Heights church of $1,900 yesterday as he was about to take the Sunday collection to the bank.
Treasury Minister Emilio Colombo said today that Italy's balance-of-payments deficit had run $1-billion a month in the first five months of the year and would total $10-billion for 1974.

Nonagricultural jobs in New Jersey rose to about 2.5 million during May, Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry said. He attributed the increase mainly to the addition of 25,000 jobs in nonmanufacturing industries to the work roles. Mr. Hoffman said the largest changes were in the construction industry, where 9,500 workers had been added as part of the seasonal expansion of the job market.

School Chancellor Irving Anker has asked Community School District 9, in the Bronx, to look into allegations of corporal punishment at two more schools, making a total of four in the District where such charges have been made.

After worrying through a sleepless night, Fritz Peterson pitched against the Yankees last night and put on a. good show for all his old friends who were there, working seven strong innings as the Cleveland Indians won, 10-3.

President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived here today on his first official visit to West Germany. According to West German and Yugoslav officials, there are no problems of substance between the two countries.

The head of the nation's largest Orthodox Jewish body charged the Conservative and Reform movements of Judaism today with "unwarranted interference" in Israel's political and religious life.
Responding to the complaint by an Indian tribal council, a Federal judge here ordered today that four of the 472 precincts in Iowa's Third Congressional District conduct a new election on July 2.

The Onondaga County (N.Y.) Bar Association was asked yesterday to investigate whether it was proper for the lawyers for Robert F. Garrow, who is on trial for murder in Lake Pleasant, N.Y., to withhold knowledge of two killings.

Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., reported yesterday consummation of its acquisition of Clark, Dodge Co., Inc., a mediumsize retail brokerage house that has suffered continuing losses, like many others in recent months.

President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan today decided to hand over to the Palestine Liberation Organization the guerrillas who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian in a siege of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum 15 months ago, the Middle East News Agency reported.
The Coming Glass Works the first major company to issue a financial statement fo the second quarter and firs half, reported yesterday record sales but earnings slightly low er than a year ago.

The episode began with an apparently straightforward block transaction last Friday that ended a steady rise in Struthers Wells shares over the past several weeks. The rise had carried the stock to 8 on Tuesday of last week.

Gary Baalman has no real quarrel with the American housewife. If she thinks beef prices are too high in the supermarket, he more or less agrees with her -at least, in view of the price live cattle are bringing.

Darius Milhaud, the composer who helped overturn traditional French music in the nineteen-twenties, died at his home in Geneva Saturday. He was 81 years old and leaves his wife, Madeleine, and a son, Daniel.

What Wimbledon is to London, Forest Hills is 'to New York and now this city is enhancing its image with a Tennisport on the East River. Planned for 30 clay courts and with room for a small stadium to hold tournaments, the Tennisport will be the biggest club here next to the West; Side,. which has 56 courts and is host to the annual United States Open championships.

The British pound fell sharply today against the United States dollar and most European currencies. Prices on the London Stock Exchange also declined amid continuing anxieties over the state of Britain's economy.

Steve Willams may get a chance to race Valeriy Borzov when a United States track and field team meets the Soviet Union on July 5 and 6. A 40-man United States team was named today by the Amateur Athletic Union for the dual meet at Durham, N. C.

The First National Bank of Chicago raised its corporate base lending rate-its equivalent of the prime interest rate for business loans-to a record 11.8 per cent yesterday, from 11.5 per cent. Five large California banks quickly raised their rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 11 3/4 per cent, but for the time being the predominant rate at most of the largest banks' in the country continues at 11 1/2 per cent.
A 65-year-old Queens man was shot fatally yesterday outside a Brooklyn bank when he apparently resisted a gunman attempting to steal a deposit he was carrying to the bank for his son.

Two men were killed by a premature explosion as they carried a bomb into a supermarket in Londonderry today. A British Army spokesman said a pistol was found near one of the bodies. A baby and two women were treated at a hospital for shock.

Trans World Airlines said yesterday it had completed $80-million of lease financing of four Lockheed L-1011 aircraft. Under 16-year leases, the First Chicago Leasing Corporation, Citicorp Translease and Greyhound Financial and Leasing, Ltd., have each assumed ownership of one aircraft.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had raised prices on a number of rolled steel products by 5 to 15 per cent. Affected by the increases are steel goods used by the construction, shipbuilding and automobile industries.

The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered that Gerardo Catena, the reputed Mafia kingpin in the state, remain confined on civil contempt charges for refusing to tell the State Commission of Investigation what it wanted to know about organized crime in New Jersey. Gerardo Catena

Delegates to the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church approved without dissent today local study of a plan to reunite the 2.9-million-member denomination with its 900,000-member Southern counterpart.

Seven blacks were killed today and at least six others were wounded when Portuguese troops at a border post opened fire on a "disorderly crowd of mine workers returning from South Africa," a military spokesman said here.

Helen M. Thompson, who served for 20 years as chief staff executive of the American Symphony Orchestra League and as manager of the New York Philharmonic from 1970 to 1973, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in Carmel, Calif. She was 66 years old. Helen M. Thompson
An explosion of international reserves, which countries use to settle debts with one another, was seen today as one of the principal causes of world ination.

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, under strong pressure from the United States Government and competing airlines, said yesterday that it had dropped a controversial rebate scheme under white travelers to Amsterdam aged 16 through 23 have been paid $50 for answering an opinion questionnaire.

The city school system, in partnership with.The City University, will start a major program next fall to overcome the basic educational deficiencies of some of its high school graduates - a task that must now be done by the university after the graduates are enrolled under its "open admissions" policy.

Reservists Committee to Stop the War). Dissenting: Douglas, Marshall and Brennan.
The Soviet Union has sent its chief border negotiator to Peking for talks on the long-standing border quarrel on the eve of President Nixon's visit.

About 575 hockey fans who bought season tickets for the New York Golden Blades last season but lost out on seeing most of the games when the World Hockey Association franchise was moved will get more than $250,000 in refunds, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

One of the misfortunes of President Nixon's present mission to Moscow is that he did not take along some of the leaders of Congress, whose understanding of the complex issues of military arms control is vital to Congressional approval of whatever agreements are reached there.

Young musicians who have been attending Jazz Interaction weekly workshops since February were given a showcase Monday evening in a program at the Pub Theatrical, Broadway at 51st Street, that also included a visiting Swedish jazz quartet, the Eje Thelin Group.
The automobile repair industry is "sick," a conference of consumer affairs officials from around the country has been told.

Al Fatah, the largest and most moderate of the Palestinian resistance organizations, announced today that it was responsible for the guerrilla raid that resulted in seven deaths last night at the Israeli town of Nahariya.

Phlebitis, the condition from which President Nixon has been suffering in recent weeks, is regarded in medical circles as common and not serious if treated properly. President Nixon rested his legs on a pillow as he listened to Secretary of State Kissinger en route to Brussels
Members of the House Judiciary Committee demonstrated today that, even in a process as lofty as impeachment, partisan. pressures and human disorder can sometimes prevail.

Several thousand mourners poured out their grief at a beachfront cemetery this evening during the funeral for the four Israeli victims of the Arab guerrilla attack on this northern resort town. A woman being helped from a building in Nahariya, Israel, after Arab guerrillas attacked Monday night.

Recommendations that Congress limit a President's use of executive privilege and define exactly what he can do in the name of national security have been proposed for the Senate Watergate committee's final report.

Sales of new cars are showing signs of pulling out of the long 1974 model slump, although retail deliveries are still well below 1973 levels. The four domestic auto manufacturers today reported sales of 257,022 cars in the June 1120 period. This was a decline of 17,4 per cent from the 311,044 sold in the same period last year.
A $10-million popular history museum housing a visual and electronic projection of the events of 200 years ago will be the centerpiece of the city's contribution to the bicentennial celebration.

The Eli Lilly Endowment today established a series of prizes to reward television writers for programs that "affirm human values in American television." The prizes range from $25,000 for the best-written movie made for television to $15.000 for the best one-hour

A House subcommittee reopened today its inquiry into alleged corruption in the Immigration ind Naturalization Service as result of charges two weeks go that a Justice Department investigation had been a "Cover-up."

James E. McMullen, retired partner of the investing firm of Payson and Trask, 748 Madison Avenue, died in Colorado Springs Monday after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

Marlon Brando was released today from the U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he underwent treatment for a torn throat. The actor's secretary, Alice Marshak, said the 50year-old actor had damaged his throat vomiting after apparently having eaten spoiled fish in Tahiti two weeks ago.

When George Weller wrote his novel about Harvard, "Not to Eat, Not for Love," he took his title from an Emerson passage about a trip to Cambridge, Mass., where he saw snakes gliding up a tree, "not to eat, not for love, but only gliding."

The District 2 School Board, at an emotional-and at times tumultuous - public meeting, confirmed last night its decision to replace Superintendent Rhoda S. Lansky with the district's current deputy superintendent, Dr. Barbara Weldon.

The Supreme Court ruled today that an ordinary citizen elevated to sudden prominence by news events can sue any newspaper or radio or television station that circulates a false and defamatory account of his role in those events.

WASHINGTON -- When President Nixon promised to sell nuclear fuel and power plants to Egypt and Israel--the outstanding commitment of his Middle Eastern trip--he was in part carrying out a policy originally conceived by ex-President Eisenhower and his former atomic energy chief in 1967, during the Lyndon Johnson Administration.

Christopher and Gregory Brody threw a joint birthday bash the other day. Actually it was a bit premature--Christopher's birthday isn't until July 23 and Gregory's is July 27--but by July all their friends would be scattered from Southampton to St. Tropez. Gregory Brody and his girlfriend, Serena Erlich, share a quiet moment at his birthday party, left. At right, Gregory and his brother, Christopher, sample cake as their mother and giggling guests look on.
