Four men described as part of a loosely knit band of armed robbers who stole and squandered more than $1-million over the last four years have been arrested by Nassau County detectives and charged with individual holdups that netted more than $250,000.
The Supreme Court denied today an application for bail by former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is seeking review of his court-martial conviction in the My Lai killings.
SUBIC BAY, the Philippines--In foreign ministries and embassies around Southeast Asia, the prospect of a military disengagement by the United States is still discussed as a major imponderable.

The Internal Revenue Service has withdrawn from a Federal grand jury's criminal investigation of C. Arnholt Smith and has notified the long-time friend of President Nixon that it will not prosecute him on charges of income tax fraud. C. Arnholt Smith

ABRAMSON--Nory, beloved husband of Susan devoted talher of Fern and Frank an cherished brother of Sheila Shapiro. Service today, 12 o'clock, Parkside Memoria Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Rego Park N. Y.
Vice President Ford expressed grave concern today over what he termed the growing tendency to violate the privacy of doctors and patients.

Luther Rackley and Jim Ard went job-hunting yesterday. So did 16 other hopefuls as the Knicks opened a threeday camp at Pace College in search of talent. It was the first such camp the Knicks had run at this time of the year since 1966.

The president of one of the largest mortgage-lending concerns in the East, his wife and two other persons were convicted. by a Federal Districts Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of conspiracy to misuse Federal funds designed to help the poor buy houses.

The House Ways and Means Committee voted down today the major portion of a tax-reform proposal that was aimed at reducing the tax advantages that wealthy persons can get from investing in real estate.
Bridget Rose Dugdale, 33-year-old daughter of an English millionaire, was sentenced to nine years' imprisonment here today for receiving 19 paintings known to have been stolen. Bridget Rose Dugdale
Africa in History: Themes and Outlines, by Basil Davidson (Macmillan, $6.95). Revised edition of a 1969 work. American Odyssey, by Robert Conot (Morrow, $14.95). A history of Detroit.

Bernard L. Barker and Eugenio R. Martinez, who go on trial in Washington tomorrow, accused of breaking into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, left their hometown here this afternoon virtually penniless.

John McLaughlin's newly incarnated Mahavishnu Orchestra played for the first time in Manhattan on Monday evening at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, and let neither the onslaught of rain nor the reservations of a few critics stop it.

Herbert Frutkin, a long Island real-estate man, was arrested yesterday on charges of paying a bank officer approximately $20,000 so he could fraudulently borrow $355,000 From the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company in 1972 and 1973.
Rev. Kenneth L. Dean, a white who helped Mississippi blacks gain civil rights in the nineteensixties, won the Democratic nomination in the Fourth Congressional District in a runoff today.

Chanting demonstrators pushed into the lobby of the Veterans Administration Building in downtown Newark yesterday to protest local procedures in aiding veterans and to call attention to a four-day national demonstration planned for Washington beginning next Monday. Demonstrators gathering outside the Veterans Administration offices in downtown Newark yesterday A detective, left, with cigar, getting a demonstrator out of the building after he had pushed into the lobby.

The Mexican Government has ordered a price freeze on all basic consumer products until Jan. I in a bid to combat inflation that is running at 22 per cent. It also agreed to study a labor demand to link wage increases to the cost of living.
The winner of the first Tournament Players championship, beginning Aug. 29 at Atlanta, will be exempt from qualifying for next year's United States Open, golf officials said today.

A few hundred Spanish monarchists stood on a rain-drenched lawn in nearby Estoril yesterday and shouted "Long live the King!" at a tall man long frusfrated in his ambition to be ruler of Spain. Don Juan de Borbon

The stock market turned bullish yesterday although analysts insisted its rally was just technical. The Dow-Jones industrial average added 12.52 points to close at 828.85, This was its high point for the day and marked the largest single day's gain since the Dow rose 15.17 points on June 6.

The publisher of a forthcoming "autobiography" of Marilyn Monroe, titled "My Story," said yesterday the book was written by the late Ben Hecht. Sol Stein, president of Stein and Day, said Mr. Hecht originally wrote the manuscript for Doubleday in the mid-fifties on the basis of several interviews with the late star.

The Hughes Tool Company announced yesterday in Houston that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Byron Jackson, Inc., a subsidiary of the Borg-Warner Corporation, under approxicately the same terms as first proposed last Dec, 20.

The quiet beauty still clings to this little place, hidden at the end of a fjord and sheltered by mountain peaks. But occasional sounds, as emphatic at the crack of ice off the front of a glacier, forecast the human flood that is only months away. In Valdez, Alaska, the serenity is broken by the sounds of people and machines preparing for the oil pipeline

The W. T. Grant Company, which had a 78 per cent decline in earnings last year and a $6.9-million loss in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, announced the resignation yesterday of Richard W. Mayer as chairman and chief executive officer. In addition, Edward Staley, the previous chief executive, resigned as a director. Harry E. Pierson

Two representatives of the United States Government have cautioned the world's natural-gas exporting countries to keep prices realistic and supplies secure if they expect to sell up to the United States.
Frank F. Shulock, a textile broker and specialist in the sale of surplus fabrics, died in his office Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 425 West 23d Street.

Trapped in a crumbling credit market, the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company sold $250-million of debentures yesterday at a record yield of 9.5 per cent. It was the highest yield ever paid on any Bell System issue and exceeded the previous record, 9.35 per cent, on $100-million of debentures sold by the New Jersey Telephone Company on June 16, 1970.

To the Editor: Today at the supermarket, two rib lamb chops are $1.54. At the same time, cattlemen complain that they don't get enough price to continue production. So they run to the Government to put on a "promotion" campaign to get rid of the "excessive" meat supplies backed up between production and sales.

The Loews Corporation reported yesterday increased net income for the third fiscal quarter ended May 31, but a decline for the nine months despite a $4.4-million income from the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation.

Governor Byrne of New Jersey normally can count on legislative margins of three to one in support of his major proposals, but the state's political history made it certain that he would face an uphill fight when he decided last month to press for a long-needed state income tax.
When the Newport Jazz Festival, a triumph of logistics dealing with a breed always on the move opens here Friday, it will find a city steeped in the art it loves.

United States District Judge Harry Pregerson submitted Robert A. Maheu's $17.3-millinn defamation suit against Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation to a six-member jury shortly before noon today on the 69th day of trial.

Canned Heat, which opened at the Bottom Line on Monday and plays through tonight, dates to 1965, when it was one of the first and best white blues bands. Aside from its blues and rhythm-and-blues recreations, Canned Heat was the archetypal party band, fun and full of good times.

William E. Long, a pianist who entertained trans-Atlantic passengers on vessels of United States Lines and American Export Lines, died Monday of cancer at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 88-01 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

The lessee of West Side Towers, a single-room-occupancy hotel at 230 West 76th Street, says he plans to begin renovations next month to convert it into a studio building. The rents will be $250 or more a month, he said.
A new concept in neighborhood planning, epitomized by a series of "miniplans" tailored to the needs of individual communities, is being inaugurated by the City Planning Commission.
Dr. Edward Little, a leading researcher on the Arctic ice fields and on polar survival, died Saturday. He was 76 years old.

The International Whaling Commission approved measures today designed to insure that no species of whales face extinction, but there was no indication that the two leading whaling nations would abide by them.

If baseball's annual All-Star game has any excuse for existence, it is the opportunity it creates to present on one field the 18 players the fans most enjoy watching. When the late Arch Ward, sports editor of the Chicago Tribune, thought it up as a promotion stunt for his paper,

The House Judiciary Committee decided today, despite bitter and bipartisan dissent, to make public as soon as possible virtually all the evidence assembled for its investigation of President Nixon's conduct in office. Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, talking to Walter Flowers, an Alabama Democrat, before yesterday's session of the committee began.
The city's mandatory plan to increase jobs for minority workers on federally subsidized city projects went into effect yesterday.
American and Mexican agents have made the largest seizure of marijuana in United States-Mexican border, the Drug Enforcement Administration announced today.
Over the last three weeks, Israel has been borrowing $300-million in the United States through an unusual issue of securities guaranteed by the United States Government.

The newly elected school hoard for District I in Manhattan held its first successful public meeting last night, although the session was marred by long delays by supporters of the Hispanic minority bloc and by the audience.

The Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973, which President Nixon signed into law on Jan. 2 and which provides a means by which the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads could become part, of a new taxpayer-supported railroad, was found unconstitutional in part yesterday by a special three-judge Federal court in Philadelphia.

The office of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, is reviewing the court records of 150 narcotics cases in the five boroughs where defendants, convicted of felonies before the more stringent laws took effect last September, may have been sentenced illegally and, in effect, set free.

Controller Harrison J. Goldin, disclosed yesterday that, in keeping with a campaign promise, he was considering how to make New York City notes available to small investors. Last year, when the authorities in Khartoum captured eight "Black September" gunmen who had tortured and killed a Belgian and two American diplomats, the Sudanese Government condemned the outrage and promised to bring the criminals to justice. The Sudanese Foreign Minister called the brutal killings "a criminal act" to be prosecuted and punished. Sudan's President Nimeiry himself denounced the barbarous deed on television.

The Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and 92d Street, considered a national dance center in the nineteen-forties and fifties has announced its "aim to revive that center" and invited the Jose Limon Dance Company to become the institution's resident dance company.

The Carbon Fuel Company said yesterday that it had signed a contract with a minimum duration of 15 years under which all coal produced at its West Virginia operations would be sold to the United States Steel Corporation, effective last April 1. The company's West Virginia operations produced about 1.8 million tons of metallurgical coal during 1973 and Carbon Fuel plans to increase production to 3 million tons annually by 1977.

Among the best of the strengthening amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act approved by Congress this year was one aimed at ending the shameful exploitation of children on the nation's farms. It prohibited the hiring of boys and girls under 12 to work on large farms, a limitation so modest that its enactment should have come long before agribusiness had all but abolished the family farm.

In private meetings as well, Mr. Nixon gave the allies assurances that he would protect their interests in his Moscow talks with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

In an atmosphere of public tension, the Cabinet met today to consider what help it might ask from other Arab nations to defend Lebanon against possible new Israeli attacks on Palestinian centers within her borders.

Dr. Henry M. Dater, historian and principal chronicler of United States Antarctic operations since their beginning in 1947, died yesterday of cancer in Washington. He was 65 years old. Dr. Dater, a native of Brooklyn, received a bachelor's degree from Yale in 1931 and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in history in 1936.
A strong movement challenging the Roman Catholic Church's ban on divorce has emerged in Portugal as a result of the revolution in April.

The South African Government announced today that it had turned down a request from Hassan Howa chairman of the Black Crickel Board of Control, for a passport to attend a meeting of the International Cricket Association in London.

John Clifford, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who has staged eight of his own ballets for the company, will leave the troupe at the end of the season on Sunday.

President Nixon will nominate six new members to the National Science Board of the National Science Foundation and will reappoint two others, a White House announcement said today.

In the best monthly advance so far this year, chain-store sales in May registered a gain of 14.2 per cent over the level of May, 1973. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte as Chief of State could mean a gradual easing of the repression in which Chile has been held since the overthrow of President Salvador Allende's Marxist Government last September. Tuesday's advances on the American Stock Exchange and over-the-counter market proved short-lives as prices fell yesterday. Investors seemingly have become convinced that the rise in the prime interest rate has not halted.

Canada announced today the sale of 74.6 million bushels of wheat to China, one of the largest single contracts she has ever made. The sale, for an estimated $350-million, rings China's total purchases of Canadian wheat for 1974 to 112 million bushels, firmly establishing China, along with the Soviet Union, among Canada's major wheat customers.

Dr. Kurt Salomon, who retired in 1962 as professor of radiation biology and biophysics at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, died June 17 in Lagos, Nigeria. His age was 76.

The most popular open international tournament in the world, though only two years old, is in Monte Carlo each June. This month it attracted close to 100 American competitors, as well as players from most European countries.

The girl, Margaret Fox, had placed an ad in a newspaper seeking such jobs. Her parents said she had received calls from a person identifying himself as John Marshall, asking her to baby-sit Friday and then postpoining the job until Monday.

The House Agriculture Committee approved by a 27-to-2 vote today an emergency $2billion credit-relief measure for livestock producers, including sheep and goat raisers and corporate livestock operations.

With labor demanding big wage increases to "catch up" to the cost of living, the two months since Federal wage-price controls expired have brought a round of collective-bargaining settlements of 8 to 10 per cent a year-and more-and a big increase in strikes.

The stock market managed--but just barely--to keep above the 800 level on the Dow-Jones industrial average in yesterday's trading. The index closed at 802.41, off 1.25. Earlier it had fallen to 799.05 and then managed to rebound to 801.16, up 2.50 at 11:30. Observers insist that 800 is a support level that creates almost automatic reaction.

Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has decided., to change Iran's longstanding option on the Concorde supersonic airliner into a firm order for three, according to a report circulated here tonight. But confirmation was not immediately available.

In the last year or two the steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America have been making a zealous joint effort to persuade the country of their social responsibility in avoiding strikes and heightening productivity. The specter of competition from foreign steel made cost-consciousness a mutual concern, with clear benefits for the economy.
Corporate profits rose slightly in the first quarter even after adjusting for the "inventory profits" resulting from inflation, revised Commerce Department figures disclosed today..

Sydney H. Lane, who had his own insurance brokerage concern here until his retirement a few years ago, died yesterday of complications following surgery. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 Hutchinson Avenue, Scarsdale, N. Y.
The House passed by 311 to 10 today a health research training bill that would also create a national commission on medical ethics and put a temporary ban on research involving the human fetus.
The Sucrest Corporation, a major sugar refiner and marketer, announced yesterday that it was reducing the price of industrial sugar by 55 cents on a 100-pound bag, effective July 3.
Eight persons, all apparently members of the Pagans motorcycle club, were arrested by the police in Nassau County and in Queens in two separate incidents yesterday and last night.
The downward slide of prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market continued yesterday, for the third day in slightly stepped up but dull trading.
James J. Caulfield, who retired in 1970 after 41 years as a pressman for The New York Times, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 163 Forbell Street in Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

Some 4,400 nurses who had struck 43. northern California hospitals for three weeks returned to work this morning after ratifying a two-year agreement here' last night. A spokesman for the California Nurses Association said the agreement had been approved by a vote of 1,670 to 494.

The new chairman of the Franklin National Bank said yesterday that the financially troubled bank was writing off an additional $11.8-million in loans as losses, and had sold a large volume of Government securities at an additional loss of $2.2-million.
Forrest Gerry Jr., who was convicted in Brooklyn Federal Court on May 31 on both counts of a sports-bribery-conspiracy charge, yesterday had his sentencing postponed until next Friday.
The International Whaling Commission concluded its 26th annual convention today, having taken at least one small step toward saving the world's largest creature from extinction.

President Nixon and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, moved today toward an agreement to reduce the ceiling on antimissile defense systems permitted under the treaty they signed here two years ago.

Premier Mariano Rumor awaiting the outcome. of a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies in Rome yesterday. Mr. Rumor later won the vote.

The contempt conviction of Meyer Lansky, alleged financial wizard of organized crime, was reversed by a Federal appeals court today. Mr. Lansky, 72 years old, was convicted last year of failing to answer a subpoena issued by a Federal grand jury in Miami. He was sentenced to serve a year and a day in prison, but has been free' on bail pending his appeal.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos signed a sweeping amnesty decree today, offering a pardon to Moslem rebels who lay down their arms and cease fighting for independence in the southern Philippines.
Samuel Rabin, an associate judge of the State Court of Appeals and the Republican designee for election to that post in November, withdrew from the race yesterday.

Nissen, owned and ridden by Valerje Monnett of Honolulu, made his' first start on the summer, circuit a successful one by winning the small junior working hunter championship today at the Middlesex County Horse Show. Jidda winning first race yesterday at Aqueduct.

Separate indictments against two father-and-son teams accused of mail-order frauds totaling nearly $1.6-million were returned by a Federal grand jury. today. More than 100,000 people. throughout the United States were said to have been bilked by the alleged schemes.

Robert L. Lewis, president of the Robert Lewis Travel Service here, died Thurday in I Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 53 years old and had I lived in Stamford, Conn.

Harry Browne during his lecture at Carnegie Hall.

Chinese foreign policy experts see no harm in President Nixon's trip to Moscow. They expect the American President is merely seeking diplomatic achievements but will not sacrifice the interests of the United States or Europe. Agreements reached in Moscow, the Chinese think, may sound important, but will have as little effect on the world situation as the signing of a dozen agreements during Mr. Nixon's last visit.

For more than a decade, most efforts to curb nuclear arms have focused not on the weapons but on the missiles and the delivery systems that place atomic bombs on target. Recently, however, there has been a growing realization that, as the nuclear era began with an explosion in 1945, the arms race cannot be halted nor can the nuclear power balance be stabilized without ending nuclear explosions.

Evidence emerged at the 26th annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in London last week that the 15 member nations, succumbing to world opinion, were giving priority to the survival of the whale over the interests of the whaling industry.
A group of Soviet Jews has begun a protest hunger strike in Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia, which President Nixon is to visit tomorrow, informed Jewish' sources said today.

In center field at Damaschke Baseball Park, where six years ago Amos Otis, the Kansas City Royal star, was snaring flies for the Oneonta Club in the New York-Penn League, a Scottish deerhound snared the best-inshow honors today.

Gene W. Setzer, after 10 years as chairman of the board of directors of the National Audubon Society, has resigned the post to join the administrative staff as a vice president to take part in day-to-day decisions.

The National Women's Political Caucus, created three years ago with the goal of attaining more political power for women, voted today to change its basic membership structure and to increase its dues tenfold in an effort to build a more effective National organization. Maya Miller, Democrat from Nevada, one of two women still running for a seat In the U.S. Senate.

John A. Moore of Lakeview, L. I., was arraigned on charges of murder, arson, burglary and robbery in connection with the beating and burning death of Mrs. Hanna Hansen, the 74-year-old woman whose body was discovered June 15 by firemen responding to a fire in her Lakeview home.

At a stroke of the pen, some 25,000 acres of coastal marshland rich in wildlife, history and natural beauty have been spared potential exploitation and instead marked forever as a heritage for future generations of South Carolinians and all Americans.
Bill Shoemaker sent Agitate, the favorite, to the front early and kept him there to win the $111,300 Swaps Stakes for 3-year-olds at Hollywood Park today.
A low-paid black service worker in Chicago, mother of six, could not recall her union's name last week nor was she cheered by two 15-cent hourly raises that the union had won her.

Two young Pennsylvanian experts captured the open pair title here Saturday night in the New York-New Jersey regional championships. Heading a field of 48 pairs were Billy Gough of Oreland and Phil Brady of Philadelphia.
More than 32 million Social Security and adult welfare recipients will be getting higher Federal checks in July, but many also will be billed more for their medical care.

The Democratic party wrapped up a 21-hour television fund-raiser yesterday with songs, patriotic pleas and gibes at the Republicans. Nearly $7million in pledges were tallied.

Gaye Kelly's chances of becoming this resort's first female lifeguard have been wiped out in a raging sea. A wave knocked the 17year-old Atlantic City girl out of her lifeboat as she neared shore Friday after successfully rowing a 300-pound boat out into the surf in a. competition for 10 lifeguard jobs.

On taxes, the Administration is talking out of both sides of its mouth, and in the middle as well. The President's new economic "czar," Kenneth Rush, says the Administration might want a tax increase to balance the fiscal 1975 budget. Chairman Stein of the C.E.A. says this is "a possibility but not a probability."

Julius H. Berman, a retired restaurateur who had formerly helped operate the Claremont Inn on Riverside Drive, the Merry England restaurants at the New York World's Fair in 1939-40 and the Tavern-on-theGreen in Central Park, died Thursday oh a visit to Gettysburg, Pa He was 83 years old and lived at 181 East 73rd Street.

The chairman of the House subcommittee on immigration has accused the State Department of "seriously" impeding investigations of suspected Nazi war criminals and ignoring the Justice Department's requests for cooperation.

Marcus Wayne Chenault Jr. Marcus Wayne Chenault Sr., the suspect's father, waved newsmen away from his Dayton home.

The work of close to 300 contemporary American craftsmen is readily available to residents of Greenwich, Conn., thanks to Kay Eddy, Betsy Beasley and Emily Toohey, owners of The Elements. Sexwicke cups are priced at $20 each at The Elements in Greenwich, Conn.

Bob Murphy regained the Long Island amateur golf championship, which he won in 1970 and 1971, when he beat Gene Francis, the 1973 champion, in the 36-hole final today at the Plandome Country Club. Murphy came from 2 down after 16 holes to win the match. I up.
High energy music was heard from both stage and audience Saturday at the ShaeferMusic Festival. LaBelle started everything grooving, and Mandrill continued the momentum.

The American Medical Association has ended a six-day meeting here with new leadership and new challenges for action in the next year.

Herbert W. Kalmbach will go to prison tomorrow. carrying what a friend described as a "deep hurt" over President Nixon's apparent displeasure because of Mr. Kalmach's decision to cooperate in the Government's prosecution of the Watergate conspiracy. Herbert W. Kalmbach

It was just a little more than six years ago that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis. The civil rights leader was shot on April 4, 1968, at the age of 39, as he stood on a motel balcony in Memphis, where he had gone to support striking sanitation workers.

After Poland defeated Yugoslavia, 2-1, at Wald Stadium today and took a giant step toward reaching the World Cup soccer final in Munich next Sunday, the question was how many more surprises the Polish players had in their soccer boots. The Ethiopian armed forces said today that they had been arresting officials of the previous Government for conspiring to obstruct the four-month-old administration of Premier Endalkachew Makonnen.

Changes in the City Charter to limit the city's power to grant raises, increase the number of employes and to borrow. money, except for capital as-. sets were urged yesterday asways of halting the continuing, rise in the municipal budget.

The Bolshoi Ballet is behaving as if it were business as usual on the fourth visit to London of the first company. And certainly it is appearing before sold-out houses with prices at a fat top of $21.50 for an orchestra seat.

BUDAPEST - Buttressed by unprecedented prosperity and an atmosphere of contention on how national profits shoul`d be spent, Hungary's Communist trade union organization is seeking recognition by Western counterparts as an authentic labor movement. Sandor Gaspar, head of the Hungarian Trade Union Organization, would welcome contact with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

A woman named Knox got on a No. 6 bus on a recent rainy Friday, taking with her a small pocketbook and a red shopping bag, and settled down for a long, dull ride to 12th Street. When she got there, she ran into a grocery to buy orange juice, realized that she had forgotten the red shopping bag, and ran back to the street to look for the bus. It was, of course, gone.

The revolution in communications in the last decade requires Congress to bring the Copyright Act of 1909 into the 1970's. Technological advances in cable TV systems, photocopying machines' and computers are ingenious; but this hardware cannot function without the so-called soft ware, a technical term ironically standing for nothing less than the creative works of writers, editors, playwrights and composers.

A 3-year-old Bronx boy was bitten and seriously injured by a St. Bernard dog yesterday while chasing a ball. The youngster, Anthony Bryant, was rescued by his mother, Meta, who also suffered bites of the legs and arms while wrestling her son from the large dog's jaws, the police said.

Many students and their parents face tax questions if the children take summer jobs. Depending on what he earns, the student probably will owe little or no tax, but there still is paperwork.

Mrs. Carole Jo cause the Skala dropped a 25-foot putt for an eagle on the 460-yard eighth ,hole today and totaled an 11-under-par 208 to finish first in a 54-hole Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opens its 65th annual convention tomorrow in an area where there is strong resentment of the organization's position on the integration of state colleges.

The people of this steam. ing, grimy city 720 miles from New Delhi seem to regard India's new nuclear potential as just another Hindu trick. The Government of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto continues to issue angry statements about India's detonation of a nuclear device six weeks ago and the press dutifully prints them.

Two Brooklyn law secretaries, one of them also the secretary of the Democratic County Committee, are under investigation for allegedly siphoning some $50,000 from the organization's funds for their own use, political sources said last night.
An effort to save Florida's coconut palms will be started in July with the use of an antibiotic that may arrest the spread of the tree disease called lethal yellowing.

The four Justices whom President Nixon named to the Supreme Court have solidified into a bloc that is increasing in both unity and capacity to produce a working majority for their views of the law and the Constitution. Warren E. Burger William H. Rehnquist Lewis F. Powell Jr. Harry A. Blackman
Venezuela implemented one of its announced oil price and tax actions yesterday, raising export prices moderately for crude oils as well as refined products, including gasoline,
The prospect of having to leave Bissau when Portuguese Guinea becomes independent makes the hearts of Portuguese soldiers and officials here beat faster in happy anticipation.

The value of building contracts during May was the highest for the year despite a substantial decline in the construction of housing units, the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, reported yesterday.

The sportive bottle-nosed dolphin that moved into Mattawan Creek in Keyport on May 27 was apparently killed by rifle fire ad stabbing this weekend. The carcass of the nine-foot female was found floating in the creek at 11 A.M. yesterday, according to the New Jersey Marine Police.

Mrs. Else Fritz Reif, a couturiere in Vienna, Stockholm and from 1940 to 1950, on Central Park South, died yesterday in Vancouver, British Columbia. She was 87 years old and the widow of Oskar Reif, who was killed serving in the Austrian army in World War I.

Brecker was still a student at the University of Pennsylvania, he had a mind for business (he was at the Wharton School), he and his girlfriend Dorothy (later his wife) loved to dance, and he was convinced that Philadelphia wouldn't be such a sleepy place if it had a really nice ballroom. The Federal Government wound up fiscal 1974 with the budget approximately balanced. This is not a consequence of prudent planning but of inflation. When the Administration prepared the budget for the fiscal year that ended yesterday, it projected outlays at $268.7 billion and receipts at $256 billion, for a deficit of $12.7 billion. But inflation has caused revenues to rise nearly enough to wipe out that deficit. Expenditures have risen very little.

Today, less than four months after the end of the Arab oil embargo, there is a decided surplus of oil in the world. This surplus, variously estimated at between 1.5 and 3 million barrels a day, is putting downward pressure on prices.
Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival- New York: 2 P.M., Pope Auditorium, Fordham University, Columbus Avenue and West 60th Street. Milford Graves Trio and Teo Macero Cotton.

Golda Meir, the former Premier, gave up the last trappings of office today when she moved out of the official residence. She left with a handful of clothes, giving a word of thanks to a neighbor who always kept her phonograph turned down.

High pressure recruiting and athletic scholarships are usually reserved for the football and basketball standout. Occasionally, an outstanding athlete comes along to excite the less-publicized, nonmoney-making recruiting world. Such was the case of Walter Wilson, who will attend the University of Kentucky on a $2,500-a-year swimming scholarship in September.

Hubert Williams, the police lieutenant and lawyer nominated by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson last week to become the city's second black police director, is expected to receive the Municipal Council's approval this week with relative ease.

A 37-year-old doctor from Australia, was fatally shot last night during an apparent holdup in the Riveria Hotel in Jamaica, Queens, the police reported. Three other persons, including a bellhop, were robbed.

With a little help from his friends and teammates in the field, Mike Cuellar prolonged the New York Yankees' frustrations against lefthanded pitchers today by beating them, 3-0, before a crowd of 21,176.

A bountiful harvest of winter wheat is nearing it peak in Kansas, and the combines will soon be moving northward into Nebraska to cut the crop there. But this year a new element is changing the usual patter in which wheat has moved from field to grain dealer to flour miller.

Dr. H. Harry Giles, a retired professor of education at New York University, who founded its Center for Human Relations Studies, died Saturday in a hospital in Fall River Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in nearby Westport Mass.

In center field at Damaschke Baseball Park, where six years ago Amos Otis, the Kansas City Royal star, was snaring flies for the Oneonta Club in the New York-Penn League, a Scottish deerhound snared the best-inshow honors today.

A low-paid black service worker in' Chicago, mother of six, could not recall her union's name last week nor was she cheered by two 15-cent hourly raises that the union had won her. "It's worth nothing when they take out taxes," she scoffed.

LONDON-A harried-looking woman pushed a ticket under the window of the change booth in the Notting Hill Gate underground station. "May I return It, please?" she asked politely; "I have waited 45 minutes for a train and I cannot wait any longer." She was given her money back.

Harry B. Nason, a former managing editor of The New York Post, died Friday of cancer in Will Rogers Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old. Mr. Nason started his newspaper career in Philadelphia, where his father was an editor and executive of The Inquirer for more than 40 years.

Henri Pescarolo and Gerard Larousse of France, winners of the Le Mans 24-hour auto race, won a 1,000kilometer event yesterday in Zeltweg, Austria. Their victory, at an average of 124.7 miles an hour, expanded the lead of Matra-Simca in the world automobile manufacturers championship.

Sally Bowden and Roy Berkeley are both low-keyed, easy performers with a great deal of presence. On Saturday at the cavernous Blue Dome Rehearsal Hall on the Bowery, she danced and he sang in a duet that showed how naturally they work together.

The conflict between the judicial process and the insistence of journalists who protect news sources enters a new phase Tuesday. William Farr, the 39-year-old Los Angeles Times reporter who has fought a three-year legal battle, may be returned to jail once again for refusing to identify the sources of a 1970 article he wrote, this time before a Los Angeles County grand jury.
Three men were arrested shortly after midnight today at the Brooklyn home of Ludwig G. Glowa, chief administrative judge of the City. Criminal Court, and charged with burglary, the police reported.

The announcement of his death was made by his wife, Vice President Isabel Peron. She assumes the presidency, becoming the first woman chief of state in the Americas. [1:7-8.]

The Soviet Union clinched first place in the International Team Tournament by defeating the Philippines 31/2-1/3 in the 14th round. With one round to go, the Russians have run up 431/2 points for an insurmountable 71/2-point lead over the second-place team, Yugoslavia.

The House Administration Committee tentatively approved today a major campaign spending bill after reversing itself and authorizing the use of limited public funds to help finance Presidential primary elections.

In a statement issued here Mr. Nixon said: "At a time when others would have been content to retire from public life, he accepted the challenge to return to his country to guide and assist the Argentine people. The Royal Bank of 'Canada raised its base interest rate for lending United States dollars in Canada today to 13 per cent from 12.5 per cent, effective tomorrow. The bank said the action was prompted by rising interest rates that it must pay on dollar deposits.

Last night's "The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson," shown on public television from 8 to 9, was the first in a series of public-affairs programs that will be produced under a new co-production arrangement between Washington's National Public Affairs Center for Television (NPACT) and the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Leon Jaworski said today that the Watergate grand jury had named President Nixon as an unindicted co-conspirator so that any evidence he might have would be admissible in any trial of members of the alleged conspiracy.

The House voted today to extend the life of the ExportImport Bank for 30 days pending passage of more permanent legislation. The vote was close, with a two-thirds majority required passage was by 238 to 115.

The 174-vear-old Boston Naval Shipyard, the oldest in the nation, shut down today. An invocation, the lowering of the flag and the playing of the national anthem marked the closing ceremony.

Johnson Johnson, the New Brunswick-based manufacturer and worldwide marketer of pharmaceuticals and healthcare products, disclosed today that it had invested more than $1.5-million toward the purchase of real estate in downtown New Brunswick.

Attacks by savings bankers on a proposed offering by Citicorp of $850-million of 15-year notes continued yesterday. The United States League of Savings Associations urged the Federal Reserve Board to "dissuade" Citicorp from making the offering.
The rates of Treasury bills mixed today as the Government borrowed a total of $4.5-billion at its weekly sale of short-term securities.

A new method of "bargain sale" on state of Texas oil and gas leases brought in dozens of new independent oil companies today, and the Texas School Land Board collected $24,686,448 in cash bonuses, even at the reduced prices. It was the largest sale in bonuses collected since 1965.
Former Chief Justice Earl Warren was hospitalized today for the second time in six weeks and was reported to be in fair condition with a heart ailment.
Premier Olafur Johannesson, who took office in 1971 as head of a majority coalition of leftists, resigned today in the wake of a leftist setback in general elections Sunday.

The delinquency rate on savings-bank home mortgages climbed during the first quarter of 1974, while the foreclosure rate remained steady, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The association's latest quarterly mortgage delinquency survey showed that the number of delinquent loans equaled 0.59 per cent of the total number of home mortgages held by savings banks at the end of March.

Stephen Smith, the brotherin-law of the late President John F. Kennedy, was arrested, handcuffed and charged with theft of services early yesterday, the police said, after he allegedly refused to pay a 60cent taxicab fare.

Alfred Eisenpreis, the city's Economic Development Administrator, said yesterday that he expected to have in operation this summer the city's new Industrial Development Corporation, which was authorized by a bill signed into law two weeks ago by Governor Wilson.

Use of the posters, which accuse high party functionaries of "revisionism," are seen by some as an attempt to repeat the Cultural Revolution of 1966.

A heavy pounding of both glamour and blue-chip issues yesterday forced the stock market to its lowest level of the year. The Dow-Jones industrial average plummeted 15.56 points to 790.68, its lowest level since Dec. 5, 1973, when the index stood at 788.31.

Fourth of July holiday travelers should have little trouble finding gasoline, the American Automobile Association said today. It said that its spot checks of 5,224 stations in all states except Alaska had found slight improvement in the number of stations open after 6 P.M. on weekdays and on weekends.

Top officials and auditors of the Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas have been named by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a case that the agency says involves "massive and serious violations of the securities laws."

Lee Trevino heads a surprisingly strong field for tomorrow's early start in the $130,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.
A hospital union has paid $300,000 toward a $723,500 fine imposed for contempt of court in a one-week strike last November against voluntary hospitals and homes.
A Federal court denied today Charles G. Rebozo's plea for an order barring the Senate Watergate committee from either inquiring further into his affairs or citing him for contempt.

For the second time in a month, State Representative Stephen Rapp of Waterloo scored an apparent victory tonight in the Democratic race for Iowa's Third Congressional District nomination.

William Farr, the Los Angeles reporter who has fought a three-year legal battle to protect his news sources, again avoided jail today when a Superior Court judge vacated a contempt order against him.

Manufacturers inventories continued to rise strongly in May, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase, which amounted to $2.33-billion, or 1.8 per cent, brought total inventories to $130.76-billion at the end of May.

Representative Hugh L. Carey, who is campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was greeted in friendly fashion as he made a meet-the-people walking tour of 34th Street during the lunch hour yesterday.
Three Roman Catholic organizations urged Congress today to prohibit the inclusion of abortions as a family planning measure in any national health insurance plan it adopts.

The Labor Department imposed racial hiring plans today on building contractors in 21 areas of the country. The department said the action was taken after the Office of Federal Contract Compliance found that construction unions in the areas had "failed to meet their employment obligations" under voluntary minority-hiring plans.

Texaco, Inc., said yesterday it had purchased three supertankers from the A. P. Moller Group, a Danish shipping company. The ships are of the 285,000-ton class and industry sources estimated their total cost at more than $200-million. Texaco expects to take over control of the ships in 1975 and 1976.

American television newsmen charged today that the Soviet television network had censored outgoing newscasts on Soviet dissidents. Gerald L. Warren, a White House spokesman, said, "It is the White House position that the networks should be able to send anything they wish."

Vic Dickenson, a trombonist who is a master of the sly slur and a virtuoso with the rubber plunger mute, has enlivened so many groups led by other jazz musicians that it was particularly pleasing to find him leading a group of his own yesterday afternoon at one of the free concerts in Pope Auditorium of Fordham University that are part of the Newport Jazz Festival.
The Ford Motor Company today raised prices of its cars and trucks an average $58, the second of the United States auto makers to change price tags since steelmakers increased their charges last week.

In 15 classrooms throughout Appalachia yesterday, a total of 300 teachers watched a color television presentation on how to teach children about adult careers. It was the first instructional television program to be broadcast directly via a space satellite.

A century ago the seventh Duke of Devonshire decided to finance construction at Cambridge University of of a small laboratory for research in physics. He named it for his ancestor Henry Cavendish, who in the 18th century had been able to "weigh the earth" by determining its mean density.

Murrel J. Ades, a retired distilling industry executive who had been president of the International Distributing Corporation of Washington, from 1955 to 1967, died Monday in Miami Beach of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

Tom Wicker, in a recent column, wrote about the Volvo plant in Kalmar, Sweden. The Saab experiment preceded Volvo's endeavors by almost four years.

The Assembly Taxation Committee rejected today a revision of Governor Byrne's state income tax plan that would have levied extra taxes on high incomes. It decided to submit to the full Assembly next Monday the more moderate graduated scale originally proposed by the Governor.

The indictment yesterday of C. Arnholt Smith on charges of conspiring to misappply $170-million in bank funds was the latest in a series of setbacks that have marked the California banker's slide from power in recent months.

Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia declared a mistrial yesterday in the case against Herbert K. Despite attractive profits in the last two quarters, oil industry gains may be turned into losses by a number of factors, economists at the First National City Bank said in a report prepared for release today.

State Supreme Court Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg ordered that, pending a further hearing next Wednesday, landlords of 100,000 rent-controlled apartments need not return money they owe their tenants under a recent law enacted by the city. The law repealed so-called laborcost rent increases of up to 4 per cent a year and it made the repeal retroactive.

With the addition of Jim Lago of Lyndhurst, Tony Lakawicz of Elmwood Park and John Nashmy of Bergenfield, the Bergen County Men's Bowling Association Hall of Fame numbers 22 members. The three newcomers were inducted at a special awards dinner on June 21.

Dr. Edwin John Stringham, a composer and musicologist who was the first instructor in music criticism at the Columbia University School of Journalism, died Monday at his home in Chapel Hill, N. C. He was 83 years old.

Many brokers and most investors appeared to have tried to stretch the July 4th holiday into a long weekend as volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday fell to its lowest level in more than two years.

The striking National Football League Players Association won a victory of sorts today in its three-day-old strike when Dan Goode, one of the San Diego Chargers' first-round draft choices, left the training camp and joined the picket line.

Gunfire between policemen and rioters continued for the third night tonight while Premier Sanya Dharmasakti and his Cabinet met in urgent session to decide on measures to end the violence that has plagued Bangkok's Chinese district. CHICAGO--The task of selecting a persuasive and representative survey of contemporary American art has never been more difficult than at the present moment. People entering the current exhibition at the Art Institute of Chicago find, at the entrance, Andy Warhol's portrait of Mao Tse-tung. It is more than 14 feet high.

Seven of nine manufacturers of paper labels and eight individuals indicted by a Federal grand jury in San Francisco in a criminal price-fixing case last March have pleaded no contest before United States District Judge Charles B. Renfrew.

The leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today, for the second year in a row, quashed a move from the convention floor calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

Litton Industries said today it planned to liquidate its Hewitt-Robins plant after unsuccessful attempts to sell it. "We're seeking a buyer for the principal assets," a Litton spokesman said. "We're talking with people who've expressed interest."

A Federal District Court judge refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction sought by the Staten Island Rapid Transit system to head off a strike threatened by 36 railroad policemen and track maintenance workers. They plan to walk off their jobs at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

A Federal judge in Connecticut has ruled that an elderly German-born immigrant who said he had been misinformed by Federal officials on his eligibility for Social Security could not collect six years of back pavments.

Philip F. Berrigan, the antiwar activist, was arrested today on the street outside the White House as he sat shackled in a simulated "tiger cage" prison cell. The cage, a 3-by-8-by4-foot structure used in South Vietnam, was mounted on a flatbed truck and was on display.

AT the midpoint of every year, the spirits of businessmen are normally uplifted in anticipation of a faster-paced second half and the American public's sentiments are usually buoyed by the advent of holiday and vacation pleasures. But not this time. The nation's mood is vastly different in this summer of 1974. The business world is tense and cautious. Investors are edgy.

A 17-year-old youth scheduled to start work tomorrow for the city's Youth Services Administration was shot in the head and killed late Friday night in quiet Owls Head Park in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

BOSTON IN no other painter of the 19th century-not even in Manet or Cezanne-is the notion of "tradition" at once so boldly affirmed and yet so drastically revised as it is in the work of Edgar Degas. He belongs, without question, to the great line of avantgarde masters who made of French painting in the 19th century the principal fulcrum of modernism.

WHEN Darius Milhaud died the other day, the obituaries made a point of his having written more than 400 works. As well they might. Prodigality of that sort is anything but typical of 20th-century composers, and the Frenchman's output made him something of an anachronism.

Mrs. Francoise Taylor Beck and Gerry Harkavy, both of New York, were married last evening in the garden of the house they rented in Bedford, N. Y., for this month. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

While Watergate and related scandals continue to dominate the front pages, today's inflation is the preoccupying issue for most Americans. The two subjects are not unrelated, of course. While Watergate is sapping public confidence in political institutions, inflation-rapid and persistent-is altering economic foundations long taken for granted. Americans are disoriented, bewildered and increasingly resentful of this two-pronged assault on their security.
Emperor Haile Selassie blamed corrupt government officials today for the crisis that led to an army takeover of Ethiopia.

Vermont's bottle deposit law has survived its first year despite attempts by soft-drink and beer wholesalers and by retail grocers to win repeal in the legislature or to persuade the courts to declare it unconstitutional.

Amtrak, the national rail passenger network, said last week that it would restore through-car service between New York and Chicago on the former route of the Twentieth Century Limited across New York State.

THE exhibition of picture postcards currently at the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University, in Hempstead, Long Island, is such a good idea it makes one marvel that nobody ever thought of it before. Called "Wish You Were Here" and organized by the gallery's director, Robert R. Littman, the show contains about 2,000 postcards ranging in provenance from Victorian England to present-day Ogden, Utah.

VACATIONLAND--Maine is the largest of the six New England states-almost as large as the five others put together. The deteriorating situation in Northern Ireland clearly demanded a fresh initiative from the British Government. A hospital technician calls an epileptic at work 30 miles away. The patient is told to increase his anticonvulsant medication. Review of his electroencephalogram, transmitted from an inconspicuous recording monitor attached to his scalp, had warned of an impending seizure.

The Toyota Motor Company's net profit plunged 73 per cent in the half-year ended May 31 to $33.5-million from $126.9-million a year earlier, the Japanese auto maker said today.

Scientists say further solar disturbances during the next two days will continue to allow people in the northern United States to view the northern' lights, a shimmering, multicolored spectacle usually reserved for Polar dwellers.
The Supreme Court upheld to day the conviction of a marine who prepared a statement critical of United States involvement in Vietnam.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it has extended its cash tender offer for shares of common stock of the Brown Company and the Madison Square Garden Corporation until 5 P.M. July 31, unless further extended or terminated earlier.
James H. Higgins has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Mellon National Corporation, the holding company for the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh. James H. Higgins

The Newport Jazz Festival's idea of building the second of its two midnight jam sessions, held early Monday morning at Radio City Music Hall, around a singer, Diana Ross, seemed to be a contradiction in terms. For one thing, Miss Ross, a former member of the Supremes, is not known as a jazz singer.

Terry Chow, left, teaching a staff member at Beekman Downtown Hospital how to prepare a Chinese meal.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell yesterday to their lowest point in four years in increased trading. Prices also fell in the over-the-counter market on heavier volume.

The Rev. Dr. Howell P. Lair, a Presbyterian missionary educator in Tsinan in China's Shantung province from 1913 to his eviction in 1950, died Saturday in Duarte, Calif., where he had headed a church retirement home. He was 89 years old.
Don Herrmann, who made it the hard way in professional football, will not join the picket line of established players at the New York Giants training camp in Fairfield, Conn., this morning.

Doc Schmitt has been quietly making his presence known at Aqueduct, where he has been compiling a good record with horses that are hardly of the expensive variety.
Mrs. Paul F. Wilson, who was detained 12 days ago with her husband, a missionary, has been released by the Philippine martial law Government, church sources said today.

Japan's voters have administered an unexpectedly sharp setback to Premier Kakuei Tanaka and the LiberalDemocratic Government in a record turnout for elections to the upper house of the Diet. This is the major significance of the voting even if final returns give the ruling party, in office for the last quarter-century, a slim majority in the 252-seat House of Councilors.

A traveling panel of Federal officials seeking comment on proposed regulations to combat sex discrimination in federally financed schools drew criticism from representatives of women's groups at a forum here yesterday.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Liberal party won overwhelmingly yesterday in the Canadian national elections. Robert L. Stanfield, left, Conservative leader, in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and Prime Mininister Pierre Elliott Trudeau after voting in Ottawa yesterday.
Columbia Gas Systems, Inc., one of the nation's top utilities, was unable yesterday to raise $50-million on an issue of preferred stock because of the general disarray in the money markets.

DuPont Gore Forgan, Inc., the lingering shadow of H. Ross Perot's short-lived venture on Wall Street, is likely to "button up and go away" if it doesn't get some business soon, Morton H. Myerson, chairman and chief executive, said in an interview yesterday. H. Ross Perot
The Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he had told North Vietnam that North Vietnamese troops still in Laos must leave under the peace agreement that ended the Laotian war.

Dr. A. L. Loomis Bell, a radiologist who had practiced in Brooklyn until two months ago, died Monday at Bridsboro, Pa., at the age of 84. Dr. Bell, who for about 50 years maintained an office at 142 Joralemon Street, received his medical degree from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1916.
The Nixon Administration criticized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today for using its power to persuade the Government to extend its monopoly in communications.

Nancy Newhall, a noted photography critic, conservationist and editor of many works by America's best-known photographers, died Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Jackson, Wyo., the result of injuries she received in a boating accident on June 29. She was 66 years old.

International airlines tentatively approved yesterday the fifth increase in United States-Europe air fares of the year, but cushioned effects on some travelers by voting a new "early bird" discount plan for those who buy tickets at least 60 days before a trip.

The struggling parents of New York City's liberals lived in tenements at rents they could afford and were linked to a social and cultural neighborhood network. As they worked their way up, they had no fear of losing their homes to the government bulldozer.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau met privately with some of his advisers today to begin deciding how to use the sweeping new power that the Canadian voters gave him in yesterday's parliamentary election .

Exactly when it happened nobody knows, but there came a time in the life of the city when prostitution became more open than it had been before and when the city's sensibilities about it changed, too. Prostitution is a mean operation, and it has been with us forever; the difference now is that we more or less expect to see it around.

A marine scientist who was startled last December to find that sewage sludge dumped into the Atlantic Ocean had flowed to within half a mile of the beach here found the sludge today as close as a quarter of a mile. Edward Wilensky of Brooklyn College displaying a sample of the sludge taken about one mile offshore.

At a time when democratic institutions are in retreat or under heavy pressures almost everywhere and when weak, minority governments are the rule rather than the exception throughout the Western world, the significance of the decisive outcome in Canada's general election can hardly be exaggerated.

A silver spade full of earth was languidly turned over by Mayor Beame in an open courtyard of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday and construction of the new American Bicentennial Wing was under way.

The Export-Import Bank will begin using a range of interest rates on its loans running from 7 to 8 1/2 per cent, its chairman, William J. Casey, announced today. Mr. Casey said at a news conference that the rate on each loan would depend on a number of factors.

PARIS--President Tito of Yugoslavia is now in Bucharest conferring with Nicolae Ceausescu, his Rumanian colleague, and although-as neighbors, unorthodox Communists, and highly independent-minded leaders-they are always interested in each other, this time they have more than usual to discuss. The main burden of their colloquy: What to do in a time of troubles?

The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League beginning here Friday at the New York Hilton and Americana Hotels are virtually sure to be the biggest tournament ever played anywhere. The record of 16,043 tables set last year in Washington is expected to be broken by at least 1,000 tables.

" Jambo, jambo, jambo," intoned Evelyn Jones Rich, a courteous Africanist, bidding her listeners good day in Swahili. Her greeting was just one of the dozen ways that ethnic consciousness is being brought home this week to the more than 11,000 librarians who have gathered here for the 93d annual convention of the American Library Assocation, the country's main organization of librarians.

Wyse Advertising of Cleveland opened an outpost here about seven years ago in hopes of siphoning off some of the millions and millions of dollars from the national advertising budgets that are controlled from New York. Lois Wyse
Italy's powerful labor front started a series of strikes today to protest against the new taxes that the Government decreed Saturday in an austerity effort aimed at staving off national bankruptcy.

Governor Byrne, in a pink summer suit and tieless in the broiling afternoon sun, took a boat tour of Cape May County inlets and beaches today. His objective was to see what erosion has done to South Jersey beaches and to determine what he could do about helping a fellow Democrat defeat Representative Charles W. Sandman. Governor Byrne is shown erosion of Ocean City beaches by William Hughes

The offer by the GL Corporation-a private investment company-to buy up to 1.5 million shares of the Cerro Corporation presents the Cerro holder with a classic dilemma in today's depressed stock market. That is, the shares have been much higher than the tender price of 19 in recent years, but this is well above what Cerro shares commanded before the tender was announced.

The Government said today that it would establish a nationwide toll-free telephone line on which the estimated one million American children who run away from home each year will be able to pass messages onto their parents without disclosing where they have gone.

Following is the text of a comparison, made by the House Judiciary Committee, of selected passages from transcripts prepared by the committee and by the White House of eight of President Nixon's Watergate conversations. The comparisons are preceded by a foreword by the committee chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

The proposed construction ?? a shopping mall in a ravine area of Douglaston. Queens, came up against another roadblock yesterday with a ruling by the state placing the ravine under the protection of the 1973 Tidal Wetlands Act.
France exploded two nuclear weapons at her South Pacific testing ground over the weekend, not one as reported by Australia and New Zealand, French military sources said today.

The United States sold some $8.5billion in arms for the fiscal year that ended last month, almost double the arms sales for the previous fiscal year and almost $2-billion more than all the arms sold or given away by all nations in 1971, according to official Pentagon estimates.

" Next time I'll probably stop and think twice," Raul Cubero told a visitor yesterday as he sat in a wheelchair in the intensive-care unit of Brooklyn Hospital, where he is recuperating from a gunshot wound in the stomach. "I guess you learn from experience."

A Federal judge yesterday refused to suspend the threeyear sentence of Judge Otto Kerner, a former Governor of Illinois, and Theodore Isaacs, his former revenue director, for bribery, mail fraud and income-tax evasion, Judge Otto Kerner leaving U.S. court in Chicago.

The Administration is studying a proposal that would help to broaden the equitycapital base of banks participating in the Eurodollar market, aid in recycling Arab oil revenues and give United States banks a more competitive footing in the Euromarkets.

Harold H. Shapiro, who had been a reporter on The Long Island Press and earlier with The Long Island Star-Journal for the last 18 years, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 49 years old and lived at 143-43 41st Avenue, Flushing.

The new, reform-oriented leadership of the United Mine Workers union resolved a prolonged internal struggle today by announcing its support of the stronger of two Federal bills to control strip mining scheduled for a vote next week in the House.

After the New York Mets lost to San Diego, 5-4, before a crowd of 19,264 at Shea Stadium last night Yogi Berra had this to say: "We came close, but that only counts, of course if you're playing horseshoes," said the Mets' manager.
Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has asked for "clarification" of parts of Governor Byrne's tax-reform program before he gives his long-awaited public endorsement.

Nixon Administration officials said today that they were seeking a formula to avoid a serious confrontation with Turkey over the Turks' decision to resume cultivation of opium poppies, the source of most of the illegal heroin sold in the United States until production was forbidden in 1971.

A mail-order concern specializing in poster-size enlargements of photographs has been ordered to speed its service and to make restitution to customers who demanded refunds after delays in service. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said that the concern BY'U Inc., also known as Congers Color Labs and Blow Yourself Up, Co., of Congers, N.Y., had failed to aeliver their products in a reasonable time even when the consumer paid an extra charge for "superspeed service."

Never mind about hemlines and other trendy matters. George Stavropoulos concentrates on clothes, especially evening clothes, of everlasting allure. Which means an emphasis on chiffon, with layers on layers for the skirt and a plethora of capelets, scarves and panels to wrap snugly or to float freely, setting up a constant commotion as the wearer moves. Top, a George Stavropoulos style for evening; bottom, a dress by Giorgio di Sant'Angelo.

The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company announced yesterday that it would pay death benefits to the family of a man who was shot to death last October as he pursued a berserk gunman.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday but the gap between the number of those declining and those advancing narrowed somewhat compared with the day before as volume dipped slightly. The closing price, however, was the lowest since July 7, 1970 when it was 74.60 Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

Chancellor Helmust Schmidt of West Germany and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France ended two days of talks today, and the West German leader said they had achieved farreaching agreements on the major problems facing Western Europe's Common Market.
An appeals court has overturned a Federal judge's order that was designed to release defendants from jail without bail unless they received speedy trials in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
Two defendants in the Watergate cover-up trial asked the Supreme Court today to disqualify United States District Judge John J. Sirica from presiding.

Carol Beinbrink and Mrs. Phebe Dempsey of St. George's Golf and Country Club scored a two-over-par 74 over the 5,515-yard Maidstone Club course today and lead the annual women's Long Island Golf Association better-ball championship by six strokes.
President Nixon was critical of President Eisenhower's handling of a scandal during his Administration that led to the dismissal of his chief of staff.

Justice Thomas J. Ryan of the State Supreme Court, presiding justice of the Eighth Judicial District, died today at his home. He was 55 years old. Justice Ryan graduated from Canisius College and the University of Buffalo Law School. He was a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation for five years before resigning to practice law.

Las Vegas bookmakers are taking a cautious approach to the new World Football League. Except for tomorrow night's televised game between the New York Stars and the Jacksonville Sharks, no opening-game action is being handled in Las Vegas. The Sharks have been quoted as 6-point favorites, but tonight's five games aren't on the board.

The Coast Guard commandant today recommended the prosecution of a Connecticut yachtsman who allowed two crewmen to jump into frigid waters off the coast of New Jersey while keeping his dog on a small skiff after their schooner had capsized. The two crewmen drowned.

Morris I. Charlap, the composer who wrote the music for Mary Martin's television version of Barrie's "Peter Pan" in 1953, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived at 4 East 62d Street.

Herbert Loewenthal, retired bankruptcy judge in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday at Manhattan Veterans Hospital, First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 76 years old and lived at 888 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
President Nixon's chief defense lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today that he did not know whether the President would obey a Supreme Court order to turn over subpoenaed White House tapes.
Potential swimming-pool buyers are faced with a "massive illicit market peddling junk merchandise at grossly exaggerated prices," according to a spokesman for the National Swimming Pool Institute.

Over the objection of Paul O'Dwyer, President of the City Council, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved a $5-million payment to prevent a halt in work on the 14-mile-long water tunnel being built from the Hillview Reservoir in Westchester County to Astoria, Queens.

Yes, Virginia, there is World Team Tennis. And yes, Virginia Wade, as the newest member of the New York Sets, the crowd is allowed to hoot, holler and yell as they did tonight when you dropped your Nassau Coliseum singles debut, 6-3, to Mrs. Nancy Gunter of the Cleveland Nets.

The one question now holding up conference agreement on this year's extension of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act is, substantively, the least important question of all-but, emotionally, the most acute: the question of busing. All of the other issues between House and Senate on the legislation which would authorize $25.2 billion to help educate American children over the next three years have been resolved.

The council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization sharply criticized the Netherlands today for planning to cut its armed forces by 20,000 men. A communique said the move would weaken NATO and impose extra burdens on other member countries.

The 17th Festival of Two Worlds came to ts traditional close in Spoleto's Cathedrall Square last evening is Thomas Schippers conducted he youthful Festival Orchestra U.S.A. in Mozart's Requiem in ?? Minor.

Olivares of Mexico City became the first former bantamweight champion in 34 years to win the featherweight title tonight by stopping Zensuke Utagawa of Japan in the seventh round of their scheduled 15-round World Boxing Association championship bout.

Ralph Nader and an associate, Carl E. Nash, asked the Federal District Court here today to roll back the average ceiling price on controlled crude oil from the present $5.25 a barrel to $4.25, its level last Dec. 19 when the Administration authorized a $1 increase.
At the government's request, Judge Barrington Parker of the united States District Court dismissed today one of three perjury counts against Lieut. Gov. Ed reinecke of California.
The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would increase the price of unalloyed 99.5 per cent primary aluminum ingot 2.5 cents a pound to 36 cents, beginning with shipments Aug. 2.

Children who enjoy such games as Monopoly and tiddlywinks, but wish they could devise their own board games too, will have their chance soon. The opportunity to experiment in the atmosphere of an exhibition and workshop is being offered by the New York Public Library at the Central Children's Room of the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street.

City garbage collectors continued a wildcat strike today for the ninth day as a circuit court judge granted an injunction against workers in three other sections of their union who walked off the job in sympathy yesterday. Some 3,000 city workers are now on strike.
The stock market engaged in a-holding action yesterday, going nowhere on a volume of 15,580,000 shares, compared with 15,510,000 shares on Monday.

Leon Shamroy, who won the Academy Award for cinematography four times, died Saturday in the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 72 year old.

Dr. Arnold John Zurcher, professor emeritus of political science at New York University and executive director of the Sloan Foundation from 1945 to 1968, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was stricken while swimming in Long Island Sound off New Rochelle, N.Y.

OTB revenue to the city, state and racetracks declined by $473,000 during the first week of the new 5 per cent surtax on winning payoffs, the president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation said yesterday.

A proposal to handle Westchester County's worsening garbage-disposal on a countywide basis was approved unanimously tonight by a committee of the Board of Legislators, indicating quick approval by the full body and early implementation.

Robert Langdon of Oratory Prep or summit round broken egg after dropping box from dormitory roof.

Seven United States Naval Academy midshipmen have been expelled for cheating, and 13 have been placed on probation as the result of a scandal that began seven weeks ago with the leaking of questions on a final examination. Superintendent William P. Mack at news conference
Earl Warren, who as Chief Justice of the United States presided over extraordinary constitutional change, died tonight at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 83 years old. Earl Warren
An offering by Citicorp of $850-million in a controversial and novel type of security, scheduled for sale today, has been postponed, banking sources said yesterday.

The American astronauts of the joint Apollo-Soyuz mission, winding up three weeks of training with Soviet astronauts here, reported today that the crews were progressing well together-and even working in each other's language-since their first meeting a year ago.

The United States sold more than $8.5-billion in arms in the fiscal year 1973-74, almost double the sales of 1972-73, according to official Pentagon estimates. This surge, many officials say, has been at least as much for economic reasons as to meet defense and diplomatic requirements. The bulk of the sales has been to the Middle East and the Persian Gulf area. [1:5.]

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says he is amending proposed Federal regulations against sex discrimination to allow separation of boys and girls in sex education classes.
Carol Channing at drawing of post position for Roosevelt International. With her are, from left: Del Miller, Jean Riaud and Jene-Rene Gougeon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - During his presidency, Georges Pompidou pursued a constant strategy on behalf of a definite policy. The policy was to promote France's industrial development, under the guidance and with the help of the state, while softening the resulting social change with subsidies and tax advantages for the groups most hurt by it: peasants, small shopkeepers, independent workers.

J. P. Morgan Co. Inc., the holding company that owns the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifthlargest bank, said yesterday that its net operating earnings for the second quarter rose 22 per cent from the equivalent period last year.

VOICES FROM ABROAD Well, not exactly too far abroad. But the Newark Boys Chorus has been gathering esteem for each of its eight years of existence, with enormously well-received world tours, including a special concert last year before Pope Paul VI at the Vatican. Today it's crossing the Hudson River for a free concert downtown.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that the state had acted against two abortion referral agencies that had been accused of using "bait" advertising and of charging fees for abortion referrals, which is specifically forbidden by state law.

Estimating that as many as 1,000 schoolchildren might have been killed if the severe tornado outbreak of April 3 and 4 had struck Xenia, Ohio, during school hours, United States weather officials have requested extra spending this year on tornado warning systems.
Citing the "unconscionable cost" of borrowing and asserting that "near panic" exists in the money market, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday rejected the sole bid on a sale of city bonds.
