The tempting fallacy is to anticipate that the Supreme Court will now finally "decide Watergate," once and for all. Increasingly skittish Congressmen look across the Capitol lawn to the Court for rescue from politically perilous decisions. An exasperated electorate longs for it all to end, sensitivity to public right and wrong dulled by the charges, counter-charges, the ambiguities real and contrived. However deeply desired, Watergate cannot simply be made to go away.

The House Judiciary Committee, plodding through apparently inconclusive questioning of witnesses at closed hearings, will be unable to meet its tentative deadline for completing the impeachment inquiry, the committee chairman said today. William O. Bittman, former lawyer for E. Howard Hunt Jr., testifying at impeachment inquiry. At rear are James D. St. Clair, left, and John McCahill, White House lawyers.

OUR SOUTHERN LANDSMAN. By Harry Golden. 241 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $7.95. Harry Golden, the Jew from New York who went South more than 25 years ago and, through his Carolina Israelite, dispensed his pickle-barrel khukhmas, or accumulated wisdom, to the cracker-barrel country, has never lost the sense of wonderment that seizes the provincial New Yorker on his forays beyond the city line.
Husky Oil, Ltd., has been appointed by a Federal court to operate the California properties of the troubled Home-Stake Production Company, Husky's president, James E. Nielson, announced today.

Judge John J. Sirica denied today a wide series of defense motions for dismissal, for separate trials, for moving the proceedings out of Washington and for delaying the start of the Watergate cover-up conspiracy case.

New York City's two major Jewish philanthropic agencies. have merged in an effort to increase the effectiveness of their fund-raising. The two groups are the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, which was established in 1939, and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, which was formed in 1917.
Labor and management in the port's longshore industry reached agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract, which includes a guaranteed annual income of $16,640 in the pact's final year.
On the last stop of his European tour, Secretary of State Kissinger today initialed a new declaration of military cooperation between Spain and the United States.

George Burns of Port Washington, L.I., has done lust about everything an amateur golfer can do in the New York metropolitan area. When he took the 22d annual Ike tournament by a two-stroke margin at Wheatley Hills Golf Club today, he won his fifth major amateur tournament in the area.

Having just completed an explosive four-game stand in Texas where they staged a 59-hit, 37-ran bombardment, the Yankees opened their three-game visit with the Royals tonight by detonating a six-run, first-inning rally. Graig Nettles is congratulated by a Yankee teammate, Gene Michael, after hitting grand-slam homer.

The 12member energy coordination group, made up of major oilconsuming nations, reported substantial progress during meetings in Brussels yesterday and today toward working out the details of an emergency oil-sharing system.
President Hugo Banzer Suarez has swept civilian politicians out of his Cabinet and promised a return to constitutional rule next year.

Senator'Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that there would be "a very positive effect on the world's economy" if President Nixon "stepped down." But he added that the same effect might be obtained if Congress acted quickly on the question of impeachment.

Drawbridges jammed, highways buckled and utilities fought to meet power demands as a hot, humid blanket of air smothered the entire East Coast with 90degree temperatures for the third straight day yesterday. Fireman attempting to wash away oil spilled when Con Edison transformer exploded

Safeway Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest food chains, continued its upward profit trend of the first quarter with an increase of 30.6 per cent in earnings in the second quarter. This brought the company's half-year net up by 32.7 per cent.

The National Transportation Safety Board disclosed yesterday that a National Airlines DC-10 suffered dangerous damage Monday when cowling tore from the left engine, smashed into the wing and knocked out the rear engine.

John D. Ehrlichman completed today more than seven-hours on the witness stand, repeating his denials that he knew in advance of the break-in at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist. Mr. and Mrs. John D. Ehrlichman arriving at courthouse yesterday in Washington with their children. From left: Tom, Bob, Jody, Peter and Jan. Mr. Ehrlichman finished testifying in his defense in the "plumbers" trial.

That old saw, "Those who can, do; those who can't, teach," doesn't apply to Tony Fusco, the personable professional at the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club. The 40-year-old Fusco has taught here for seven years, helping hone the talents of such local high-ranking juniors as Bill Csipkay and Jane Lennon, as well as numberless Sunday players.

The Spanish Government announced today that General issimo Francisco Franco had been hospitalized for treatment of phlebitis in his right leg. Generalissimo Francisco Franco being greeted by Dr. Murioz Calero upon his arrival at hospital in Madrid.

Worldwide sales of the Volkswagen group in the first half of 1974 declined 17.5 per cent from the 1973 period, Rudolf Leiding, chairman, said today, to 1.02 million vehicles. Poor sales and sharply rising costs make a loss in 1974 a distinct possibility, he told the annual stockholders meeting here.
H. R. Haldeman, President Nixon's former chief of staff, is seeking $1-million through an agent for rights to a book he is writing about his years in the White House.

Still another view of "Apollo," George Balanchine's seminal neoclassic ballet of 1928, was provided on Monday night at the State Theater when American Ballet Theater presented a new cast headed by Daniel Levins and Kim Highton.
Mario Andretti, who has been having trouble finishing races this season, will start three this weekend. Johnny Rutherford, who said after winning the Indianapolis 500

George Burns of Port Washington, L.I., has done just about everything an amateur golfer can do in the New York metropolitan area. When he took the 22d annual Ike tournament by a two-stroke margin at Wheatley Hills Golf Club today, he won his fifth major amateur tournament in the area.

Israel's latest raid on fishing ports in southern Lebanon was regarded here as restrained in comparison with the threats of violent reprisal issued by Israeli officials after a Palestinian guerrilla raid from the sea on the beach resort of Nahariya two weeks ago. Residents inspecting the damage to fishing boats in Tyre, Lebanon, after raid Monday night by Israeli commandos

The setback suffered by the governing Liberal-Democratic party in Sunday's upper house election continues a trend of well over a decade in which the conservatives have steadily lost popularity but still hung on to their control of the Government.
The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to merge the General Crude Oil Company into a subsidiary of International through a $437million purchase
The Nixon Administration criticized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today for using its power to persuade the Government to extend its monopoly in communications.
President Lon No1, declaring that Government troops had made major progress aginnst negotitaions today "Without prior conditions."

It was the best of seasons, it was the worst of seasons. Theater seasons are like the weather. They always seem more dramatic after a few decades of contemplative retrospection. When we were young, the summers were hotter and the winters were colder. Theater seasons were better, too. It is, as everyone knows, the atom bomb that has done it.
Twelve jurors and six alternates were selected today as five Cuban refugees went on trial in the kidnapping of 8-year old John Calzadilla from a street near his home in Dix Hills, L.I., last March 6.
The City Council yesterday approved a bill banning smoking in passenger elevators, but another environmental matter--sound pollution--was set back when the Council

In an attempt to preserve what is left of country greenery in New York City, the Planning Commission yesterday proposed a new zoning concept, the Special Natural Area District, and moved to designate the Staten Island greenbelt as the first such protected area. An aerial view of part of the Staten Island's Todt Hill area. New zoning would protect island's natural areas. At the right is St. Francis High School of the New York Archdiocese.
Protesters seeking a meeting with President Nixon to discuss veterans affairs locked themselves in a White House rest room and the Washington Monument today.
By the latest Government estimate more than ?? Americans have something painful in common with President Nixon and Generalissimo Francisco Francophlebitis.

Two inmates of Trenton State Prison today charged in Federal District Court here that the State Department of Institutions and Agencies violated their rights by abruptly transferring them from Rahway State Prison following a mass meeting there last April.

A mutilated body found in the desert near the northwestern city of Hermosillo has been tentatively identified as that of a United States vice consul, John S. Patterson, who disappeared, apparently kidnapped, in March.

Seven United States Naval Academy midshipmen have been expelled for cheating, and 13 have been placed on probation as the result of a scandal that began seven weeks ago with the leaking of questions on a final examination. Superintendent William P. Mack at news conference

The New York City Council yesterday approved a bill banning smoking in passenger elevators, but voted to raise the permissible sound level for automobile horns. The smoking ban won out despite admission by its supporters that enforcement would, at best, be minimal. The change in horn noise levels was said to be needed as a safety factor.

Fulton County grand jury indicted Marcus Wayne Chenault today on two counts of murder and one of aggravated assault in the June 30 shooting at Ebenezer Baptist church in which Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. was killed.

Lancy Smith, medalist in the qualifying round, advanced to the second round of match play in the Women's Western Golf Association amateur championship today by defeating Pam Palmieri of Santa Rosa, Calif., 5 and 3. Miss Smith, of Snyder, N. Y., will face Mrs. Alice Dye tomorrow morning. Mrs. Dye, a nine-time Indiana state champion, eliminated Judith Oliver of Pittsburgh, 2 and 1.

Harold Ormond Burdick, whose hormone research played an important role in birth control for humans, and who was a retired chairman of the biology department at Alfred University died last night at his home. He was 77 years old.

Sir Harry Brittain, known for his lifelong service to Anglo-American friendship, died at his home this evening. He was 100 years old. In the nineteen-twenties, Sir Harry, then a member of Parliament, called for a reduction in trans-Atlantic telephone rates for at least one day each week to encourage calls between Britain and America. Sir Harry Brittain

A Federal judge ordered a Philadelphia-based airline today to hire male applicants for stewardess positions and to seek out previously rejected males who had sought such jobs but were turned down because of their sex.
Jody Taffet, a 19-year-old sophomore at Potsdam State Teachers College, today won the Syce Cup, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association women's sailing championship.

The House Judiciary Committee released today eight transcripts its staff had prepared of President Nixon's Watergate conversations, and committee members of both parties said that the marked differences from the edited transcripts made public by the White House Benjamin C. West, superintendent of the House Press Gallery, distributing copies of the Judiciary Committee's version of Presidential tapes.

A second group unveiled its bid yesterday for the laid-up liner United States to use her as a floating bicentennial exposition and trade fair. The group, calling itself S.S.U.S. Ship of State, to have the ship tour America's berthing it here permanently along Battery Park City.

Gaylord Perry's winning streak is over, and in the long run the player who ended it may become the better remembered of the two. After having won 15 straight games since an opening-day loss to the Yankees, the 35-year-old Cleveland pitcher was going for No. 16 at the Coliseum last night against the world-champion Oakland A's in chill and rain before a Family Night crowd of 47,582.
Labor and management in the port's longshore industry reached agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract, which includes a guaranteed annual income of $16,640 in the pact's final year.

A marine scientist who was startled last December to find that sewage sludge dumped into the Atlantic Ocean had flowed to within half a mile of the beach here found the sludge today as close as a quarter of a mile. Edward Wilensky of Brooklyn College displaying a sample of the sludge taken about one mile offshore.

An agreement was reached today to end a work slowdown by Nassau County bus drivers that had forced 65,000 riders to find transportation alternatives since yesterday afternoon. Scene at terminal in Hempstead, L. I., during strike yesterday by drivers of Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority

The Appellate Division, citing trial errors by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh, yesterday ordered a new trial for a former city police officer convicted on an indictment brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

Keith Wilkes has come out from the shadow of Bill Walton, his former teammate at the University of California, Los Angeles, to sign a multiyear agreement with the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association. The Warriors, who had made the 6-foot-7-inch allAmerica forward their top college draft choice this year, signed him yesterday. Keith Wilkes

A State Controller's study has found serious deficiencies in the state's prisoner-rehabilitation programs and has identified the failures as a factor in growing criminal recidivism. The study found a lack of educational, job-training and drug-treatment programs and inadequate diagnostic services to channel prisoners quickly into the appropriate aid programs.

While throngs filled the concerts of the Newport Jazz Fes tival over the last week hundreds of other jazz lovers crowded into Studio Rivbea in the East Village to hear some of the country's most innovative and exciting musicians play their best.

David G. Trager, the New United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, has given the assistants in his office who live outside the district an Oct. 1 deadline to move into it, but at the same time has urged them to question the constitutionality of the district's residency requirement.

The New York Rangers and the City of Long Beach today signed an agreement under which the Long Island community will provide practice facilities for the National Hockey League club. The Rangers' general manager, Emile Francis,

The State Environmental Protection Commissioner today announced an expanded priority list of facilities to control water pollution in New Jersey that will more than double the number of sewage-disposal projects eligible for Federal financial aid during this fiscal year. David J. Bardin, Environmental Protection Commissioner, announcing projects in Trenton.

The army issued a set of guidelines tonight for the future government, retaining Haile Selassie as Emperor, but with reduced powers, and giving the military a major role in important Cabinet decisions.

The Dominican Government's negotiations to obtain higher revenues from the Aluminum Company of America on its bauxite exports here have broken down, Government officials said today. They hinted that the Government could decide to follow neighboring Jamaica, which unilaterally increased her royalties 500 per cent. The country is also seeking alumina production facilities. Aluminum is made from alumina, which is made from bauxite.

The tiny tribe of Havasupai Indians has a reservation in a side canyon of Grand Canyon. The tribe-fewer than 300 persons live on this reservation-principally makes a living by guiding tourists on muleback to see the spectacular waterfalls in its canyon.

The General Electric Company improved on its recordbreaking first-quarter pace through the first six months. The giant electrical manufacturer reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for both the second quarter and first half. A generator rotor forging at General Electric's generator shop in Schenectady, N. Y. Concern reported new sales and earnings records for the second quarter and first half.

Alfred B. Leech, public relations manager for Allis-Chalmers and a former editor of Newsweek magazine and former reporter for United Press International, died Sunday. He was 56 years old. Mr. Leech, who joined AllisChalmers in 1962, was with United Press for 15 years, leaving the news service to join Newsweek in New York in 1958.
Elmer Wayne Henley Jr., sat unmoved in a crowded courtroom today as the state built up its case of homosexual torture and multiple murder against him.

Howard J. jury Samuels, the designated Democratic candidate for Governor, was endorsed today by the Albany County sheriff, John J. McNulty Jr., one of the few Democrats with a political power base in this area who is not loyal to the Albany County Democratic machine led by Daniel T. O'Connell.

The United States sold some $8.5billion in arms for the fiscal year that ended last month, almost double the arms sales for the previous fiscal year and almost $2-billion more than all the arms sold or given away by all nations in 1971, according to official Pentagon estimates.
John A. Brogan, who played a major role in building King Features Syndicate into the world's largest feature-distributing organization, died Monday evening in Nassau, the Bahamas. John A. Brogan

Portugal's first effort at civilian government since the revolution in April collapsed tonight with the resignation of Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos and four of his middle-of-the-road ministers. Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos led resignations.

To the Editor: I wonder if all the testimony and hearings that are leading up to the great debate over the question of President Nixon's "high crimes and misdemeanors" will in the long run serve the best interests of the country.

The new Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs warned the oil-producing countries today that any cutback in production levels in an effort to hold up prices would be "counterproductive." Jack F. Bennett

A dozen Canada geese from a flock of 35 to 40 that had made their home in a pond on the grounds of the Sperry Gyroscope Company in Lake Success, L. I., suddenly became ill and died yesterday morning after the area was sprayed with insecticides.

Portugal's first effort at civilian government since the revolution in April collapsed tonight with the resignation of Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos and four of his middle-of-the-road ministers. Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos led resignations.
A Superior Court judge today sentenced three Black Muslims to life sentences totaling a minimum of 140 years in prison for each man.

The dye on the footballs may still be wet and the players may not be able to keep dry in the stifling heat, but the World Football League brings midweek, midsummer football to the nation's sports life tonight.
The authorities in this provincial capital declare that its security is "completely normal" and that everything is under control despite the series of bomb explosions set off in the last few months.

The British Government announced today that it would permit the phased release of suspected guerrillas held without trial in Northern Ireland.

A counsel appointed by a Federal District Court has submitted proposals for reform of the Dutchess County Jail that are aimed at restoring jailers' control over prisoners and enhancing chances of rehabilitating the inmates.
Potential swimming-pool buyers are faced with a "massive illicit market peddling junk merchandise at grossly exaggerated prices," according to a spokesman for the National Swimming Pool Institute.

Gov, Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, in a statement issued in Harrisburg, Pa., yesterday, said that there was "absolutely no danger of an immediate liquidation" of the Penn Central Railroad as a result of a recent ruling by Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia that the Penn Central should not be reorganized under terms of the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973.

Luis Tiant, who came to the Boston Red Sox as a free agent in May of 1971, has turned out to be one of Boston's best bargains. Last night in Fenway Park, the 33-year-old right-hander made two first-inning runs stand up for a 2-1 victory over the Texas Rangers. Sets' Virginia Wade playing with and without her jacket against Mrs. Nancy Gunter

The Jets welcomed their rookies into camp today, the coaches from their air-conditioned rooms and the striking players from their sunstruck picket line. Despite the 92-degree heat, no one tripped over the picket line and no one dropped a picket sign, not even the one that said, "Up the Oligopsony." Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill picketing at the Jets' camp at Hofstra
The State Supreme Court ruled today that the state must adequately compensate municipalities when it takes over public property for its own use.
President Nixon's chief defense lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today that he did not know whether the President would obey a Supreme Court order to turn over subpoenaed White House tapes.
Something odd has happened to local television programing involving minorities. A couple of years ago, public television, specifically Channel 13, could claim a virtual monopoly in the area.

On the way to Watergate trials on Pennsylvania Avenue and to the House and Senate on Capitol Hill these steaming July days, it is hard to avoid the contrast between the enduring symbols and ideals of the Republic and the petty maneuverings of the contemporary politicians.

Armed with new paper weapons and fired by increased public concern over the pillage of ancient sites throughout the world, the United States Customs Service is beginning an intensified crackdown on the smuggling of plundered art and artifacts into this country. Paul T. Tutone, an import specialist for. Customs here, examining an artifact recently.

Joseph W. Barr, the new chairman of the Franklin National Corporation, the parent company of the troubled Franklin National Bank, was in the Capital today seeking Administration and Congressional support for legislation that would permit an out-of-state bank to merge with Franklin. Joseph W. Barr

" Next time I'll probably stop and think twice," Raul Cubero told a visitor yesterday as he sat in a wheelchair in the intensive-care unit of Brooklyn Hospital, where he is recuperating from a gunshot wound in the stomach. "I guess you learn from experience."
In their fight to keep pace with inflation, many investors have increasingly turned to bonds paying high yields. For example, take the case of a high-grade bond known as XYZ Industrial 6's of '86.

With three deuces going to the turn, Gary Player scored a 69 today to share the first-round lead with a British ex-schoolmaster, whose only previous distinction in an Open came at Carnoustie in 1968 when he was bitten by a rat. Gary Player, above, and lack Nieklaus each hitting out of a bunker on the 15th hole in British Open yesterday.
Robert Hayes, a reputed member of the so-called Black Liberation Army, has received five prison sentences of 35 years to life for the attempted murder of five police officers.

Lines of cliffs running nundreds of miles across the surface of the planet Mercury may have been created by compression of moon-like outer layers following the shrinkage of a dense, iron-rich and earth-like planetary core, American space scientists reported this week.

A 2-year-old girl who the police said was trying to reach a toy on a sixth-floor fire escape yesterday fell to her death in the rear yard of the Lower East Side apartment house where she lived, at 361 East 10th Street. The child was identified as Tynaisha Gonzalez.
Rises in the cost of beef, pork, sugar and cola soda were mainly responsible for increasing food prices in the city last week by 0.5 per cent over the previous week.

The 1974 College All-Star game, plagued by the National Football League players' strike, was canceled today, marking the first time in its 41-year existence that the annual charity game will not be played. John McKay, College AllStar coach, talking yesterday to reporters about cancellation of the game.
A stirring, for independence has been shaking Portuguese Africa since the coup in Lisbon last April 18. But the issue is particularly complicated in this underdeveloped and overpopulated archipelago

" When we talk about big dollars and cents, men like to talk to men," said Carol Lane, age 32. And, when she and her associate, Miss Lee Frankel, 31, agree to do new product development for a company, it involves big money. The minimum fee is $25,000 plus out-of-pocket costs.
Secretary of State Kissinger's Western European travels, unlike his trips to Communist capitals and the Middle East, had a special personal flavor. It was a kind of class reunion.
The Thyssen - Bornemisza Group of the Netherlands will pay $27 a share for the outstanding common stock of Indian Head, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Because of a transmission error, a phrase and a sentence were omitted by The Associated Press from its transmission of the text of the treaty signed by President Nixon and the Communist leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, on July 3 limiting underground nuclear tests.

Ever since the World Football League was organized, cynics have wondered if it really would get off the ground. Let it be recorded that the New York Stars got off the ground today at 10:54 A.M. in their chartered Southern Airways DC-9 that deposited them here for their opening game against the Jacksonville Sharks tomorrow night.

The public television system has operated in a climate of crisis ever since the passage in 1967 of the Public Broadcasting Act which created the system without providing the permanent means of support.

A state park devoted to the creative and performing arts will open north of Niagara Falls on July 25 with a two-month season offering such attractions as Van Cliburn with the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, The theater at Artpark, north of Niagara Falls, N. Y., scheduled to open July 25

Good news is often hard to come by these days, but the energy crisis has produced at least one large silver lining. Principally as a result of the lower fuel-saving speed limits adopted by the states early this year, highway deaths have fallen off sharply.
Can you tell a candy bar by its wrapper? Not necessarily, unless you look closely, in the case of Baby Ruth.
The Senate today voted unanimously to give Congress veto power over President Nixon's plan to provide Egypt and Israel with nuclear reactors.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to prohibit the establishment of fast-food restaurants on residential blocks in the city, but cautioned that its action should not be construed as an attempt to limit the increasingly popular takeout operations on commercially zoned streets.
Mrs. Mary LaRosa Liebhafsky and Paul Kevin Rooney were married here last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton by State Supreme Court Justice Ernst Rosenberger.

Boris Spassky complained to me in Nice that he was in the wrong frame of mind during his disastrous semifinal candidates match with Anatoly Karpov in Leningrad this spring. "I felt depleted, devoid of creativity," the former world champion said.

The office that overseas the administration o the New York State courts modified its procedures to make judges responsible for filing reports of fees paid to lawyers and other guardians appointed by the court.

The executive committee of New Jersey's Federation of Senior Citizens Council charged today that Governor Byrne had "deceived and defrauded" the elderly of the state by turning his back on campaign promises too help them.
Attempts by a local newspaper to interview the families of jurors in the multiple murder trial of Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. produced a motion for a mistrial today.

The International Paper Company, the world's largest producer of paper, reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half-year in its 76-year history and the biggest percentage gains for any period.
Two Soviet astronauts today completed their first full week in space, most of it aboard the Salvut 3 spacecraft, and were in the best of health, The Tass press agency reported.
A pharmacist was shot and killed yesterday in a drugstore robbery at the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport.
Carl E. Kauffeld, retired director of the Staten Island Zoological Society and a widely known authority on snakes, died yesterday of emphysema at Richmond Memorial Hospital on Staten Island.
The House voted authority today for publication of 20,000 sets of its Judiciary Committee impeachment inquiry hearings and proceedings and 50,000 copies of the final report.

Have you been thinking more and enjoying less lately? Tired of cerebration and eager for celebration? If sans-souci is your goal, the place for you is the Little Hippodrome, the theater restaurant at 227 East 56th Street.
The American public continues to divide almost evenly on the question whether the Watergate scandal is "a serious matter" or "just politics," the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.
The defender, Dianne Wilde of Amsterdam, N.Y., defeated Paula Kern of Windsor today and advanced to tne second round of the 45th annual New York State women's amateur championship.

Saying farewell to friends is never easy. Sporting the casual clothes and hair styles and regional accents acquired in 10 months in this country, 2,500 foreign teen-agers kissed and held hands and sang together for the last time, preparing to return to 60 homelands. Audre Viljoon of South Africa saying farewell to Willy Jakulica of Argentina in Uniondale, L. I.

President Nixon personally decided against releasing a portion of a tape-recorded conversation on March 22, 1973, in which he discussed a cover-up of the Watergate affair, White House officials said today.

Avon Products, once among the most glamorous stocks, reeled yesterday in the. midst of rumors about its earnings results. for the quarter just ended, and a Chicago-based investment banking firm reportedly rated the stock a sell,

Arab oil ministers decided today to lift their oil embargo against the Netherlands, an act that brought public rejoicing in the Dutch port of Rotterdam. Taking part in the meeting of Arab oil ministers in Cairo yesterday were, from left, Ahmed Hilal of Egypt, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia and Mani Said el Eteiba of Abu Dhabi.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its 434 member firms lost $21.6million in May, less than half their April losses of $47.8-milnon and below the loss of $37.8million in May, 1973.
Official West German sources said today that Israel would be kept informed of the dialogue the Common Market was undertaking with Arab states to deal with the financial and supply problems of oil.
Edwin Fancher and Daniel Wolf, founders of The Village Voice, were removed yesterday as publisher and editor of the weekly newspaper, five weeks after it was merged with New York magazine.

The Soviet Union has asked Egypt to postpone until October a visit to Moscow by Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy that had been scheduled to begin next Monday, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

The defense in the trial of John D. Ehrlichman concluded its case today with testimony from President Nixon, whose sworn, written answers to six questions submitted by the defense were read aloud to the jury by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell. Secretary of State Kissinger leaving court in Washington after appearing as defense witness in "plumbers" trial

After montns or searching and screening, St. Peter's College announced today the appointment of Dick McDonald as its new basketball coach. McDonald, who has resigned as basketball coach at William Paterson College, succeeds Bernie Ockene, who died of a heart attack last April 26.

Italy's Constitutional Court ruled today that the Government had no right to ban cable television or booster stations that relay foreign programs into the country. An announcer at the Capodistria television studios in Yugoslavia. The station broadcasts in Italian.

John D. Ehrlichman repeatedly put pressure on the Internal Revenue Service to find something wrong with the tax returns of Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic party chief, hoping to "send him to jail before the election" of 1972,
New Yorkers received some measure of relief from oppressive temperatures as cool air began moving down the East Coast and eased the heat wave that had gripped the area for four days..

Proceedings were interrupted yesterday in 12 Manhattan Criminal Courtrooms when Legal Aid Society lawyers attented the sentencing of a colleague for criminal contempt and were not on hand when their clients were called for arraignment and hearings.

The staff of the Senate Watergate committee disclosed today what it described as additional information to support the charge that Charles G. Wakefield Herbert W. Kalmbach
The New York Giants will operate this season even if they have to use rookies or hold a tryout camp to recruit players, Wellington Mara, the club president, said today.

The new president of the Franklin National Bank met today with the chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, Representative Wright Patman, of Texas, who hinted that the troubled New York bank might be merged with an out-of-state institution.
The prosecution has demanded death penalties for the Korean poet Kim Chi Ha and six other persons on trial on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government of President Chung Hee Park.

The Government here announced today that it would use British technology in the development of the nation's nuclear power program and suggested that the public lacked confidence in American nuclear reactors.

McLEAN, Va.-Although no proof was probably needed, the agreements negotiated at the Moscow summit conference have demonstrated beyond a shadow of doubt that United States arms control goals have become hostage to impeachment politics.

Bill Bergey, free of a World Football League commitment, was traded within the National Football League today, going from the Cincinnati Bengals to the Philadelphia Eagles for three future draft choices.
Watergate has claimed another victim; a picture of the late Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn. Since 1966, his portrait has guarded the main entrance of the House office building that bears his name.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has ratified three-year contract with Local Technical Engineers, providing wage increases and other fits for operating and office employes, it was announced today.

Dean A. McGee, the 70year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the KerrMcGee Corporation, announced yesterday his resignation as a member of the board of directors of the Oklahoma Natural Gas Company-bowing to a move Denis Healey

Vice Admiral Vincent R. Murphy, executive vice president of the Navy Relief Society from his retirement from active duty in 1946 until his second retirement in 1962, died at Bethesda Naval Hospital, Bethesda, Md., on Tuesday.
A Federal grand jury began an investigation of possible criminal fraud in the operations of the Home-Stake Production Company, whose investors included well-known entertainment and business figures.

" Nothing that happens surprises me," said Reggie Jackson, star outfielder for the Oakland A's, yesterday when he learned that Manager Al Dark had released two coaches, Irv Noren and Vern Hoscheit, and hired Bobby Winkles and Bobby Hoffman in their place.
Mike Marshall, the Dodgers' ace relief pitcher, is working toward his doctorate at Michigan State University during the off season. His specialty is kinesiology.
Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler's Balbuco, a mount that has won major events all over North America, captured the featured open jumper class today at the Lake Placid Horse Show.

Pan American Airways and the Transport workers Union of America announced tentative agreement last night on new contracts covering 20,000 employes, averting a strike that had been scheduled to begin this morning. Dario Shindell, musician, actor and opera director, was found dead in his apartment at 45 East 66th Street on Tuesday. An autopsy is being conducted to determine the cause of death.

The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday told 13 rate bureaus representing the nation's big over-the-road truckers that they are free to increase their rates on 15 days' notice by 8 to 11 per cent. -Supplies of major oil products including heating oil, are much higher now than a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute said today. The House voted today to authorize a $200-million subsidy for Amtrak and to forbid the corporation from dropping any passenger trains for another year. In addition to the subsidy, the bill authorizes Amtrak to borrow $500-million with Government backing, bringing its total Government-guaranteed loan authority to $900-million.

While Dan Goich 'walked the picket line at the New York Giants' training camp today, Andy Robustclli seized on the opportunity to use the defensive tackle as an example in his blast at the players' strike for freedom. Coach Bill Arnsparger shouting encouragement to two rookies, Albin Zsdesar (dark jersey) and Steve Crosby during workout at Giantsi camp-in Fairfield, Conn.

Sanitation Commissioner Robcrt T. Groh yesterday swore in two deputy commissioners, Walter J. Hinckley and Ralph F. Demarco. Mr. Hinckley has been deputy health Commissioner since 1973. From 1968 to 1970 he was inspector general of the Sanitation Department.

The energy crisis-a fading memory to most Americans --produced a special group of winners and losers, people whose livelihood depends in different ways on. energy. Through events that none of them could have predicted or controlled, some of these people were able to turn last winter's shortages to their profit, while others were plunged into a personal nightmare from which they have yet to awaken.

To the Editor: Arthur S. Weinberg's July 3 letter reflects some confusion as to why industrial managers might apply job enrichment. It is not convincing to state - as in effect he does - that Swedish industry acts only from humanitarian concern while United States industry acts only to increase productivity.

Prices declined as volume rose slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. In the over-the-counter market prices closed mixed. The Amex market-value index fell 0.35 to 74.62 yesterday as volume reached 2,228,000 shares compared with 2,144,000 shares the day before.
Supplies of major oil products including heating oil, are much higher now than a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute said today.
Sidewalk venders virtually abandoned the city downtown shopping district today as a campaign to restrict such sales went into effect for the first full day.

What the nation requires is a national policy to attack inflation, unemployment and crucial social needs in a way that will command the support and respect of people generally because it is fair. Such a policy will protect the living standards and jobs of those who are most susceptible to the capricious erosion of rising prices or of rising unemployment.

High-level contacts between the United States and Palestinian organizations may develop in coming months as part of an evolving American effort to bring about a Middle East settlement, a senior State Department official said today.
Robert Fahey was held on assault charges today after he allegedly shot his son when he found the youth smoking marijuana, the police said.
The British Government announced proposals today to reap a larger share of the profits from North Sea oil and to assert greater public control over its development.

Five thousand people fled safely down the stairwells of two adjoining downtown office buildings yesterday in an orderly escape from a smoky fire 21 floors high following drill and warden systems started after the fatal 1970 fire at 1 New York Plaza. Interior of All Transport, Inc., where the fire was said to have started in a file case Building at 17 Battery Place North, where fire broke out on 21st floor.
A major developer offered today to build a 1,100-room hotel on Atlantic City's boardwalk and follow it with commercial buildings and new housing.
Mrs. Nancie Brown Stewart and Harold Cornelius Palmer, both of New York, were married Wednesday in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.
Dr. John W. Cline, who had been president of the American Medical Association and the American Cancer Society, died yesterday. He suffered a heart attack Monday.

Following is the text, of a statement by an unidentified employee of the Central Intelligence Agency describing partial reaction of the agency and the White House to reports that E. Howard Hunt Jr. was involved in the Watergate case. At the request of the C.I.A., names were deleted and numbers substituted by the House Judiciary Committee.

A Dutchess County, N.Y., grand jury has recommended the removal of two deputy sheriffs who first shot at a man they mistook for an escaped prisoner and theninstead of apologizing-arrested for reckless endangerment.
Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn denied at his trial yesterday that he had ever met with a postal official and a reputed Mafia member at his Congressional office in Washington.

Eugene E. Wilson, former president of the United Aircraft Corporation, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old. Mr. Wilson, who wrote books and articles about the aircraft industry and world peace, had served as a Navy Commander before he became president of the Hamilton Standard Propeller Corporation in 1929.

WASHINGTON--Whatever may be said about the procedures being followed by the House Judiciary Committee in its impeachment inquiry, it cannot be denied that there is increasing public criticism of those procedures and, more important, that there is growing cynicism and apathy about the efficacy of the impeachment process itself.
As trials go, the trial of John D. Ehrlichman has gone briskly and efficiently, propelled by the polite but persistent prodding of Judge Gerhard A. Gesell. But the heat has defied even him.

Curtis J. Berger, the Columbia University law professor who drafted plans to desegregate Mark Twain Junior High School, yesterday defended his plans, which on Wednesday were called "racist' by an education consultant for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
The United States and the Soviet Union are wrangling again about the parking of diplomatic vehicies on the city's streets outside of reserved spaces.
A second top environmental official of the Nixon Administration disclosed publicly today his defection from the Government's policy of opposing a strict strip-mine reclamation law.

Hundreds of tourists were disappointed this evening when a performance of Puccini's "Turandot" at the Baths of Caracalla was canceled because the city has no money to pay singers, musicians and stagehands .

The Soviet Union bowed today to the West's insistence on a summer break at the slow-moving European conference on security and cooperation, but only after exacting a token concession on the length of the adjournment.

John Taylor Terry, retired senior partner of Wood, Walker Co., stockbrokers, and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here Wednesday. He was 85 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

Of the 25,100 Israelis who graduated from high school last month, the vast majority -- young men and women alike - will go directly into the army. They will be inducted for periods of compulsory national service ranging from 20 months to three years. Graduating high school students in Jerusalem talking about issues confronting Isreal and themselves. From the left are Amira Hass, Dror Zandman, Anita Juliusburger, Eytan Rozin and Ofer Bruckstein.

KALAMAZOO, Mich. - Residents of New Horizon Village are beginning to feel as if they have been orphaned at an early age. New Horizon Village in Kalamazoo, Mich., is one of Operation Breakthrough's nine subdivisions. It faces a deficit of $80,000 this year, according to the cooperative's chairman. He blames the high cost of maintaining the experimental housing.

The more moderate prospect for grain harvests is likely to have little 'effect on retail prices this year, but may cause a reduction in the production of livestock and thus put upward pressure on meat prices in 1975, the Agriculture Department's chief economist said
President Nixon will shortly nominate Alan Greenspan, a consulting economist in New York City, to be chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

The senate Appropriations Committee approved today a Federal Trade Commission request to collect certain business data on 500 companies. The House had cut the number in half on the ground that a more limited program should be undertaken initially to give Congress an opportunity to judge whether it was worth. while.

An unnecessary conflict is now brewing between the United States and Turkey over the Turkish Government's deplorable decision to resume cultivation of the opium poppy. The poppy ban instituted by the Turkish military government in 1971, under American prodding, has unquestionably been the major factor behind the dramatic decline in heroin addiction in New York and other Eastern Seaboard cities.

In a moment of modesty about six years ago, Al Davis, the overseer of the Oakland Raiders, was discussing the potential for forming a new pro football league. "You could do it," Davis said, "in 10 minutes." Obviously the World Football League organizers moved somewhat slower. It took them all of 10 months. Representative Robertl McClory, the second ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, said tonight that the conviction of the President's former chief domestic adviser, John D. Ehrlichman, would seriously damage the President's case in the impeachment proceedings.

Postures of pensiveness and concentration-the face of competition-set the scene at the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel, where part of American Contract Bridge League's tournament was held.

The Detroit Tigers announced today that Willie Horton would be hospitalized tomorrow and may have to undergo knee surgery. The slugging left fielder, who injured his right knee when he ran into the grandstand wall in Tiger Stadium in May, was placed on the 15-day disabled list.

The Broadway musical theater of the nineteen-fifties and sixties owed a great deal to the scrubbed, schoolgirl charm and glowing voice of Barbara Cook. Slim and apple-cheeked, with long blond hair and a surprisingly big voice, Miss Cook sang Cunegonde in the original production of "Candide."

Harold Gould Henderson, who retired in 1956 as professor of Japanese. language and arts history at Columbia University, died Thursday at his summer home in Hunter, N. Y. He was 84 years old and lived at 179 East 70th Street.

An investor who says he owns $200,000 of New York City's tax-exempt bonds and has confidence in them for the future is nevertheless distressed by some current advertising, stressing the fact that under the Constitution .of New York State bondholders may be paid even before the Mayor, firemen and policemen.

A 22-year-old unemployed Greenwich, Conn., man was charged 'by Connecticut authorities yesterday with setting the fire that killed 24 young people and injured 32 others two weeks ago in a singles bar astride the New York-Connecticut. border. Peter J. Leonard

The First National City Bank held its prime corporate lending rate to 12 per cent yesterday to allow for a period of "reappraisal." The nation's second biggest commercial bank's action is always watched closely in the money market.

Governor Byrne retraced the steps of his triumphal electioncampaign trail in Ocean County today, not looking for votes this time, but in his words, "to talk about the problems of government."

Charlie Caldwell-a black man, age 32, resident of Mount Vernon, N. Y.died in his apartment on the morning of Oct. 19. Two teen-agers and a man in his late twenties jumped an off-duty Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority patrolman last night near his home in Jamaica, Queens, shot him once in the right side and escaped with his service revolver, the Police reported..

Edward Holloway, a specialist in corporate, tax, estate and trust law here for 59 years, died Thursday in White Plains Hospital of a stroke. He was 83 years old and lived at 1 Edgemont Road, Scardsdale, N. Y.

A jury of nine men and three women was completed yesterday in the perjury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo of Brooklyn and presentation of evidence is expected to begin Monday, fol. lowing selection of two alternate jurors.

After two years of planning, Rutgers University will launch its first women's varsity sports program at the university level next fall with seven teams and a 14-woman coaching staff. And before the year is out, Rutgers may also make available its first athletic scholarship for a woman.

Tract of land jutting Into Hackensack River, center, is site of proposed development. New Jersey Turnpike is at bottom, Route 3 is at left, and New York skyline, background.

The Senate Watergate committee formally went out of business today, and its chairman said the committee recommended creation of a new office of "public attorney" to handle cases in which public officials are charged with wrongdoing.

Bjorn Borg of Sweden, seeded No. 1, had to fight all the way today to beat Corrado Barazutti of Italy and qualify as the only Swede to gain the semifinals of the $50,000 Baastad grand pnx tennis tournament. Borg, whose poor service kept him in trouble, finally won, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2. Despite Barazutti's loss, Italy advanced two players to the semifinals.

Fifty thousand Protestant marchers, elated by their recent overthrow of the power-sharing Northern Ireland government, paraded here today in Northern Ireland's biggest Orange Day celebrations.

To the Editor: Georgy A. Arbatov's party-line defense of detente, Soviet style (Op-Ed June 28), is a classic study in Stalinist paranoia. Mr. Arbatov is in knee-shaking dread that the Soviet Government is about to be dismantled by the American Cofigress.

From a foreign policy standpoint, defenders of Amercan arms sales argue that if this country does not supply the arms, other countries-the Soviet Union and France, for example-will do so. There surely is some truth to this argument; .but it also may be dangerously selfdelusive, depending on the specific circumstances of particular arms sales.

The role of Marseilles as a crucial link in heroin traffic to the United States may have ended, some French antidrug experts believe. They have maintained this view despite the decision of the Turkish Government last week to resume growing opium poppies,

The European Common Market announced today that it had suspended its subsidy on cheese exported to the United States. The action, taken in response to pressure from United States producers, will tend to raise the price of imported cheese for Americans.
A 25-year-old Brooklyn man being frisked with two companions by two police officers last night fired a shot at the officers and was killed with several shots in the return fire, the police reported.

Mayor Beame yesterday unexpected ordered that "round the clock" talks begin with the unions representing firemen and of the pre Sanitationmen.

The police have added ZU men each to their patrols in Central and Prospect Parks following two recent murders of bicyclists and a general rise in crime. The addition has made the force in Central Park the largest in recent years.

The world economy may be heading for a slump, but the international arms trade is booming. The world market leader in this unsavory competition is the United States which, in the fiscal year that ended last month, sold some $8.5 billion in arms, almost doubling its sales in a single year. About $7 billion of the American weapons were sold in the Middle East and Persian Gulf area.

The stock market got the medicine it needed yesterdaya dose of good news-and leaped to its best gain in more than a year. The Dow -Jones industrial average climbed 27.61 points to 787.23, its largest daily advance since a 29.24-point move May 24, 1973.

Del E. Webb willed a taxpaid $1.5-million to his second wife and $75,000 a year for life to his first wife, court records show. The will was filed yesterday and scheduled for probate in Superior Court Aug. 2.

A surge of ticket buying was touched off yesterday at the American Ballet Theater following the announcement of three forthcoming appearances by Mikhail Baryshnikov, the ballet star who defected last month in Toronto from a Soviet company.

With the conviction in Washington yesterday of John D. Ehrlichman and three codefendants, the Watergate scandal has now produced 36 verdicts or pleas of guilty. In.addition, five persons have been cleared of charges arising from the scandal and at least seven others await trials.

Marvin Mandel ordered 115 Maryland state troopers and the state's armored car into Baltimore tonight in an attempt to quell the street violence that has erupted here during a spreading citywide strike of municipal employes. A store in the eastern part of Baltimore being looted yesterday. There were widespread reports of such incidents as many of the city's policemen went on strike.

To assemble the 200 playthings for the "Toys From the Attic" exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, John Noble investigated on his hands and knees all the storage areas under the museum's eaves.

Herman Glick, vice president of Glick Brothers, a chain of meat markets in Brooklyn and Long Island, died of a heart attack Wednesday in the Coney Island Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Sands Point, L. I., and Hollywood, Fla.
The board of trustees of Atlantic Community College has asked the State Attorney General's office to expedite its inquiry into allegations of misuse of funds and employes by college officials.

A three-judge Federal court panel today gave the Delaware Board of Education until Sept. 15 to propose means of desegregating the Wilmington schools.
One of two armed convicts holding seven hostages in the Federal Courthouse here vowed tonight to "take a lot of people" with him if the pair were not guaranteed their freedom.

Yacht-watchers have a choice this weekend. They can see hundreds of yachts in Long Island Sound competing in Larchmont Yacht Club's 76th annual race week or watch two or three 12-Meter craft in the America's Cup observation trials off Newport, R. I.

A partial but compelling reply to those who asked during the late sixties what it would take to bring about significant social change has been given in a recent report to the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The answers are: a good idea, money and a sustained determination to get something done.

The new military - dominated cabinet that is expected to be announced here shortly reportedly will grant independence in the next few weeks to Portuguese Guinea, one of three African territories where Portuguese troops have been battling liberation movements for 12 years.

President Nixon has arranged a six-month postponement of his final mortgage payment on his San Clemer.te estate, officials said today. Originally, a payment of $226,660 was due Monday, along with $17,000 in interest.

Reversing the trend thus far this year, prices on the American Stock and the over-thecounter market bounded upward yesterday. Exchange trades dipped slightly on the Amex but showed a slight increase in the counter market.

An offering by Citicorp of $850-million in a controversial and novel type of security cleared two major hurdles yesterday after the bank-holding company agreed to alter the terms of the proposed offering. It still was uncertain when the issue would be offered to the Public.

Cooper Schiefflin; chairman of the board of the Penn Yan Boat Company, Penn Yan; N. Y., manufacturer of motorboats, died yesterday in Southampton (L. I.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Bridgehampton, L. I.

Charles E. Spahr, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), announced today that the initial operating rate of the trans-Alaska pipeline would be doubled from 600,000 barrels daily of crude oil to 1.2 million barrels with completion in mid-1977.

The Federal Government's decision to mandate safety standards for bicycles reflects the phenomenal re-emergence of the bike as a popular mode of transportation in the United States. Bicycle sales doubled from less than seven million in 1970 to more than fifteen million last year, outstripping the sale of automobiles for the first time since World War 1.
Perry Osborn Jr., vice president of the board of directors in charge of public affairs at the Burke Rehabilitation Center here, died yesterday in Garrison. He was 57 years old.

All nine horses, and eight of the nine drivers, were in perfect shape today awaiting the $200,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night, A crowd of 35,000 is expected to attend the 16th running of the event, the richest trotting race in the world. The army said today that it had arrested a close adviser to Emperor Haile Selassie. The adviser, Ras Mesfin Silleshi, one of the most powerful men in Ethiopia, was the top man on the army's most wanted list.

The Mayor's "walk and talk" road show moved onto Staten Island last night, with Mr. Beame leading a jaunt through two older business districts in an effort to lend a hand to the neighborhood shopping strips.

At 7:17 A.M. local time on June 30, 1908, something frightful occurred in the Tunguska area of central Siberia. As though a catastrophic mid-air explosion had taken place, virtually all trees within a radius of 20 miles were blown down. The rarest accidents apart, the autobiographer is, in the nature of things, deprived of all these prerequisites.

HANOVER, N. H.--There are many kinds of hypocrisy, but the kind I am concerned about involves performing immoral actions while at the same time publicly condemning similar immoral actions by others. Immoral action does not mean swearing in pri. vate, but rather serious violations of the moral rules: killing, deceiving, failing to perform one's duty or violating the law. No rational person can favor such hypocrisy.

The consumer Product Safety Commissioh has bees double-crossed by the White House in the agency's sevenmonth battle for political independence, Chairman Richard 0. Simpson said today.
Shooting broke out in the center of Luanda today and unofficial reports said that nearly 20 people had been killed and 15 wounded as troops broke up the two demonstrations.
Bobby (Boogaloo) Watts knocked Eugene (Cyclone) Hart through the ropes at 2 minutes 40 seconds of the first round tonight to score a quick victory in a middleweight fight at the Spectrum.

FOREST, Miss. - The sun was low over the corn patch when Mrs. Annie McLaurin rode up the dirt lane and pulled into her driveway. A rooster crowed under a fig tree and a young hound moved slowly across the dirt yard and disappeared behind the unpainted house.
Mrs. G. Thomas Aydelotte of Stanwich won the medal in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tournament by three strokes by scoring 38, 38-76 at Woodway Country Club today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Teleprompter Corporation, the nation's largest cable television franchise operation, had defrauded its stockholders and the public by providing misleading financial information in 1973.

Soviet space authorities disclosed today that they had considered, but apparently rejected, a proposal to curtail the mission of the space laboratory Salyut 3, which is orbiting the earth with two astronauts aboard, because of intense solar flares.
Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. was found guilty tonight on all charges for his part in the nation's largest mass murder case of the century.

Eleven restaurants and food distributors have been cited by the Health Department, after two inspections, for violating the city's health code. If these food places fail to correct their violations before their next inspection, they will be subjected to closing.
Paul E. Miller, professor of law and former dean of the Howard University School of Law here, died Friday of pancreatitis at his home here. He was 38 years old.

Barry T. Leithead, retired chairman of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., shirtmakers, died yesterday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and had made his home in Aiken, S.C., since his retirement.

Greg Cook, outstanding rookie quarterback with the Cincinnati Bengals in 1969, has hardly played since then because of three major operations for shoulder injuries. This year he reported to training camp convinced he had regained his passing touch. But he had trouble throwing in a workout on Sunday and left camp that night.
Two armed convicts surrendered quietly to the police and United States marshals tonight after barricading themselves in the United States District Courthouse for more than 100 hours.

Charging that President Nixon's summit meeting in Moscow last month had failed to abate the arms race, George Meany suggested today that the Administration should "try for detente with the American people."

The Internal Revenue Service, as part of its audit of President Nixon's tax returns, employed independent appraisers who valued Mr. Nixon's prePresidential papers at less than half the $576,000 claimed by the President's own appraiser.

Even if they don't agree on the issues in the National Football League players' strike, Steve Tannen, the Jets' labor leader, and Charley Winner, the Jets' coach, agree on one thing-the image conjured up by Carl Barzilauskas.
The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, which has one of the highest corporate credit ratings in the nation, paid a record 9.737 per cent to borrow $175-million on 40-year debentures yesterday.

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation has agreed in principle with the state of Kentucky to develop a large coal gasification pilot plant.
Franc Shor, an associate editor of National Geographic, died here today of a brain lesion at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 60 years old.
A West Hartford lawyer with a background in engineering was named by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today to head the new state energy agency.
Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, said yesterday that his company did not intend to raise steel prices
Readers responding to a Milwaukee Journal straw vote on the National Football League players' strike were overwhelmingly in favor of the owners.
Premier Yitzhak Rabin today ruled out any possibility of contact or negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

Rugglero Sons Funderal Home, 726 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx Mass of the Resurrection, Wednesday 9:45 a.m. at Our Lady of Solace Church.
Three of the nation's major airlines-United, Trans World and American-paid fines total. ing $60,000 today for violating airline ticket regulations.

Blood supplies in the state greatly improved over the weekend, according to the American Red Cross, as hundreds of donors responded to an urgent plea for blood.

Michele Sindona, the owner of 21.6 per cent of the Franklin New York Corporation, has reportedly yielded a controlling interest in Societa Generale Immobiliare as collateral for a loan of more than $100-million.

The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that it was permissible to place children adjudged to be "persons in need of supervision" in training schools that also contained youngsters convicted of relatively serious offenses - provided the supervision and treatment were adequate.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 9.

A Federal judge here today authorized almost $10-million in state and Federal aid to keep passenger service on the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey running through Nov. 30.
A former Interior Minister who paved the way for elections last year that ultimately led to the return of Juan Domingo Peron was shot to death today by unidentified assassins.

Conscience as well as cost is a consideration that may soon impel Americans to reduce their consumption of meat, It takes 1,600 pounds of grain per person every year to provide the high-protein diet that has become common in the United States.

After the United States took third place In the International Team Tournament, one point behind Yugoslavia, Svetozar Gligoric asked me whether I felt that we deserved the second-place silver medal, since we won our match with Yugoslavia.
Luis Tiant, the Boston Red Sox right-hander, with two complete-game performances in which he did not allow. a run, was named yesterday the American League's player of the week.

Western diplomats here expressed fears tonight that the coup on Cyprus might bring Greece and Turkey to the point of war, the kind of war that the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization barely averted 10 years go.

Harold E. Berg, president of the Skelly Oil Company, will be named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Getty Oil Company, succeeding Ernest B. Miller, according to plans announced by Getty Oil yesterday.
--A rederal appears court today reversed a judge who held that the sales scheme operated by Koscot Interplanetary, Inc., did not violate federal securities laws.

The American Enka Company, a unit of Akzona, Inc., announced yesterday that it was phasing out the production of rayon filament yarn at its plant in Lowland, Tenn. Part of the plant will be converted to production of rayon staple fiber.
India's smallpox epidemic has spread from Bihar and the number of cases has reached more than 130,000.
Helen Rogers Wardwell, widow of Allen Wardwell, a senior partner in the law firm of Davis Polk Wardwell, died Sunday at her home, 355 Ocean Avenue in Lawrence, L. I. She was 92 years old.

The White House said today that Federal revenues in the 1975 fiscal year ending next June 30 would be higher than expected and that the budget deficit for the year would probably be narrowed even beyond current estimates.

It was more of the same at the America's Cup trial; today. Intrepid, the good old boat, beat Valiant thoroughly in two true races and finished off what little remained of the latter's consideration as a possible defender of yachting's foremost trophy.

Texas insurance commissioner Don R. Odum has tightened his supervision of the Republic National Insurance Company of Dallas, now that the Federal district court In the southern district of New York has affirmed his control of the company.
Industrial production was unchanged in June from the May level but rose in the second quarter from the depressed first quarter, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Four of the nation's five major copper companies were struck today by a 26-union coalition, idling about 30,000 workers. One of the companies, the Kennecott Copper Company, reached a tentative agreement with its employes later in the day.

Paul Joseph White Jr., vice president of Great Eastern Packing and Paper Stock Corporation, died after a long illness Sunday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 49 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

A 15day strike by sanitationmen, jail guards and most other municipal service workers ended today, but hundreds of policemen refused to return to duty without an unqualified amnesty for their illegal four-day strike.
An independent milk dealer in Westchester County charged today that he was being forced out of business through collusion and power politics in the milk industry.
In a small, cramped storefront in Harlem, Federal, state and city officials and a few "arch-enemy friends" joined Florence Rice yesterday in opening her second consumereducation center uptown.
District Attorney Richard H. Kuh has made a private apology to two Supreme Court justices whose conduct he publicly criticized three months ago.

The Suffolk County Medical Examiner's office, unable to determine what killed two Lake Grove, L.I., girls, last night dispatched its chief toxicologist and samples of the dead girls' tissues to the Finnegan Corporation, a San Francisco laboratory on the chance that its more advanced equipment could find traces of a deadly chemical.
The son of an official of the Dominican Republic has been killed. The police ruled it a suicide today, but family members said it was an accident.

The Jersey blueberry took stage center in the Bergen Mall here this morning as nimblefingered berry-packers awed the public with their packing precision and small boys in a blueberry-muffin-eating contest turned into purple-faced stuffers.
Four men reportedly armed with machine guns were arrested today after they allegedly held up a Bank of New Jersey armored car and stole more than $100,000.

Adversity has succeeded in bringing the Giants and Jets together. New York's two National Football League teams, admittedly short on personnel with the player strike, have. agreed to hold two 90-minute "combined workouts" this week, utilizing rookies, free agents and the few established players who crossed union picket lines.

The Board of Education, acting under Federal court orders to improve integration at Brooklyn's Franklin K. Lane High School, submitted a plan yesterday to draw 570 white students from predominantly white schools in Queens into the school, while simultaneously shifting 600 minority students in Lane's current feeder pattern to other high schools.

Canadian jurist who was the apparent source for reports yesterday that Premier ChouEn-lai had suffered a heart attack denied on his arrival here today that he had received any information from Chinese officials about the state of the 76year-old leader's health.
The State's Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, said yesterday that the city was failing to assess adequately the ability of parents to pay for their children in foster care.

Sydney Sewall Whittier, widow of Charles L. Whittier, who was vice chairman and president of the plans board of Young Rubicam, Inc., the F New York advertising agency, when he retired to Maine in 1954, died yesterday in Boothbay Harbor, Me. She was 77 years old and lived in South Portland, Me.
A year and a half ago, when Bruce Springsteen emerged as the latest in the line of "new Bob Dylans," he impressed mostly for the manic energy of his speedy strings of words and metaphors.
The two leading container companies - the Continental Can Company, Inc., and the American Can Company-had record sales and earnings in the quarter ended June 30, they reported yesterday.

We've had fashion revivals of the 1920's (flapper dresses), the 1930's (slinky, bias cuts) and the 1940's (twin sweaters and platform shoes). Evenfor those who want to go back that far-the 1900's embroidered muslins, currently designed by Giorgio di Sant' Angelo and tagged at $1,500.

Prices closed moderately higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after having risen sharply in the first hour but then leveling off. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

A 21-year old purse-snatching suspect suffered undetermined injuries when he broke away from detectives and leaped from a third-story window of the Ericsson Place Police Station yesterday, the police reported.
Walter Elcock has just returned home to Boston from Europe wearing his second hat as newly elected president of the International Lawn Tennis Federation.

It is like watching a slow avalanche. Two years ago this month John N. Mitchell resigned as head of the Committee for the Re-Election of the President immediately after a committee aide was tied to the Watergate burglary.

With quiet deliberation, the world's major oil-consuming countries are discovering an impressive-if belated -readiness to cooperate in devising contingency plans for dealing with any future oil shortages. Against the gloomy forebodings of last winter, the progress made in the 12-member energy coordination group, meeting in Brussels, is unexpectedly encouraging.

Kelly Moser of Winged Foot and Bob Watson and Dennis Walters, both of Wykagyl, shot 72's today over the Fairview Country Club course to lead the field in the 52d annual Westchester open golf championship.
The White House appears to be steadily seeking to construct a secondary line of defense to protect President Nixon against impeachment.

Warning that rental housing here was being ravaged by inflation, Housing and Development Administrator Roger Starr made public a study yesterday showing that prices involved in operating a major group of apartments here had increased by nearly 20 per cent in the last year.
Lawyers for Otto Kerner Jr., former Governor of Illinois, asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its decision not to review his conviction on bribery and related charges.

Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal District Court here yesterday that he would not be on trial now if he had known before 1968 that John A. Masiello was a reputed racketeer.
Two Japanese accused of having been important go-betweens linking North Korean and Japanese Communists with the anti-Government student movement here were sentenced to 20 years in prison today.

The House of Representatives, registering pique at the Senate and the nearly $1-million cost for the printing of additional copies of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry proceedings, rejected today a resolution authorizing the cost.

Jen Bednarek plays basketball so well it is hard to believe she is just 16 years old. And thanks to the Leonia summer basketball league, she has a chance to improve and exhibit her skills. Last year, after sponsoring a boys' league for 10 years, Leonia started a girls' league to fill the need for organized summer basketball for young women.
All soybean futures contracts and the nearby corn futures contracts jumped the daily permissible limits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
An admirer of Aleksandr I Solzhenitsyn telephoned the book department of Alexander's department store recently and asked whether "The Gulag Archipelago" was in stock.

A 1972 audit showing that $3,95-million in securities could not be accounted for when Abraham D. Beame was Controller was made public yesterday by Mr. Beame's successor, Controller Harrison J. Goldin.
HAPPY MEDIUMS Under the moon, the psychics sail tonight, and you're not very likely to find a more unusual happening all summer.

The United States today obliquely warned Greece, Turkey and the leaders of the coup against Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, to avoid any steps that could compromise the independence of Cyprus.

The eighth annual Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center will open next Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Five Mondays later, when it's over, William Lockwood, the director, will be in his office working on next summer's programs.

Wayne Garland of the Baltimore Orioles pitched a dream game for eight innings against the Oakland A's but wound up in a nightmare last night. Three outs away from becoming one of the most unknown no hit pitchers in baseball, Garland faltered.

For the third time In four years the Congress is attempting to create an institutional voice for consumer interests in Washington, to balance the well-organized activities of business lobbies and trade associations. Only the prospect of a filibuster, perhaps starting today, seems to stand between this much-needed legislation and Senate passage, following last April's overwhelming approval by the House of Representatives.

The Treasury and other Federal financial agencies today came out in opposition to emergency legislation aimed at blocking issuance of securities by bank holding companies such as the floating interest rate notes due to be sold by Citi-corp, parent of the First National City Bank.

The prosecution in the perjury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo told the jury yesterday that it would prove that the judge had tried to get a Waterfront Commission lawyer to "go easy" on the investigation of Thomas, Masotto, described by the prosecutor as the judge's "long-time friend," client, tenant and butcher.
Laurens Reeve Bowden, who had been active in yachting, died Sunday in Portland, Me. He lived in Newcastle, Me., and formerly in Bellport, L.I.

The E. F. Hutton Group, Inc., parent of the Wall Street brokerage house of E. F. Hutton Co., Inc.,reported yesterday that it earned $11,000, or 2 cents a share, in the second quarter ended June 30, compared with a loss in the 1973 quarter of $922,000.

In a ruling that should spare municipalities the loss of property tax revenues, the appellate division of superior court rejected the argument that the amount of taxes actually collected in one year should be used to set the tax rate for future years. The court turned down the challenge to the 1965 tax rate in the Bergen County community of Bogota by the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc.

Joseph E. Fontana, vice president and director of manufacturing for Hearst magazines since 1969, died Saturday night at his summer home in Southold, L. I. He was 66 years old and lived at 1232 80th Street in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON - "People bring in the most exquisite things," said Anne Bradshaw, whose small, imaginative Georgetown shop is full of those exquisite things.
Asea plane was demolished Saturday night when the pilot attempted to land here at a private landing field, but the three occupants escaped serious injury.
State and Federal health officials took steps today to combat the spread of parrot fever in Texas, where they say 25 persons have been sickened by the disease, spread in this case by turkeys.

Dr. Daniel H. Barish, health scientist administrator, Bureau of Health Services Research, Deapartment of Health, Education and Welfare, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Rockville Md. He was 57 years old.
