A severe 49 per cent sales drop at the Ford Motor Company during the first 10 days of July sent United States auto sales sliding 28.4 per cent below the 1973 pace.

In the hot sun at the gate to Biscayne College where the Miami Dolphins hold their training camp, Doug Swift, the linebacker and player representative, wore a floppy red hat, a white T-shirt advertising "Adidas" across the chest, blue jeans, thong sandals and a National Football League Players' Association picket sign. Nearby, red, white and blue bunting hung from the roof of a rented beige camper that was air conditioned.

Former Mayor John V. Lindsay is to play a United States Senator in a motion picture now being filmed in France. Reached at a Paris hotel, Otto Preminger, the film's producer-director, said that Mr. Lindsay "is an important man and he could only play an important role."

After centuries of denudation and catastrophic erosion, Iceland is beginning to grow forests again. Yet, as noted by Iceland's chief forester, the task is doubly difficult, for most Icelanders have never seen a forest.

" In keeping with Channel 40's policy of bringing you the latest in blood and guts and in living color you are going to see another first-attempted suicide." With that announcement Chris Chubbuck, 30 years old, shot herself in the head today during her morning talk show on WXLT-TV.

Karl and Debbie Dortzbach, both aged 24 and married three years, ended a visit with her family in Freehold, N.J., yesterday and headed west for a camping trip in the Colorado Rockies west of Denver, Karl's hometown.
Finance ministers in the European Economic Community expressed concern today that lagging expansion in the United States could help lead the world into an economic slump.

A three-way primary contest for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate was virtually assured yesterday when the two insurgent candidates, Abraham Hirschfeld and former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, filed nominating petitions containing more than twice the number of signatures required to get on the ballot.
Gov. Milton J. Shapp is still looking for state funds to help Finance an investigation into alalleged police and administrative corruption in Philadelphia.

Regina Dougherty Auspitzer, a former president of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, died yesterday at the Smithtown Lodge of heart failure. She was 86 years old.

Mayor Beame said yesterday that murders in New York had decreased by nearly 5 per cent in the first-five months of this year, compared with the same period last year. In May alone, he said, murders showed a decrease of 39 per cent compared with May, 1973, according to figures of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
South Vietnam said today that the Vietcong tried to sabotage the municipal and providencial elections yesterday by sharply increasing cease-fire violations and terroists attacks.

The State Court of Appeals yesterday invalidated the landmark status of the J. P. Morgan mansion on Madison Avenue in a decision that could represent a major setback to landmark preservation efforts in New York.
Dan W. Lufkin, one of the trio of 30-year-olds who created the maverick Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette 15 years ago, returned to it yesterday.

William J. ("but everybody calls me Bill") Miles Jr., executive vice president of Playgirl, has discovered what the publishers of Penthouse and Playboy already know - a good number of advertisers still consider it bad for their corporate image to be in one of the so-called "skin books."
Thomas W. O'Connor, a of partner in the law firm of Logue O'Connor, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 47 Crestwood Avenue, Crestwood, N. Y. He was 49 years old.
Production of steel, which has been declining steadily since the week of June 22; dropped to a new low for the week ending Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Guillermo Vilas of Argentina needed only 50 minutes today to upset topseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain, 6-1, 6-2, in the men's singles final of an international tennis tournament. The victory earned the South American champion $8,000, while Orantes got $4,700.
One afternoon in June, 1972, an excited lieutenant general breezed into the office of Gen. Michael Davidson, commander of the United States Seventh Army.
Two men were arraigned today on Federal extortion charges in connection with the apparent kidnapping of a wealthy industrialist's son.

In a letter to the President of Greece dated July 6, Archbishop Makarios accused the military rulers in Athens of planning to murder him and furnished what he called "irrefutable" evidence that Greek officers commanding the Cyprus National Guard were plotting with "EOKA-B" underground forces to overthrow his Government. He demanded that Greece recall the 650 officers.
Thousands of dollars worth of vegetable oil poured out of a railroad tank car and onto the grounds of a Brooklyn processing plant when a valve lock was broken, the police reported yesterday.

Representative Michael J. Harrington introduced two bills today to extend Congressional control over the Central Intelligence Agency.
Bill Cosby, who stars with Sidney Poitier and Harry Belafonte in "Uptown Saturday Night," has retracted and apologized for statements he wrote and delivered in a radio commercial for the film.

Henry Smadia, owner and publisher of the Paris newspaper Combat, died today, the day after his 77th birthday.

The Chase Manhattan Bank asked a Federal court here yesterday how it should dispose of $156-million it holds in the account of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt, the West German bank that was ordered into liquidation last month.

The rates of Treasury bills fell today as the Government borrowed a total of $4.5-billion at its weekly auction of short-term securities.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the world's largest chemical producer, had record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year, but the profit gains were modest, according to the midyear report issued yesterday.
The Getty Oil Company Eastern operations announced yesterday that effictive today it would raise the wholesale price of gasoline and several other petroleum products by 1 cent a gallon.

Cypriote troops led by Greek officers overthrew the Government of Cyprus. There were conflicting reports on the fate of Archbishop Makarios, the country's 60-year-old President who, according to early dispatches, was killed. But later reports indicated he might have been given refuge. The rebels named Nikos Giorgiades Sampson as the new President. He is a 38-year-old GreekCypriote newspaper publisher who had been an assassin.

Last Jan, 30, when Gen. George Grivas was buried at a mountain hideout from which he commanded Cyprus's struggle for independence from Britain, the major eulogy was delivered by Nikos Giorgiades Sampson.
A corrected United Nations report showed today that the Soviet Union and the United States had stepped up their military rivalry in the Indian Ocean, that Britain's presence there had declined,

Several copper mining companies invoked the force majeure clauses in their sales contracts yesterday in the wake of labor strikes. Force majeure is a standard clause in business contracts. It refers to forces outside the control of the company. The Phelps Dodge Corporation said its Arizona mines and smelters as well as its El Paso refinery were struck.

Church World Service, the $25 - million-a-year Protestant and Eastern Orthodox agency for overseas aid, declared yesterday that "it is not in the business of promoting violent revolutionary change," and that its continuing aim would be "to respond to human needs quickly."

Governor Byrne's income tax bill won its first legislative test by the narrowest possible margin tonight when the State Assembly approved the proposal by a vote of 41 to 38.

A 15-day strike by sanitationmen, jail guards and most other municipal service workers ended today, but hundreds of policemen refused to return to duty without an unqualified amnesty for their illegal four-day strike.

Philip Morris, Inc., the first of the tobacco companies to issue financial results for this year's second quarter, reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for the second quarter and first half.

A Federal magistrate yesterday suggested that Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaway section of Queens be closed if "it is going to be a gathering place of nudists."
Two leaders of the United Mine Workers criticized today their union's executive board endorsement of a strip mining regulatory bill and called for the House to reject the legislation.
Plays at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater are exercises in audience identification: Cheer the hero, hiss the villain, recognize the stereotype.

A policeman who was suspended last week for living with a woman to whom he is not married intends to fight in courts the action by the chief of police. Jeffrey W. Vance and four other police department employes were ordered by Police Chief William Kimbrough to end their cohabitant arrangements.
A lawyer who used his license the way "a bank robber uses a submachine-gun" was sentenced yesterday to two three-year terms in state prisons for. robbing elderly clients of almost $85,000.
The White House has demanded the resignation of Alvin J. Arnett as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, Mr. Arnett said today in an interview.
President Anwar el-Sadat said today he was confident that he would be able to bring about a meeting within the next few weeks between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat,
The unrelenting bear market increased the vulnerability of margin accounts in June and apparently set up brokerage house customers for the worst siege of margin calls in many years.

A man carrying his 2-yearold daughter on his way to the corner grocery yesterday evening fell 15 feet with her when a section of sidewalk collapsed under him in front of 71 East 97th Street, near Madison Avenue, the police reported.
Turkish Government officials warned today that they would not "accept and fait accompli" on Cyprus and expressed concern for the Turkish community there.
The Union Corporation and Barlow Rand, Ltd., both of South Africa, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge into a new group to be known as Unicorp Barlow, Ltd.

A state referee ruled today, that a newsman had a right to remain at a supposedly closed session of the Enfield Town Council, but upheld the Council's right to shut its doors when considering administrative matters.

Reported crime in the United states increased 15 per cent luring the first three months of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. It was the second consecutive period reflecting a dramatic increase in the national rate of murder, rape, robbery, assault, ??urglary , larceny and auto theft, the crime categories measured by the F.B.I. in its Uniform Crime Reports.
The stock market caught its breath yesterday with prices steadying and volume dropping off after Friday's hectic 27.61 advance.

The Centex Corporation of Dallas announced yesterday that a subsidiary, the Centex Construction Company, was awarded a $49.2-million contract to build a water-pollution-control plant along the Potomac River. The contract was awarded by the District of Columbia Government's Department of Environmental Services. The facility, a sedimentation plant, is scheduled for completion in mid-1977.
The United States and East Germany began talks in Washington today aimed at establishing diplomatic relations. The State Department said that the talks might last for a week or 10 days.
The Czechoslovak Federal Assembly today Unanimously ratified a treaty normalizing relations with West Germany.

The 7,000-member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Workers Union voted today to "shut down the state of Ohio" in a midnight strike in an attempt to gain a 40-cent-an-hour wage rise for state workers.

The Los Angeles Dodgers and their closest western division pursuers, the Cincinnati Reds, were the heavy winners yesterday in the final National League all-star baseball voting, each placing three players on the squad.

Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal District Court here yesterday that he would not be on trial now if he had known before 1968 that John A. Masiello was a reputed racketeer.

The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee raised its target for the key Federal funds interest rate twice between mid-April and mid-May rather than permit rapid expansion of the nation's money supply to accelerate, it was disclosed today.
Lawyers for two New Orleans newspapers took their plea for an end to a gag rule at a murder trial to the United States Supreme Court today.

Louis Sisler, a lobbyist for the National Rifle Association and a former Indiana state judge, was fatally shot last weekend by a woman and several youths looking for a rapist, the District of Columbia police said.

The responses of Corrections Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm and the Corporation Counsel's office to Federal District Court Judge Morris E. Lasker's denunciation of conditions in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men are disappointing.

Michael Beaumont, the new Seigneur of Sark, the tiny Island in the English Channel, promised yesterday that he would follow the example of his grandmother during his rule and said that "the last thing. I want to do is drag the island into the 20th century."
The White House denied today charges by Senator Henry M. Jackson that President Nixon had made a secret agreement with Moscow to restrict the number of United States nuclear submarines.
Tom Seaver, whose fundamental importance to the New York Mets is so taken for granted that it often is not fully realized, is at the most difficult stage of his remarkable career.

Governor Byrne's income tax bill won its first legislative test by the narrowest possible margin tonight when the State Assembly approved the proposal by a vote of 41 to 38.

The defense Department today said it would await the result of an inquiry in New Zealand before acting on claims that four New Zealanders killed six American soldiers who were torturing civilians in Vietnam.

A string of business deals by two school custodians who are renting property to the city for leases totaling more than $5million has created a bureaucratic nightmare at the Board of. Education, where officials knew about the situation four years ago but failed to act until recently.

Pato Consolidated Gold Dredging, Ltd., a 65 per centowned subsidiary of the International Mining Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold its mining and related assets In Colombia to a private Columbian group for $16-million.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd announced yesterday that policemen on the streets were being trained for the first time to aid heart attack victims. They are taking a one-day course on mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and external heart massage intended to revive someone whose heart has stopped and who is no longer breathing.
" Mr. Majestyk" is a competently standard showcase for Charles Bronson's superhero cool. This time, as a Colorado melon farmer, he jostles an obsessive killer with syndicate backing Guess who wins.

In a move to improve New England air service, the Civil Aeronautics. Board announced yesterday that it was upgrading Air New England into a fullfledged regional airline corn mitted to operate a basic route network and with authorization to use more comfortable planes.

Bearing the red and gold colors of his uncle's Detroit Red Wings hockey team, Art (Snapper) Norris brought more fame, glory and money to his family today by winning the Hennessy Grand Prix offshore powerboat race in his 36-foot Cigarette Slap Shot. Slap Shot winning the 1974 Hennessy Grand Prix race at Atlantic City yesterday

With the palomino gold and international orange football lost in the basic black of the New York night, the Stars squandered a 26point half-time lead last night and dropped a stunning 32-29 decision to the Birminghim Americans and George Mira in their World Football League home opener. Bob Gladieux (35), Stars' running back, picking up a first down against Birmingham last night in the New York team's home opener at Downing Stadium.

A former Navy pilot, who flew missions over Iwo Jima and Truk in World War II, now is flying all over the country on a more pleasant assignment - judging dogs. He is Jim Frank of El Cajon, Cal if., who is engaged in almost every phase of dog shows.

The former New Haven po1ice chief, James F. Ahern, paid a $20 fine. today after pleading no contest to a disorderly conduct charge. The authorities decided not to prosecute three other charges stemming from a scuffle with

Recruiters or business school graduates rate Harvard and Stanford universities as having the top business schools in the nation, according to a survey sponsored by the Graduate Business Association of Columbia University.

A new type of financial instrument has suddenly appeared in Wall Street. While offering attractive shortterm benefit to small investors and savers, it is sending a shock wave of anguish through the nation's home mortgage market and the housing industry.

The Coast Guard is seeking to find the owner of an old Staten Island ferryboat whose last known owner sold it for scrap for $1. The boat, Dongan Hills, now lies halfsubmerged at a dock in Arthur Kill, leaking oil that has created a costly cleanup problem.
A bomb exploded in a cellar armory at the Tower of London today, ripping through clusters of tourists and injuring 42 of them. One died tonight in a hospital.
Archbishop Makarios smiled broadly today and said: "You should have known it was not that easy for me to die. But tell me, at ,least, were my obituaries good?"
The Baltimore police commissioner has revoked the exclusive bargaining representation of the police union that led to a fiveday strike here.

Merck Co., Inc., one of the world's largest health-products makers, achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half year in its history during the periods ended June 30 the company's results disclosed yesterday.

Executives of the Bookof - the - Month Club, departing from their usual staid decorum yesterday, denounced Doubleday Co. for having legally established the right to use the name Book-of-the Month Club for Its own purposes in Western Australia and Tasmania.

The Comptroller of the Currency has reversed an earlier blanket ban on stock option trading by national banks to permit them to deal in one particular option. The option cleared by Comptroller James E. Smith is for dealing in coveted calls.

Mrs. Carol Polls, saying she used to get "squeamish" when a boxer was knocked out cold but that she has got over it, yesterday became the first woman boxing judge in New York. Carol Polls holding her boxing judge's license.
An editorial in today's issue of The Machinist sheds light on why almost 600 labor strikes are under way in the United States, a large number, perhaps the largest number in 20 years.
Live beef cattle futures rose the 1-cent-a-pound daily permissible limit yesterday in heavy trading of more than 15,000 contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Strikes involving prison guards in Rhode Island and 4,000 state employes in Ohio were settled yesterday, but almost a quarter of a million other Americans were off their jobs because of labor disputes.

If acupuncture hasn't been a major point in theatrical movies heretofore, its value is still debatable to judge by "Golden Needles," which surfaced yesterday at the Cinerama, 59th and 86th Street Twin Theaters.

Having told a Federal judge, "If I don't tell the truth, I will get punished by God," 9-year-old John Calzadilla walked calmly across a crowded courtroom, here today and pointed a finger at two teen-agers charged with kidnapping him.

Reynolds Securities, Inc., one of Wall Street's leading retail houses, reported yesterday a small loss for the quarter ended June 30 and a sharp decline in first-half earnings. Revenues were static in the half.
Prisoners who go on hunger strikes in British jails will no longer be fed by force. After due warning, they will be allowed to die.

Harold G. Faller, president of Sunrise Home Juices, Inc., of Far Rockaway, Queens, died - Mo yesterday in the South Shore Medical Center, Far Rockaway. He was 65 years old and lived at 571 Oak Drive, Far Rockaway.

A young Irish rider, Eddie Macken, took a surprise lead after the speed test that opened the men's world horse-jumping championships today. Macken, riding the 10-year-old Pele, had a faultless round over the 13-fence course, clocking 95.6 seconds. Hugo Simon of Austria was second on Lavendal in 99.1 seconds, followed by Hartwig Steenken of West Germany, who clocked 101.3 on Simona.

President Anwar el-Sadat said in a television interview last night that an Egyptian submarine had put to sea to torpedo the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 when she was on a charter voyage to Israel last year.

A millionaire banker from Texas has bought 'a controlling interest in The Washington Star-News, the capital's sole surviving afternoon newspaper, from members of the three families that have operated it for more than a century.

" The Education of Sonny Carson," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse and 86th Street East theaters, is a howling brute of a film. Riddled with flaws, inexpressive as art, it shakes off its shortcomings with a primal energy that imbues, it with terrifying eloquence.

In an action rare in the, history of science, prominent American biologists, including one winner of the Nobel Prize, are voluntarily renouncing, for the present two types of genetic experiments that they consider could be hazardous.
In a somber outdoor ceremony, Vice President Ford presented the Medal of Honor to the families of one Marine and six Army men who died in 6 acts of heroism in Vietnam.
Two Soviet astronauts are completing nearly two weeks in an orbiting space laboratory and are getting ready to return to earth, Izvestia reported today.

The National Football League has informed the New York Giants that a former member of their organization is being investigated by an "official agency" for gambling associations and other possible irregularities.

Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. urged Mayor Beame to reject a staff recommendation that the Tweed Courthouse, the 19th-century monument to corruption, be demolished. Mr. Wagner, at-large Democrat from Manhattan, said that instead the building should be renovated for an executive headquarters.

Several diplomats, including the American Ambassador, Henry J Tasca, called at the Greek Foreign Ministry today, most of them to urge that Cyprus should remain independent and that the constitutional procedures under which Archbishor Makarios was elected President should be respected.

The tenants of the Stella Wright Homes ended their-four year rent strike today. After years of bitter court fights and exhausting negotiations, an agreement was reached with the Newark Housing Authority that charts a new course in managing the deeply troubled public, housing project. SHIPPENSBURG, Pa. -- The toleration of homosexuality among American. college populations has been regarded as a successor to the antiwar radicalism of the nineteen-sixties and early nineteen-seventies. Individaul hostility and repugnance to homosexuality has bent before a tolerance among students, faculty and administrators, with results unimaginable even a decade ago. We seem to be experiencing a new humanitarianism, a new and more personal revolutionism, not only on the campus but in American society at large.

It is unusual for a selftaught tennis player to win an important tournament. The odds are that he will come up against players who have had better basic training, which will give them an edge. But he may overcome that disadvantage if he plays with determination, tenacity and concentration.

Everyone had a good belly laugh some months back when attorneys for former Cabinet members John N. Mitchell and Maurice Stans argued that the only way their clients could get a fair trial on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Vesco case was for the Federal court proceedings to be moved from New York to Mississippi.
The Arizona State Bar Association said today that its administrative committee was studying possible disciplinary action against former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst.
The nation's hotels and motels are beginning to encounter a new phenomenon: unmarried couples who insist on registering as unmarried couples.

The Justice Department announced yesterday that John Lennon, the former Beatle, had been given 60 days to leave the country or be forcibly deported. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating foreign-exchange transactions between the troubled Franklin National Bank and other financial institutions in which Michele Sindona, an Italian financier who is Franklin's largest stockholder, has an interest, according to well-informed sources.

Animal health officials in Texas and Oklahoma, said today that they had isolated and controlled an anthrax epidemic that had threatened to destroy cattle herds in both states and to spread across the nation.

The United States and India will probably sign an agreement calling for joint cooperation in trade, science, technology, education and culture when Secretary of State Kissinger visits New Delhi in September,. Ambassador T. N. Kaul of India said today.

A bomb exploded in a cellar armory at the Tower of London today, ripping through clusters of tourists and injuring 42 of them. One died tonight in a hospital. Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic gubernatorial contender, called for a halt to the dumping of sludge in the Atlantic Ocean within two years and the development of alternate disposal methods on land He disputed Federal officials who said over weekend that sludge was not a threat to Long Island beaches.

New York's City Planning Commission has been demonstrating an exceptional sensitivity to the factors that make a city a decent and even a desirable place to be. The tool of zoning is being used with unusual skill to achieve this end.

Weather: Partly sunny today; mild tonight, Partly cloudy tomorrow. Temp. range: today 67-86; Wed. 65-86. Highest Temp.-Hum. Index yesterday: 74. Details on Page 70.

Minneola Perry Ingersoll, a former member of the Board of Higher Education and a leading figure in civic and community organizations, died Tuesday of cancer at her home, 135 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. She was 61 years :old. Minneola P. Ingersoll
The Senate passed today and sent to the White House a bill providing $2-billion in loan guarantees to livestock producers.
The Boering Company's first commercial yydrofoil, a craft that will carry 284 passengers across water at 50 miles an hour, was successfully tested

Joseph Yacoe, 14 years ld, of the Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club won his third junior race in three days off Larchmont Yacht Club today and this evening was named as the outstanding junior of the 76th annual Larchmont Race Week.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and educator, condemned yesterday as "absolutely impossible" a plan to integrate Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island by upgarding it to attract white, middle-class pupils.
The Men's Bar at the Biltmore, now a bastion of masculinity in name only, lost another round yesterday in its efforts to remain the Men's Bar.
The Senate voted today to keep most union-management disputes out of the reach of the proposed Federal consumer protection agency.

Turkey, in response to reported requests from the United States and Britain, today took the path of diplomacy and consultation n the Cyprus crisis. Armored personnel carriers moving through Mersin, on the southern coast of Turkey, about 100 miles from Cyprus Youngsters at Mersin harbor watch a Turkish warship nearby. Turkey would not confirm a state of military alert exists.
Diplomats and United Nations officials held intensive private consultations today about Cyprus while awaiting the arrival from London tomorrow of Archbishop Makarios.

After only a few weeks of negotiations, the city reached completee agreement yesterday on new two-year contracts with firemen and sanitationnen. Through a combination of wage and cost-of-living increases, the base pay of the city's 11,000 firemen is expected to rise to $18,000 a year and of the 11,000 sanitationmen to $16,500 by next July 1.

United States banks have increased their foreign lending by $8.5-billion, or about onethird, since the abolition of controls on lending and investment abroad at the end of January, a member of the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today. Andrew F. Brimmer

In less than 24 hours at Candlestick Park, the New York Mets dissipated whatever momentum they had achieved in Los Angeles last weekend, as they followed last night's 9-4 loss to the San Francisco Giants with a 6-2 loss today.
Muhammad Ali, former heavyweight boxing champion, has sold his home here for $175,000 and moved to Chicago.

Hanover Shoe Farms of Hanover, Pa., has paid $1million for 90 per cent interest in Armbro Nesbit, harness racing's most successful pacer of 1974, the United States Trotting Association announced yesterday.
A brief flight over Nicosia today appeared to confirm the assertion by the Cyprus radio, controlled by the rebel national guard, that order had been restored.

The city's Board'of Education and Chancellor Irving.Anker, in a statement last night, blamed inflation, City-Hall budget cutting and changing Federal rules for the loss of at least 6,000 teachers and cutbacks in numerous special programs during the coming school years.

A bomb threat caused the closing of the westbound tube of the Holland Tunnel for 23 minutes yesterday - from 5,23 P.M. to 5:45 P.M. when thousands of motorists were trying to get home to New Jersey. No bomb was found.
Common Cause criticized Governor Wilson yesterday for failing to submit a detailed listing of his campaign contributions and finances, as the two Democratic contenders for Governor had done.
Ford-werke, A.G., one of the Big Four automakers in West Germany, reported toddy a 36 persent sales drop in the first half of 1974, compared with the corresponding period last year.

Yurl Shikhanovich, a dissident Soviet mathematician who had been charged with circulating anti-Soviet propaganda, has reportedly been released from a mental hospital.

Joseph Yacoe, 17 years old, of the Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club, won his third junior race in three days off Larchmont Yacht Club today and this evening was named as the outstanding junior of the 76th anndaui Larchmont Race Week.

Florida's Tommy Reamon scored on a 5-yard run with 97 seconds remaining, then the Blazers stopped the Detroit Wheels on the 1-yard line with 10 seconds left to post an 18-14 World Football League victory tonight.

The weekly cost of feeding a family of four in the city has passed the $60 mark again, a level previously reached only last February during the nationwide truck tie-up. Compared with a year ago, the cost was 14 per cent. higher.

As counsel to President Nixon in the impeachment inquiry, James St. Clair has performed with a rare insouciance. He has had what most lawyers would consider a difficult client with a difficult case, but nothing has seemed to faze him.

Two defense witnesses testified yesterday that relative calm prevailed around Wounded Knee the day that two men charged in connection with the 71-day occupation of the village last year were arrested.

Six elated high school students who represented the United States in the International Mathematical Olympiad in East Germany returned home yesterday, having surprised everyone, including themselves, by finishing second among the 18 competing countries.
After only four months on the job, Clifford W. O'Key, City Manager of Yonkers, abruptly resigned yesterday in a move that took the Republican-dominated administration by surprise.

A bright light suddenly appeared in. the black sky above the bowl of a crescent moon, at about dawn yesterday. It was 5:45 and the sun had just appeared over the horizon, not far below.

The Governor General of Eritrea, Lieut. Gen. Debebe Haile Mariam, and six other high officials of the province have been arrested by the Armed Forces Committee of the North, the Asmara radio said tonight.
The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit has upheld a ruling affirming women's rights to have elective abortions in public hospital in the first three months of pregnancy.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas Bomar, announced today the ending of a special program for buying pools of mortgages from savings and loans institutions.
Morgan Paul Dickerman 2d, associate publisher and general manager of The Wilson Daily Times, died Tuesday night after a long illness. He Was 56 years old.

Governor Wilson today attributed a projected record increase in state spending to inflation but said inflation would also result in more tax revenues, so the state budget would remain balanced without tax increases.

For officials of the nation's 3,106 counties, ending their 39th annual convention today, the New Federalism has meant moer money, additional responsibilities and a new feeling of self-worth.

Dr. Louis Fliegler, chairman of the department of special education at Kent State University, died yesterday. His age was 57.

The international peace-keeping commission met today for its first regular session in three months. The agenda was routine, but informed sources said the meeting was intended to prod the North Vietnamese and' South Vietnamese to resume suspended military and political negotiations.

Louis De Funes, reportedly the biggest thing to hit French films since Brigitte Bardot, is a tiny middle-aged man, bald and usually frowning. He looks a little bit like Leon Errol, but he acts a lot more like a souped-up version of Edgar Kennedy.

Dizzy Dean, a farmboy who pitched his way into the Baseball Hall of Fame with a blazing fastball, died here early today in St. Mary's Hospital at the age of 63. Dizzy Dean Dizzy Dean pitching in 1937, year his career was cut short when he changed delivery because of a toe injury.

Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, whose arm was fractured in a fracas yesterday while he was inspecting migrant labor camps at a farm near here, and two other persons were accused today by Fred J. Sorbello of trespassing on the farm of Rosario Sorbello Sons.

As a team of independent accountants Worked through the night to complete a special city audit, it was learned that their final report would show that the city may have had $40million to $45-million more on deposit last December 31 than the controller's official records indicated.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation reported yesterday an increase of 18.3 per-cent in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 13.8 per cent. For the first six months the forest products company's net, a record, was up 17.6 per cent while sales were 13 per cent higher than a year ago.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that tension between the United States and its European allies had largely disappeared and Atlantic relations could now be viewed in a "rather relaxed way."
Portugal ended a week of political crisis today with a new Government heavily dominated by the armed forces.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation for its first quarter ended June 29 are expected to show a 7.5 per cent increase to 57 cents a share from 53 cents a share a year earlier, James L. Ferguson, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday in White Plains.

A divisive battle over the reorganization of House committees was reopened today when a committee of Democratic Representatives proposed a plan that would reduce the power of the House Rules Committee and increase the power of the Speaker.

A White House official criticized a CBS television newsman today for not having identified the source of a report but then offered a tentative apology when told the source was Secretary of State Kissinger.

The Italian Minister of the Treasury, Emilio Colombo, told Parliament tonight that the Italian Government had obtained from the European Economic Community the promise of a loan, "in various forms," of $1.82-billion.

A proposal to amend Worcester's human rights ordinance and extend protection against discrimination to homosexuals has been voted down by the city council.

United States and British military officials are concerned that a prolonged Greek-Turkish political dispute or war - if Greece moves toward union with Cyprus-might wreck defense deployments of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the eastern basin of the Mediterranean.

Dr. William H. Conley, who retired July 1 as chancellor of Sacred Heart University in Bridgeport, Conn., died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport, He was 67 years old.
The Tweed Courthouse, a symbol of 19th-century elegance to some and of 19thcentury corruption to others, was praised for both its aspects yesterday at a rally to urge the building's preservation.

"Let's go to the ballet," a Queens man suggested to his wife last Sunday. And off they went, not to Lincoln Center or City Center in Manhattan, but to Alley Pond Park in Queens, where the Long Island Ballet Theater was packing them in.

The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer after E. I. du Pont de Nemours, achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half year in its history in the periods ended June 30.

Amax, Inc., announced yesterday a 21 1/2-cent-a-pound increase in its base price for special high-grade zinc, used mostly for die castings and in automobile parts. The new base is 39 cents f.o.b. the company's Sauget, Ill., plant.
Mark Hayes birdied the first five holes he played today, and finished with a 66 as he tied four others for the lead after the first round of the $150,000 B.C. open golf tournament.

The United States should not withdraw recognition from the Cypriote Government of Archbishop Makarios without Congressional approval, Representative Ogden R. Reid, New York Democrat, said today.

To the Editor: The Times should be commended for giving so much attention to the world hunger problem recently. Your editorials have drawn attention to what may become the greatest human tragedy the world has ever witnessed unless immediate steps are taken to increase global food production.

Following is the text of a White House memorandum from Egil Krogh Jr. and David R. Young to John D. Ehrlichman indicating the Department of Defense's view of the Government's case against Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today a proposal to adjust capital. gains taxes for inflation. It would allow taxpayers to exclude from taxable capital gains 1 per cent of the cost of an asset for each year it was held.

Following is the text of a psychiatric profile of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency at the direction of the White House. The profile, the second of two prepared, was compiled by a man who had never met Dr. Ellsberg.
President Nikolai V. Podgorny today lent his weight to charges in the Soviet press that some NATO circles had backed the coup in Cyprus on Monday.

A strike against the Long island Rail Road was threatened yesterday for 12:01 A.M. next Monday by a union of 50 civil engineers, architects and draftsmen after cooling-off requirements under the Railway Labor Act ended.
The new Government of the rebels says that life is back to normal here and indeed there is calm in this capital city ringed by 16th-century Venetian walls. There is reason for the calm.

Ten months ago, the State Division of Criminal Justice Services set up a toll-free telephone number and offered a $1,000 reward to anyone who turned in a drug pusher. But despite a total of 7,440 calls through the middle of this week, the plan has resulted in only one major conviction, wfor which htattes w viction, for which the state will mail out a $1,000 check next week.

The directors of the Gillette Company, the razor-blade giant based in Boston, have appointed Collman M. Mockler Jr. as president and chief operating officer. His appointment, announced yesterday, ended several weeks of speculation over the successor to Edward Gelsthorpe, who unexpectedly resigned as president three weeks ago after serving in that post for less than 14 months.

Irving, Lemov, a lawyer here 45 years and a founder of the Fusion party that backed Fiorello H. La Guardia for Mayor, died, of cancer yesterday at University Hospital. He was '73 years old and lived at 21-43 77th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
The Coast Guard reported yesterday that all public and private beaches along a 27mile stretch of Suffolk County on Long Island Sound had been cleared of oil and were reopening for swimming.

Following are the texts of a memo and a background paper prepared in the White House on Leonard B. Boudin, the lawyer who defended Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. The material was prepared by E. Howard Hunt and transmitted by John D. Ehrlichman to Charles W. Colson.

The Health Department released yesterday the names of 32 physicians, dentists, podiatrists, chiropractors, pharmacists and optometrists it had suspended permanently from treating Medicaid patients because of abuses ranging from fraud to poor care. The list covers the period from 1971 to the present.
A public hearing on the Board of Education's plan to integrate Brooklyn's Franklin K. Lane High School will be held early next month by Federal Judge John F. Dooling Jr.

NEWPORT, R. I. - Inflation?' For the 250 or so super-rich American families summering in their enclave here, it is but a distant happeining like summer lightning, something to notice, but not a present reality that much crimps traditional life-styles. True, there are some complaints about clover in the lawn, of help being hard to get, of women doing their own' dusting, but that's about all.
Greece made a concession in the Cyprus crisis today by agreeing to replace the 650 Greek officers in the Cypriote National Guard.

John Huarte, enjoying one of his finest games in a welltraveled professional career, threw two touchdown passes tonight and guided the Memphis Southmen to a 16-8 World Football League victory over the Portland Storm.

The Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Russell E, Train, said today that the White House had unquestionably loosened its tight hold on the executive branch of the Federal Government in recent months.

Secretary of State Kissinger and Senator Henry M. Jackson agreed today that they had made progress toward a formula for expediting Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union and Congressional passage of trade benefits to Mossow.

Simas Kudirka, ruled a United States citizen by the State Department three years after his unsuccessful attempt to defect from a Soviet fishing trawler, "is a Soviet citizen and subject to Soviet laws," a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

Overriding conservative opposition, the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation that would create a permanent system of Federal legal assistance for the poor. The measure was sent to the White House.

The House Judiciary Committee published today a mass of evidence that appeared to challenge President Nixon's contention that national security was the sole basis for White House involvement in wiretaps and the so-called "plumbers" operations.

British and American doctors have linked the use of oral contraceptives to an increased risk of developing an benign liver tumor. If not promptly diagnosed and properly treated, the tumor can lead to. a serious and fatal hemorrhage according to a report in the current issue of the British Medical Journal.

The New York Starswould just as soon avoid a repetition of their 32-29 loss to the Birmingham Americans, but if a similar tragedy should occur on their home field in the future, at least they'll have a clearer view of it happening.

Karl Klasen,president of the West German Bundesbank, said today there were no legal provisions for giving special help to foreign banks, which incurred losses in foreignexchange dealings as a result of last month's collapse of one of the country's largest private banks.

A group of perfume experts gathered Wednesday to try to make life a little easier for consumers. They defined toilet water and cologne (toilet water is stronger). They discussed the confusion caused by the various names and strengths of both toilet waters and colognes. And, in the end, they agreed that nothing would ever replace the nose.
Two leading Japanese auto makers said today they had accepted a steep price increase for steel sheet proposed by six major steel companies.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland--The divided and ferociously quarreling Northern Irish people have now been ordered by the understandably impatient British Government to get together and, subject to certain conditions, essentially involving power-shar. ing between the Protestant majority and Roman Catholic minority, work out a sensible solution to the repellent mess that religious distrust and competing political loyalties have made of the otherwise lovely little six-county province.

Nikos Giorgiades Sampson, the new President of Cyprus, charged in his first press conference today that the ousted government of Archbishop Makarios had systematically tortured its political opponents and "flagrantly violated" the human rights of all Cypriotes.
More than 1,500 of President Nixon's most ardent supporters gave an enthusiastic demonstration of their confidence in him and his Administration tonight.

A gorgeous, new and under-rehearsed production of "Coppelia," with choreography credited to both George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova, "after Petipa,"-was unveiled here last night by the New York City Ballet amid great excitement and acclaim.
The nation's total output of goods and services declined somewhat further in the second quarter but the rate of inflation diminished, Commerce Department figures indicated today.

United States auto production climbed 3,000 units this week despite strikes, vacations and change-overs but still was 27.5 per cent below output during the, same week last year, the trade publication Automotive News said today.

Showers and thundershowers are forecast today for the Northeast and the Pacific Northwest. It will be slightly cooler from the Ohio Valley to the lake region, and also over Arizona and northern California.

Buyers of defective backyard swimming pools described at a hearing today how they had been deceived by slick salesmen.
Prof. Douglas Bevis, the British gynecologist who announced that three babies conceived outside the womb had been born normally, said today he was giving up research into creating test-tube babies.
Emma Borlsovna Hurok, widow of Sol Hurok, the impresario who died March 5, died yesterday at her home, 91 Central Park West. She was about 80 years old.

A splendid opportunity has now presented itself for President Nixon to demonstrate how determined he really is to check inflation and eliminate wasteful Government programs. The Senate has passed and rushed to the President for signature the House version of a bill providing $2 billion in loan guarantees for producers of beef cattle, dairy cattle, hogs, sheep, goats, chickens and turkeys.

Police officials yesterday disclosed a campaign to rid the force of policemen who are performing below par and said that next Wednesday for the first time, two men would be brought to trial on charges of "incompetency."

Turkey today extended her territorial waters in the disputed Aegean Sea over a large area where Greece claims sovereignty. The official Gazette published a map indicating Turkey was expanding the sea area over which she claims jurisdiction to cover an additional 3,900 square miles toward the Greek coast.

As Knute Rockne told it when he coached football at Notre Dame, he had played soccer in Chicago as a youth and had come to respect this hard-running game as a swift route to physical fitness. For the first few days of fall practice, he decided, he would have the athletes play soccer to work off the summer's flab.
Prices of fixed-income securities continued to improve yesterday in anticipation of the Federal Reserve's weekly report on business borrowings, which was announced after banking hours as usual.
The Spingold upsets began early this year at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals at the Americana Hotel here.

While representatives of about 600 of 856 office skyscrapers met yesterday's deadline for filing plans for dealing with fires, one major building owner charged that the law was unconstitutional and that it -was making buildings "more unsafe," with liability thrust upon operators.
Charles T. McQueeney, retired managing editor of The New Haven Register, died yesterday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in North Haven.
Two of the biggest railroad holding companies, Burlington Northern, Inc., and Seaboard Coast Line Industries, reported sharply higher earnings yesterday for the second quarter.
Achibald Cox, the man hired and dismissed by President Nixon as special Watergate prosecutor, has eased back into his role as professor of law at Harvard.

Daniel J. Gautieri is probably the worst-paid manager and coach ever to have directed teams to 1,000 victories. The 55-year-old Montclair resident began coaching, managing and organizing teams in 1936 with a local team called the Maple Leafs.

Representative William J. Randall, Democrat of Missouri, said today that the Government Operations subcommittee he heads had voted to turn over to the Justice Department all the evidence it had assembled on allegations of corruption in the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Over the strong objection of the City Council President, Paul O'Dwyer, the Board of Estimate approved yesterday a $300,000 city contract with the New York City-Rand Institute for studies of the Fire Department.

Dr. James S. Edlin, a pioneer in the treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis, died Sunday at his home, 120 East Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, N.Y. He was 85 years old.
A twelvefoot wing section of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet broke off over Sydney this morning, smashing into homes in two suburbs.
